<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/wordcamp-london-2018/">10up supports WordCamp London</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-gabe-karp" title="Posts by Gabe Karp" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Gabe-Karp_avatar_1511804624-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2017/11/Gabe-Karp_avatar_1511804624-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Gabe Karp</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/wordcamp-london-2018/" title="10up supports WordCamp London"><time datetime="2018-04-10T11:01:15-04:00">April 10, 2018</time></a>
</p>


<div class="event-meta">

<time datetime="2013-12-14T00:00">
<span class="mo">Apr</span>
13</time>

<p class="event-title">WordCamp London&nbsp;2018</p>

<p class="location">London Metropolitan University</p>

<div class="meta">
<span class="attending">Attending</span>
<span class="speaking">Speaking</span>
<span class="sponsoring">Sponsoring</span>
</div>
</div>

<p>This weekend, catch me and 6 of my fellow 10uppers at WordCamp London 2018, an annual WordPress conference supported in part by our <a href="https://2018.london.wordcamp.org/sponsors/#wcorg-sponsor-2765">Academy Sponsorship</a>. On Sunday, I’ll be talking about <a href="https://2018.london.wordcamp.org/session/designing-the-content-creation-experience-panel/">Applying Design To Complex Problems</a> alongside one of our UK clients, Press Association. Later that afternoon, Front End Engineer Daine Mawer presents, “<a href="https://2018.london.wordcamp.org/session/developing-wordpress-for-limited-bandwidth/">Developing WordPress for Limited Bandwidth</a>.” Those taking a break from the sessions can stop by the 10up sponsor table and learn more our growing <a href="https://10up.com/europe">10up Europe team</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-19195 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-uncategorized engineering-practices-accessibility-standards">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/engineering-practices-accessibility-standards/">10up Engineering Practices now mandate baseline accessibility standards</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/" title="Posts by " rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo avatar-default" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> </a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/engineering-practices-accessibility-standards/" title="10up Engineering Practices now mandate baseline accessibility standards"><time datetime="2018-03-30T13:06:18-04:00">March 30, 2018</time></a>
</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignright wp-image-19198" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/w3c-wcag-300x217.png" alt="W3C WCAG 2.0" width="218" height="158" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2018/03/w3c-wcag-300x217.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/03/w3c-wcag-300x217-171x124.png 171w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/03/w3c-wcag-300x217-124x90.png 124w" sizes="(max-width: 218px) 100vw, 218px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;">One year ago, the popular government policy magazine Open Access Government stated, “<a href="https://www.openaccessgovernment.org/accessibility-option-fundamental-right/32591/">Accessibility for all is not an option – it’s a fundamental right.</a>” Creating equal access to digital content, regardless of age, size, ability, or disability, has always been a priority for 10up; it is inseparable from our mission to make a better internet for everyone. Creating accessible interfaces for our projects is consistent with our commitment to the <a href="http://universaldesign.ie/What-is-Universal-Design/">principles of Universal Design</a>. Because of this, <strong>we have updated the accessibility standards contained in our <a href="https://10up.github.io/Engineering-Best-Practices/markup/#accessibility">Engineering Best Practices</a> to require all projects to have a baseline accessibility compliance goal of WCAG 2.0 Level A</strong>.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/engineering-practices-accessibility-standards/#more-19195" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on 10up Engineering Practices now mandate baseline accessibility standards</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-19069 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-projects contributing-google-amp-project">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/contributing-google-amp-project/">10up contributes MathML support to Google&nbsp;AMP</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-thorsten-ott" title="Posts by Thorsten Ott" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TOtt-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/TOtt-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Thorsten Ott</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/contributing-google-amp-project/" title="10up contributes MathML support to Google AMP"><time datetime="2018-03-14T12:26:36-04:00">March 14, 2018</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/contributing-google-amp-project/#comments" class="comments-count">2 Comments</a>
</p>
<p>Last year, we found ourselves implementing <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2016/amp-google-publishers/">Google AMP</a> for a client who often includes content with mathematical formulas. The formulas were implemented using the open <a href="https://www.w3.org/Math/">MathML standard</a>, by way of the open source, JavaScript-based <a href="https://www.mathjax.org/">MathJax engine</a>. Working around AMP’s JavaScript restriction, we put the formulas into <a href="https://www.ampproject.org/docs/reference/components/amp-iframe">amp-iframe components</a>, which allow for arbitrary JavaScript execution. This workaround posed some limitations that compromised the design: formulas could not be displayed inline (inside of a paragraph), creating a slightly awkward aesthetic that didn’t quite match up with the “full” site’s presentation.</p>
<p>As a regular open source contributor committed to making a better web, it seemed to me that a native AMP implementation of the MathML standard would solve our client’s layout problem and help other developers and site owners. After a bit of background research, I opened an issue on Google’s open source <a href="https://github.com/ampproject/amphtml/issues/12800">AMP HTML project</a>.</p>
<p>With a prompt and warm welcome, Google’s team accepted my feature request. This being an <a href="https://github.com/ampproject/amphtml#wed-love-your-help-making-amp-better">open source project</a>, I volunteered to help; my offer was greeted with enthusiasm and some tips.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone wp-image-19076 size-full" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Amp-Formula-e1521044549579.png" alt="Formulas in iFrames and in-line" width="673" height="407" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2018/02/Amp-Formula-e1521044549579.png 673w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/02/Amp-Formula-e1521044549579-300x181.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/02/Amp-Formula-e1521044549579-205x124.png 205w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/02/Amp-Formula-e1521044549579-149x90.png 149w" sizes="(max-width: 673px) 100vw, 673px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/contributing-google-amp-project/#more-19069" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on 10up contributes MathML support to Google&nbsp;AMP</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-19130 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-happenings 10up-seven-year-anniversary">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/10up-seven-year-anniversary/">Lucky number 7: 10up’s seventh&nbsp;year</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/10up-seven-year-anniversary/" title="Lucky number 7: 10up’s seventh year"><time datetime="2018-02-12T16:20:04-05:00">February 12, 2018</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/10up-seven-year-anniversary/#comments" class="comments-count">2 Comments</a>
</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-19142" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/7-birthday@2x.jpg" alt="10up turns 7" width="1544" height="500" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2018/02/7-birthday@2x.jpg 1544w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/02/7-birthday@2x-300x97.jpg 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/02/7-birthday@2x-768x249.jpg 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/02/7-birthday@2x-800x259.jpg 800w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/02/7-birthday@2x-220x71.jpg 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/02/7-birthday@2x-160x52.jpg 160w" sizes="(max-width: 1544px) 100vw, 1544px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p>In our seventh year, we built on our <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/six-year-anniversary/">investment in culture and storytelling</a> by expanding our team and depth of services, and by redoubling our investments in open source and creativity.</p>
<p>We welcomed <strong>more than 30 new clients</strong> to our portfolio in another record sales year. We launched new websites along with web and mobile apps for major brands across <strong>verticals as diverse as finance, healthcare, academia, high-tech, big media, consumer packaged goods, food and beverage, and fitness</strong>… to name a few.</p>
<p>In a milestone event, we completed <strong>an <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/10up-acquires-lift-ux/">acquisition of Lift UX</a>, a boutique, Emmy-nominated agency</strong> that focused on user experience for design-driven websites powered by WordPress. Intended to strengthen our experience design expertise and resources, this investment added executive design leadership and expanded our portfolio of design stories.</p>
<p>A renewed approach to <strong>our All Hands Summit yielded our largest and most memorable team event</strong> to date. Held in Old San Juan, Puerto Rico, our team gathered from around the world to take over a former <a href="http://www.elconvento.com/">Carmelite convent</a> for a week of learning, sharing, building memories together, uniting around company goals, and celebrating our successes. Among the conference highlights, we held our first client panel, featuring leaders from companies like Microsoft, McClatchy, and Beasley Radio sharing insights on agency partnerships.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/10up-seven-year-anniversary/#more-19130" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Lucky number 7: 10up’s seventh&nbsp;year</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-19082 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-around-the-web text-to-podcast-amazon-polly">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/text-to-podcast-amazon-polly/">Transforming text into a natural sounding podcast with Amazon&nbsp;Polly</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-gabe-karp" title="Posts by Gabe Karp" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Gabe-Karp_avatar_1511804624-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2017/11/Gabe-Karp_avatar_1511804624-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Gabe Karp</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/text-to-podcast-amazon-polly/" title="Transforming text into a natural sounding podcast with Amazon Polly"><time datetime="2018-02-09T14:25:06-05:00">February 9, 2018</time></a>
</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-19084" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/banner-772x250.png" alt="Amazon Polly" width="772" height="250" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2018/02/banner-772x250.png 772w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/02/banner-772x250-300x97.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/02/banner-772x250-768x250.png 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/02/banner-772x250-220x71.png 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/02/banner-772x250-160x52.png 160w" sizes="(max-width: 772px) 100vw, 772px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p>Earlier this week one of our partners, WP Engine, released a plugin that leverages Amazon Polly to transform written content into lifelike speech, directly from WordPress. Being dedicated to helping our clients deliver great digital content experiences, we were eager to help pilot this integration with WP Engine by finding a launch partner. Collaborating with POLITICO in Europe, we transformed their daily political newsletters – Brussels Playbook and London Playbook – into engaging podcasts.</p>
<p>Here’s what POLITICO had to say about their new integration, in <a href="https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20180208005136/en/WP-Engine-Amazon-Web-Services-Bring-Voice">WP Engine’s press release</a>:</p>
<blockquote><p>“Our readers are digesting news and stories through their mobile and voice-driven devices more and more,” said Johannes Boege, Chief Product Officer at POLITICO in Europe. “This is a great opportunity for us along with our agency 10up to test the distribution of our content with voice technology. We are excited to use Amazon Polly to reach more people in new ways.”</p></blockquote>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/text-to-podcast-amazon-polly/#more-19082" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Transforming text into a natural sounding podcast with Amazon&nbsp;Polly</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-19035 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-projects chrome-enforces-ad-standards">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/chrome-enforces-ad-standards/">Google Chrome to aggressively enforce Better Ad&nbsp;Standards</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/mikebal/" title="Posts by Mike Bal" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Mike-Bal-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/01/Mike-Bal-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Mike Bal</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/chrome-enforces-ad-standards/" title="Google Chrome to aggressively enforce Better Ad Standards"><time datetime="2018-01-31T13:42:08-05:00">January 31, 2018</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/chrome-enforces-ad-standards/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<p>As announced in <strong>June, beginning February 15th <a href="https://support.google.com/webtools/answer/7308033?vid=0-1088244580613-1515531967670">Chrome will remove all ads on websites</a> that do not meet the <a href="https://www.betterads.org/standards/">standards of the Coalition for Better Ads</a></strong>. Sites will have 30 days to address any issues flagged in Google’s compliance report before Chrome begins removing ads.</p>
<p>Google started this initiative in response to a report suggesting that poor ad experiences are responsible for a <a href="https://pagefair.com/blog/2017/adblockreport/">30% increase in the use of ad blocking extensions</a> across the web, which “<a href="https://blog.chromium.org/2017/06/improving-advertising-on-web.html">reduces the ability for publishers to continue creating free content and threatens the sustainability of the web ecosystem.</a>” Google is also on the board of the Coalition for Better Ad Standards.</p>
<p>The Coalition for Better Ads is made up of leading international trade associations and online media companies committed to supporting “<a href="https://www.betterads.org/">valuable free content, robust journalism and social connections across the internet</a>” through the use of online ads. Their vision for better online ads&nbsp;aligns with Google’s view, and led Google to join the effort to improve how people experience the web. Knowing that consumers are increasingly frustrated with web ads, the Coalition for Better Ads surveyed over <a href="https://www.betterads.org/research/">25,000 internet users</a> to create a set of consumer-friendly standards. Google will apply these standards to review a subset of a site’s pages.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone wp-image-19037 size-full" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Google-Ad-Experience-Report-e1517423694842.png" alt="Google Ad Experience Report" width="2377" height="773" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2018/01/Google-Ad-Experience-Report-e1517423694842.png 2377w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/01/Google-Ad-Experience-Report-e1517423694842-300x98.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/01/Google-Ad-Experience-Report-e1517423694842-768x250.png 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/01/Google-Ad-Experience-Report-e1517423694842-800x260.png 800w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/01/Google-Ad-Experience-Report-e1517423694842-220x72.png 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/01/Google-Ad-Experience-Report-e1517423694842-160x52.png 160w" sizes="(max-width: 2377px) 100vw, 2377px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/chrome-enforces-ad-standards/#more-19035" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Google Chrome to aggressively enforce Better Ad&nbsp;Standards</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-18984 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-projects new-relic-reporting">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/new-relic-reporting/">New Relic features 10up&nbsp;plugin</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-vasken-hauri" title="Posts by Vasken Hauri" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/VHauri-600x600-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2016/11/VHauri-600x600-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Vasken Hauri</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/new-relic-reporting/" title="New Relic features 10up plugin"><time datetime="2018-01-15T05:00:26-05:00">January 15, 2018</time></a>
</p>
<p>New Relic has included our <a href="https://github.com/10up/wp-newrelic">New Relic Reporting for WordPress plugin</a> in <a href="https://newrelic.com/connect/details#wpnewrelic">New Relic Connect</a>, a directory that collects recommended integrations for New Relic customers. This plugin makes important WordPress data available in New Relic APM and Insights. You can now see Post ID and User ID for logged-in transactions, theme and template information and more, along with your other application data. We hope this increased visibility will lead to more WordPress developers getting the most out of New Relic.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone wp-image-18996 size-full" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/WP-New-Relic.png" alt="" width="2656" height="2056" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2018/01/WP-New-Relic.png 2656w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/01/WP-New-Relic-300x232.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/01/WP-New-Relic-768x595.png 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/01/WP-New-Relic-800x619.png 800w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/01/WP-New-Relic-160x124.png 160w, https://10up.com/uploads/2018/01/WP-New-Relic-116x90.png 116w" sizes="(max-width: 2656px) 100vw, 2656px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/new-relic-wordpress/">Learn more about the plugin</a> or <a href="https://github.com/10up/wp-newrelic">download it from GitHub</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-18979 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-projects improving-wordpress-transients">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/improving-wordpress-transients/">Improving WordPress Transients</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-thorsten-ott" title="Posts by Thorsten Ott" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TOtt-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/TOtt-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Thorsten Ott</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/improving-wordpress-transients/" title="Improving WordPress Transients"><time datetime="2018-01-08T14:29:44-05:00">January 8, 2018</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/improving-wordpress-transients/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<p>Modern websites can be complex, especially when a high traffic site offers advanced features that need more intensive server processing. WordPress has a few tricks up its sleeve to help developers improve performance, but as we’ve <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/engineering-challenges-caching/">written about before</a>, those tricks don’t always scale.</p>
<p>If you’ve been engineering performant sites with WordPress, you’ve probably encountered the Transients API—a basic caching method. What developers may not know is, at scale, the synchronous way WordPress handles transients can lead to performance issues that can result in a poor user experience. That’s where <a href="https://github.com/10up/Async-Transients">Async Transients</a> comes in, our open-source Composer library for WordPress transients.<br>
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2018/improving-wordpress-transients/#more-18979" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Improving WordPress Transients</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>

<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/countdown-to-2018/">Countdown to&nbsp;2018</a></h1>

</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone wp-image-18974 size-full" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/holiday_header-1.png" alt="" width="800" height="415" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2017/12/holiday_header-1.png 800w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/12/holiday_header-1-300x156.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/12/holiday_header-1-768x398.png 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/12/holiday_header-1-220x114.png 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/12/holiday_header-1-160x83.png 160w" sizes="(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>

<p>We thought we’d turn last year’s <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2016/2016-holiday-schedule/">holiday break post</a> into a tradition, so we asked some of our team: what are we doing while we’re away from our keyboards for 11 days?</p>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-18944 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-projects ads-txt-manager-for-wordpress">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/ads-txt-manager-for-wordpress/">Ads.txt Manager for&nbsp;WordPress</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/helen/" title="Posts by Helen Hou-Sandi" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Helen Hou-Sandí" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/HHouSandi-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/HHouSandi-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Helen Hou-Sandi</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/ads-txt-manager-for-wordpress/" title="Ads.txt Manager for WordPress"><time datetime="2017-12-18T16:52:37-05:00">December 18, 2017</time></a>
</p>
<p>We’re making it easier and a bit safer to manage the ads.txt whitelist for publishers using WordPress with our newest plugin: <strong><a href="https://wordpress.org/plugins/ads-txt/#description">Ads.txt Manager for WordPress</a></strong>.<b> Site administrators can add and edit their site’s ads.txt file from the WordPress admin interface</b>, eliminating the need to upload a new copy of ads.txt with every change or correction, and applying some validation to prevent simple ads.txt mistakes.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-18946 size-full" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Manage-ads-txt.png" alt="" width="893" height="551" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2017/12/Manage-ads-txt.png 893w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/12/Manage-ads-txt-300x185.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/12/Manage-ads-txt-768x474.png 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/12/Manage-ads-txt-800x494.png 800w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/12/Manage-ads-txt-201x124.png 201w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/12/Manage-ads-txt-146x90.png 146w" sizes="(max-width: 893px) 100vw, 893px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/ads-txt-manager-for-wordpress/#more-18944" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Ads.txt Manager for&nbsp;WordPress</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-18929 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-projects wp-snapshots-share-wordpress-setup">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/wp-snapshots-share-wordpress-setup/">Meet WP Snapshots: share complete snapshots of a WordPress setup</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-taylor-lovett" title="Posts by Taylor Lovett" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TLovett-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/TLovett-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Lovett</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/wp-snapshots-share-wordpress-setup/" title="Meet WP Snapshots: share complete snapshots of a WordPress setup"><time datetime="2017-12-11T12:05:05-05:00">December 11, 2017</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/wp-snapshots-share-wordpress-setup/#comments" class="comments-count">2 Comments</a>
</p>
<p>We’d like to introduce you to our latest open source project: <a href="http://github.com/10up/wpsnapshots" rel="noopener">WP Snapshots</a>.</p>
<p>WP Snapshots is a <strong>command line interface (CLI) tool that empowers engineering teams to quickly share WordPress projects</strong> – including files and the database. Up until now, onboarding a new engineer onto a project has been tedious: he or she had to setup a local development environment, check out repositories, install matching versions of WordPress and any plugins, track down and import database dumps, copy over uploaded media, search and replace paths in the database, and so on. <strong>WP Snapshots turns a painstaking process into a few simple commands.</strong></p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-18931 size-large" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/WP-snapshots-command-example-800x292.png" alt="WP snapshots command example." width="650" height="237" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/wp-snapshots-share-wordpress-setup/#more-18929" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Meet WP Snapshots: share complete snapshots of a WordPress setup</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-18906 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-projects ads-in-a-gutenberg-world">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/ads-in-a-gutenberg-world/">Ads in a Gutenberg World</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/helen/" title="Posts by Helen Hou-Sandi" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Helen Hou-Sandí" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/HHouSandi-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/HHouSandi-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Helen Hou-Sandi</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/ads-in-a-gutenberg-world/" title="Ads in a Gutenberg World"><time datetime="2017-12-01T14:28:26-05:00">December 1, 2017</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/ads-in-a-gutenberg-world/#comments" class="comments-count">6 Comments</a>
</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-18920" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/ad-block-header.png" alt="" width="1600" height="822" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2017/12/ad-block-header.png 1600w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/12/ad-block-header-300x154.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/12/ad-block-header-768x395.png 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/12/ad-block-header-800x411.png 800w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/12/ad-block-header-220x113.png 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/12/ad-block-header-160x82.png 160w" sizes="(max-width: 1600px) 100vw, 1600px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p>Think about those times when ads were intrusive as you read a story on the web: perhaps a distracting video ad interrupting paragraphs just as you were becoming immersed in the narrative, or a tone-deaf ad showing up alongside coverage of a somber event. If you’re a content creator or publisher, think about the times when the “it’s a surprise!” nature of programmatically inserted ads has been a pain point.</p>
<p>As content management systems (CMS) increasingly move to “block-based” editors that are much more visually representative of the final state on the front end, we have an opportunity to design tools that better recognize and integrate advertisements as part of the editorial process. <strong>Rather than treating ads as an afterthought, what if we start treating them as a fully integrated component of the content as it’s constructed?</strong></p>
<p>With our preferred CMS – WordPress –&nbsp;heavily investing in a new block-based editor, code-named <a href="https://wordpress.org/gutenberg/">Gutenberg,</a> our Revenue Strategists and Platform team saw an opportunity to contribute by experimenting with handling ad placement inside of the editor. At the heart of Gutenberg is a block-based method of creating and managing your content, shifting to a unified site-wide “block” concept that further empowers content creators to make their work look just the way they want. We thought: <strong>shouldn’t advertisements be one of those blocks?</strong></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/ads-in-a-gutenberg-world/#more-18906" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Ads in a Gutenberg World</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-18888 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-projects tag-open-source tag-plugin tag-wordpress distributor-plugin">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/distributor-plugin/">Distributor plugin: Share content between your WordPress sites</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-taylor-lovett" title="Posts by Taylor Lovett" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TLovett-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/TLovett-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Lovett</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/distributor-plugin/" title="Distributor plugin: Share content between your WordPress sites"><time datetime="2017-11-28T03:00:10-05:00">November 28, 2017</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/distributor-plugin/#comments" class="comments-count">62 Comments</a>
</p>
<p><strong>Meet the newest addition to 10up’s suite of powerful, open source tools for content creators and managers: <a href="https://distributorplugin.com/">Distributor</a>.</strong></p>
<p>Distributor is a WordPress plugin that <strong>empowers content managers to safely reuse and syndicate content across their websites</strong>, supporting sites within a <a href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Create_A_Network">WordPress multisite network</a> and across the web using the <a href="https://developer.wordpress.org/rest-api/">REST API</a>. Designed with an <strong>intuitive user experience</strong> at the forefront, Distributor integrates “push” and “pull” use cases.</p>
<p>The sharing interface is accessible from the admin bar when viewing a single piece of content in the editor or on the front end. Without leaving the content – and with just a couple of clicks – content managers can “push” the content to any other sites where he or she has permission to publish. <strong>Think of it as a “retweet” feature for your WordPress sites.</strong></p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-18893 size-full" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/push-screenshot.jpg" alt="Shares posts across a network" width="1782" height="1092" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2017/11/push-screenshot.jpg 1782w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/11/push-screenshot-300x184.jpg 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/11/push-screenshot-768x471.jpg 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/11/push-screenshot-800x490.jpg 800w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/11/push-screenshot-202x124.jpg 202w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/11/push-screenshot-147x90.jpg 147w" sizes="(max-width: 1782px) 100vw, 1782px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/distributor-plugin/#more-18888" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Distributor plugin: Share content between your WordPress sites</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>

<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/klein-news-innovation-camp-web-summit-wordcamps-and-other-recent-10up-talks/">Klein News Innovation Camp, Web Summit, WordCamps, and Other Recent 10up&nbsp;Talks</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-john-eckman" title="Posts by John Eckman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="John Eckman" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/jeckman-64x64.png" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2019/11/jeckman-128x128.png 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> John Eckman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/klein-news-innovation-camp-web-summit-wordcamps-and-other-recent-10up-talks/" title="Klein News Innovation Camp, Web Summit, WordCamps, and Other Recent 10up Talks"><time datetime="2017-11-02T17:44:18-04:00">November 2, 2017</time></a>
</p>
<p><strong>Service</strong> (to our clients, our colleagues, and our communities) is one of 10up’s core values, and one way we see that value made concrete is in sponsoring and speaking at various conferences connected to WordPress, content publishing, and generally making the web a better place.</p>
<p>This fall has been especially busy – so much so we’ve neglected to share updates here.</p>
<h2>Upcoming:</h2>
<p>Gabe Karp, 10up’s Business Director in Europe, will be speaking next week at <a href="https://websummit.com/">Web Summit 2017</a> in Lisbon.&nbsp;The “largest tech conference in the world,” WebSummit brings 25 different conferences together in one physical space over 4 days. Gabe will be part of a Marketing Technology panel in the Growth Summit track on Nov. 7th</p>
<p>10up is excited to sponsor <a href="https://tp.ticketleap.com/kleincamp17/">Klein News Innovation Camp</a> (formerly Barcamp News Innovation), an open, unconference style event being held at Temple University in Philadelphia on November 4th, focused on the future of news and how we can improve communities and conversations across the web. I’m looking forward to participating personally – let me know on twitter (<a href="http://twitter.com/jeckman/">@jeckman</a>) if you’ll be there as well.<br>

<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/wordcamp-for-publishers/">Supporting the first WordCamp for Publishers</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/wordcamp-for-publishers/" title="Supporting the first WordCamp for Publishers"><time datetime="2017-08-14T14:00:41-04:00">August 14, 2017</time></a>

<time datetime="2013-12-14T00:00">
<span class="mo">Aug</span>
17</time>

<p class="event-title">WordCamp for Publishers</p>

<p class="location">Denver, Colorado</p>

<div class="meta">
<span class="speaking">Speaking</span>
<span class="sponsoring">Sponsoring</span>
</div>
</div>

<p>The first WordCamp curated for publishers begins Thursday in Denver, and features sessions&nbsp;for engineering, product, and editorial teams at news rooms big and small.</p>

Combined with our committed support for open platforms like WordPress, we’re proud&nbsp;<strong><a href="https://2017-denver.journalist.wordcamp.org/sponsors/">Gold Sponsors</a> of&nbsp;WordCamp for Publishers</strong>, the highest tier publicly offered.</p>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-18630 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-around-the-web engineering-challenges-caching">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/engineering-challenges-caching/">Engineering challenges: Caching under high&nbsp;load</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/ivan-kruchkoff/" title="Posts by Ivan Kruchkoff" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Ivan-Kruckkoff-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/04/Ivan-Kruckkoff-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Ivan Kruchkoff</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/engineering-challenges-caching/" title="Engineering challenges: Caching under high load"><time datetime="2017-07-25T12:32:23-04:00">July 25, 2017</time></a>
</p>
<p>What’s wrong with this piece of code?</p>
<pre class="brush: php; title: ; notranslate" title="">function get_foo() {
$cache_key = 'fookey';

$data = wp_cache_get( $cache_key );
if ( false === $data ) {
sleep( 10 );
$data = 'foodata';
wp_cache_add( $cache_key, $data, '', HOUR_IN_SECONDS );
}

return $data;
}
</pre>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/engineering-challenges-caching/#more-18630" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Engineering challenges: Caching under high&nbsp;load</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-18771 type-post status-publish format-event hentry category-uncategorized post_format-post-format-event sponsoring-wordcamp-dc">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/sponsoring-wordcamp-dc/">Sponsoring WordCamp&nbsp;DC</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-taylor-lovett" title="Posts by Taylor Lovett" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TLovett-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/TLovett-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Lovett</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/sponsoring-wordcamp-dc/" title="Sponsoring WordCamp DC"><time datetime="2017-07-14T12:25:38-04:00">July 14, 2017</time></a>
</p>


<div class="event-meta">

<time datetime="2013-12-14T00:00">
<span class="mo">Jul</span>
14</time>

<p class="event-title">WordCamp&nbsp;DC</p>

<p class="location">Carnegie Library</p>

<div class="meta">
<span class="speaking">Speaking</span>
<span class="sponsoring">Sponsoring</span>
</div>
</div>

<p>As one of the Washington, DC metro area’s local 10uppers, I’m proud to share that 10up is a <a href="https://2017.dc.wordcamp.org/sponsor/10up/">Silver tier sponsor</a> of this weekend’s WordCamp DC.&nbsp; With our diverse client portfolio including government, political, nonprofit, and national news organizations, an event celebrating open platforms and a better web in Washington, DC was a natural fit for our support.</p>
<p>If you’re attending, be sure to catch Lead Engineer Adam Silverstein speaking on Friday afternoon, in his session, <a href="https://2017.dc.wordcamp.org/session/ten-tips-for-securing-your-wordpress-javascript/">Ten tips for securing your WordPress JavaScript</a>. Pick up our postcard on the swag table, and find Adam and me roaming the event: ask us about <a href="https://10up.com/careers/">working at 10up</a>, <a href="https://10up.com/contact/">hiring 10up</a> for your project, and our newest hosted solution, <a href="http://elasticpress.io/">ElasticPress.io</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-18736 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized 10up-acquires-lift-ux">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/10up-acquires-lift-ux/">Operation LiftUp: Welcome Lift UX to&nbsp;10up</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/10up-acquires-lift-ux/" title="Operation LiftUp: Welcome Lift UX to 10up"><time datetime="2017-07-11T12:28:21-04:00">July 11, 2017</time></a>
</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-18738" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/liftup-blog-graphic@2x.jpg" alt="" width="2000" height="936" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2017/07/liftup-blog-graphic@2x.jpg 2000w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/07/liftup-blog-graphic@2x-300x140.jpg 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/07/liftup-blog-graphic@2x-768x359.jpg 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/07/liftup-blog-graphic@2x-800x374.jpg 800w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/07/liftup-blog-graphic@2x-220x103.jpg 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/07/liftup-blog-graphic@2x-160x75.jpg 160w" sizes="(max-width: 2000px) 100vw, 2000px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p>We’re delighted to announce that after nearly one year of discussion and due diligence, <strong>10up has completed an acquisition of <a href="https://liftux.com/10up">Lift UX</a>: a boutique, distributed, Emmy-nominated agency</strong> that specializes in making user experience design driven websites powered by WordPress. The Lift team, including its founding partners, Chris Wallace and Brad Miller, join 10up effective immediately.</p>
<p>Founded as a boutique digital creative shop in 2009, Lift has delivered web projects for clients like Frito-Lay, The Next Web, eBay, GoDaddy, and Disney. Lift earned acclaim when a “second screen” experience built for AMC’s Walking Dead was <a href="http://www.amc.com/shows/the-walking-dead/talk/2013/07/the-walking-dead-the-walking-dead-story-sync-get-emmy-nominations">nominated for an Emmy Award</a> in the interactive program category in 2012. Their work earn a second nomination in 2015 for <a href="http://www.amc.com/shows/mad-men/talk/2015/07/mad-men-receives-11-emmy-nominations-remains-the-most-nominated-basic-cable-drama-of-all-time">Mad Men: The Fan Cut</a>. Among their innovations, Lift built and sold a WordPress themes shop (UpThemes), and started a career center for distributed companies, <a href="http://remotejobs.com/">RemoteJobs.com</a>. They recently launched <a href="http://campusinsiders.com/">CampusInsiders.com</a>, a project spotlighted by Automattic’s <a href="http://wordpress.com/">WordPress.com</a> VIP program; the project earned Lift an invitation to become an official VIP agency partner.</p>
<p>As 10up’s President &amp; Founder, I am elated to welcome this outstanding team, award recognized portfolio, and client roster to the 10up family. This acquisition <strong>accelerates our growth in Experience Design</strong>, adding executive-tier design leadership and enriching our growing portfolio of design stories. It represents a special opportunity for all parties to go further and faster as we partner with clients to make a better web.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/10up-acquires-lift-ux/#more-18736" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Operation LiftUp: Welcome Lift UX to&nbsp;10up</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-18671 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized restricted-site-access-wordpress-multisite">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/restricted-site-access-wordpress-multisite/">Restricted Site Access for WordPress optimized for&nbsp;multisite</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-taylor-lovett" title="Posts by Taylor Lovett" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TLovett-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/TLovett-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Lovett</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/restricted-site-access-wordpress-multisite/" title="Restricted Site Access for WordPress optimized for multisite"><time datetime="2017-06-16T12:00:52-04:00">June 16, 2017</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/restricted-site-access-wordpress-multisite/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<p>We’ve released a major update to <a href="https://10up.com/plugins/restricted-site-access-wordpress/">Restricted Site Access</a>, our popular WordPress plugin that intelligently limits website access. Designed to keep unwanted visitors out of staging, test, and private sites, the plugin is active on more than 20,000 websites and has a 5 star rating.</p>
<p>Restricted Site Access 6.0 adds full support for <a href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Create_A_Network">WordPress network (multisite) installations</a>. Network administrators can enforce restriction rules across the entire network, or set default restriction rules that are applied as new sites are added. If you have a network of private blogs or internal sites, or need time to configure new sites in your network before taking them live, this is the update you’ve been waiting for.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-18673" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/rsa-6-settings-e1497580625698.jpg" alt="" width="1601" height="679" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/restricted-site-access-wordpress-multisite/#more-18671" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Restricted Site Access for WordPress optimized for&nbsp;multisite</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-18637 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-projects estimates">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/estimates/">Estimates and estimation</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-thorsten-ott" title="Posts by Thorsten Ott" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TOtt-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/TOtt-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Thorsten Ott</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/estimates/" title="Estimates and estimation"><time datetime="2017-06-08T12:00:41-04:00">June 8, 2017</time></a>
</p>
<blockquote><p>“In preparing for battle I have always found that plans are useless, but planning is indispensable.”<br>
–<strong>Dwight D. Eisenhower</strong></p></blockquote>
<h2>Why we estimate</h2>
<blockquote><p>Suppose you’re preparing for a trip and deciding which suitcase to take. You have a small suitcase that you like because it’s easy to carry and will fit into an airplane’s overhead storage bin. You also have a large suitcase, which you don’t like because you’ll have to check it in and then wait for it at baggage claim, lengthening your trip. You lay your clothes beside the small suitcase, and it appears that they will almost fit. What do you do? You might try packing them very carefully, not wasting any space, and hoping they all fit. If that approach doesn’t work, you might try stuffing them into the suitcase with brute force, sitting on the top and trying to squeeze the latches closed. If that still doesn’t work, you’re faced with a choice: leave a few clothes at home or take the larger suitcase. —<strong>Steve McConnell, <em>Software Estimation: Demystifying the Black Art</em></strong></p></blockquote>
<p>As an engineer, nothing pleases me more than rolling up my sleeves and writing code. But before doing that, a sense of how to approach a task and the required resources (people, time, software licenses, third-party API access) need to be determined. These details support clear project expectations, which are foundational to the great client experiences we strive to create. Estimates, give all project stakeholders—internal and external—a chance to agree on a few key things before work is begun:</p>
<ul>
<li>That we understand what is being asked for;</li>
<li>That we have a plan to efficiently deliver quality results;</li>
<li>That we’ve asked (and answered) all project team questions;</li>
<li>That we’ve considered all the risks, edge cases, and alternatives;</li>
<li>That we’ve considered the effects on usability, accessibility, and SEO;</li>
<li>That the available budget and desired timeline support the approach.</li>
</ul>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/estimates/#more-18637" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Estimates and estimation</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-18614 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-projects new-relic-wordpress">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/new-relic-wordpress/">Get to know New Relic Reporting for&nbsp;WordPress</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-vasken-hauri" title="Posts by Vasken Hauri" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/VHauri-600x600-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2016/11/VHauri-600x600-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Vasken Hauri</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/new-relic-wordpress/" title="Get to know New Relic Reporting for WordPress"><time datetime="2017-05-31T12:04:24-04:00">May 31, 2017</time></a>
</p>
<p><a href="https://newrelic.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">New Relic</a> is a SaaS product that offers application performance monitoring (APM), which provides developers with real-time data for use in proactive diagnostics as well as debugging. This data—including basic information about <a href="https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/agents/php-agent/frameworks-libraries/wordpress-specific-functionality" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">WordPress hooks, plugins, and themes</a>—can be queried and visualized using the <a href="https://newrelic.com/insights/features" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">New Relic Insights</a> dashboard.</p>
<p>Seeing an opportunity to maximize the utility of APM and Insights, we created <a href="https://wordpress.org/plugins/wp-newrelic/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">New Relic Reporting for WordPress</a>, which supplements out-of-the-box data collection with additional WordPress-specific information.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/new-relic-wordpress/#more-18614" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Get to know New Relic Reporting for&nbsp;WordPress</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-18589 type-post status-publish format-aside hentry category-appearances post_format-post-format-aside syntaxcon">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/syntaxcon/" title="10up at SyntaxCon"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a54756b4e907df4d47a780bfc76c5a36?s=256&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a54756b4e907df4d47a780bfc76c5a36?s=512&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-256 photo" height="256" width="256" loading="lazy" decoding="async" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/christinegarrison/" title="Posts by Christine Garrison" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"> Christine Garrison</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/syntaxcon/" title="10up at SyntaxCon"><time datetime="2017-05-12T08:49:15-04:00">May 12, 2017</time></a>
</p>
<div class="body-copy">
<p>I’m excited to be presenting “<a href="https://2017.syntaxcon.com/session/test-driven-javascript-development/" target="_blank">An Introduction to Test-Driven JavaScript Development</a>” at <a href="https://2017.syntaxcon.com/" target="_blank">Syntax Code and Craft Conference</a> on May 18. SyntaxCon, held in Charleston, SC, is a multi-day, full stack code conference for developers and engineers. My talk introduces the concept of test-driven development (TDD) when working with JavaScript, highlights its benefits, clarifies some common misconceptions, and provides examples of how to implement TDD into your everyday workflow.</p>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-18568 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-projects wp-docker">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/wp-docker/">Introducing WP&nbsp;Docker</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-taylor-lovett" title="Posts by Taylor Lovett" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TLovett-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/TLovett-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Lovett</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/wp-docker/" title="Introducing WP Docker"><time datetime="2017-04-27T13:11:59-04:00">April 27, 2017</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/wp-docker/#comments" class="comments-count">12 Comments</a>
</p>
<p>Back in 2013, 10up introduced Varying Vagrant Vagrants (VVV), a <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/varying-vagrant-vagrants-future/" target="_blank">project led by then 10upper Jeremy Felt</a>. One of the first popular WordPress development environments based on Vagrant, VVV has since been moved out of 10up’s GitHub and into its <a href="https://github.com/Varying-Vagrant-Vagrants/VVV" target="_blank">own</a>, where it continues to thrive as a community-led project.</p>
<p>Now, <a href="https://www.docker.com/" target="_blank">Docker</a> and container-based server architectures have emerged as powerful tools for creating and managing development environments. Last year, we partnered with Joyent to release a <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2016/joyent-wordpress-docker/" target="_blank">scalable, production-ready Docker environment for WordPress</a>. Today, we’re proud to release <strong><a href="https://github.com/10up/wp-docker" target="_blank">WP Docker</a>: an open source Docker configuration optimized for local WordPress development.</strong><br>
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/wp-docker/#more-18568" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Introducing WP&nbsp;Docker</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-18559 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-around-the-web how-to-wordpress-contributor">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/how-to-wordpress-contributor/">How to become a WordPress Core contributor with one line of&nbsp;code</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/derrickkoo/" title="Posts by Derrick Koo" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/de115b7695c907ea8c0435edf2d0e4f1?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/de115b7695c907ea8c0435edf2d0e4f1?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Derrick Koo</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/how-to-wordpress-contributor/" title="How to become a WordPress Core contributor with one line of code"><time datetime="2017-04-27T08:47:00-04:00">April 27, 2017</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/how-to-wordpress-contributor/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<blockquote><p>[To better illustrate our core value of community service, we are sharing an internal post from Senior Front End Engineer Derrick Koo, who recently made his first code contribution to the WordPress project. We hope his story encourages more people who are “on the fence” about contributing to take the plunge and start giving back to the WordPress community. —Jake Goldman, President &amp; Founder]</p></blockquote>
<p>Contributing code to WordPress Core can be intimidating for a first-timer. With <a href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/tickets/no-patch" target="_blank">thousands of tickets</a> out there, it can be hard to know where to begin. With development out in the open, it takes a lot of courage to submit a first WordPress patch.</p>
<p>For the benefit of new and aspiring contributors, I’m sharing my experience making my first code contribution to WordPress. Starting with little knowledge of the Core contribution process, I embarked on a journey that resulted in <a href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/38872#comment:10" target="_blank">one line of CSS, and my first Core props</a>.<br>
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/how-to-wordpress-contributor/#more-18559" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on How to become a WordPress Core contributor with one line of&nbsp;code</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-18477 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-around-the-web wp-options-table">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/wp-options-table/">Keeping your WordPress options table in&nbsp;check</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/" title="Posts by " rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo avatar-default" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> </a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/wp-options-table/" title="Keeping your WordPress options table in check"><time datetime="2017-03-10T12:01:16-05:00">March 10, 2017</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/wp-options-table/#comments" class="comments-count">7 Comments</a>
</p>
<p>When troubleshooting a slow WordPress site, an often overlooked culprit is the wp_options database table. This table houses a variety of crucial site data, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>permalinks</li>
<li>site settings</li>
<li>scheduled posts</li>
<li>widget data</li>
</ul>
<p>In fact, nearly every WordPress page—from the front end to the admin screens—executes the query <code class="language-php">SELECT option_name, option_value FROM wp_options WHERE autoload = 'yes'</code>. If this query does not run efficiently, <strong>the results can be devastating to a site’s speed</strong>.<br>
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/wp-options-table/#more-18477" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Keeping your WordPress options table in&nbsp;check</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-18462 type-post status-publish format-aside hentry category-appearances post_format-post-format-aside day-of-rest-boston">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/day-of-rest-boston/" title="Join 10up at A Day of REST Boston"><img alt="John Eckman" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/jeckman-256x256.png" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2019/11/jeckman-512x512.png 2x" class="avatar avatar-256 photo" height="256" width="256" loading="lazy" decoding="async" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-john-eckman" title="Posts by John Eckman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"> John Eckman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/day-of-rest-boston/" title="Join 10up at A Day of REST Boston"><time datetime="2017-03-02T13:51:11-05:00">March 2, 2017</time></a>
</p>
<div class="body-copy">
<p>On March 9th, join me at <a href="https://adayofrest.hm/boston-2017/" target="_blank">A Day of REST Boston</a>: a conference devoted to exploring the WordPress REST API in-depth. My lightning talk, <a href="https://adayofrest.hm/boston-2017/speakers/274/" target="_blank">5-10 Use Cases in 10 Minutes</a>, describes various ways organizations are using the REST API in their digital projects.</p>
<p>In <a href="https://adayofrest.hm/boston-2017/speakers/360/" target="_blank">Backbone &amp; the REST API: A Love Story</a>, Lead Web Engineer Adam Silverstein explains how Backbone is used in WordPress core and walks through the core <a href="https://github.com/WP-API/client-js" target="_blank">REST API JavaScript client</a>, started and led by 10up. As a follow-up to this session, on March 10th, Adam is leading a half day workshop on <a href="https://adayofrest.hm/boston-2017/page/workshop-developing-with-backbone-and-the-rest-api/" target="_blank">developing with Backbone and the REST API</a>.</p>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-18442 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized six-year-anniversary">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/six-year-anniversary/">Six years of&nbsp;10up</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/six-year-anniversary/" title="Six years of 10up"><time datetime="2017-02-13T15:09:45-05:00">February 13, 2017</time></a>
</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/10upis6.gif" alt="" width="1000" height="468" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-18444" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"><br>
If we spent our first five years pioneering and staking our claim in the world, in our sixth year we cultivated the organization and culture we pioneered. We rallied around trends and shifts in our industry and redoubled our investment into telling our story.</p>
<p>The initiative to better express our story culminated in a <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2016/refined-message-website-design/" target="_blank">refresh of our company website</a>, prominently featuring a new mission statement, proudly summarized by a promise to deliver “finely crafted websites and tools that make the web better.” We reinvigorated our <a href="https://10up.com/our-work/" target="_blank">project case studies</a>, moving to a layout that better celebrates the challenges we’ve conquered with our clients. And we completely overhauled our <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/careers-2017/" target="_blank">Careers section</a>, taking deliberate strides to better represent our culture of diversity and inclusion.</p>
<p>All this while growing our revenue by 12%.</p>
<p>Here are some of the ways we adapted to a shifting landscape and embodied our new mission since our <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2016/5-year-anniversary/" target="_blank">last company anniversary</a>:<br>
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/six-year-anniversary/#more-18442" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Six years of&nbsp;10up</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-18432 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-projects elasticpress-hosted-search">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/elasticpress-hosted-search/">Meet ElasticPress.io: a hosted search and query engine for ElasticPress</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/elasticpress-hosted-search/" title="Meet ElasticPress.io: a hosted search and query engine for ElasticPress"><time datetime="2017-02-10T11:59:36-05:00">February 10, 2017</time></a>
</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Elasticpress_io3.png" alt="" width="1000" height="265" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-18434" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2017/02/Elasticpress_io3.png 1000w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/02/Elasticpress_io3-300x80.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/02/Elasticpress_io3-768x204.png 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/02/Elasticpress_io3-800x212.png 800w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/02/Elasticpress_io3-220x58.png 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/02/Elasticpress_io3-160x42.png 160w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p><strong>We’re proud to announce <a href="https://elasticpress.io/" target="_blank">ElasticPress.io</a>: a hosted service that integrates with <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2016/elasticpress-2-0/" target="_blank">ElasticPress</a>, our popular plugin, to provide a fast and flexible search and query engine for WordPress. </strong></p>
<p>We built ElasticPress to overcome higher-end performance and functional limits posed by the more traditional, structured (SQL) database underpinning WordPress. Storing content in a modern (noSQL) query engine like Elasticsearch empowers us to produce superior keyword search and related content results, and supercharge the performance of complex queries like a filter on multiple product properties or a location. Smarter and faster content makes for a better web and, not accidentally, is important to search engines and visitor retention / conversion. </p>
<p>While our plugin made it simple for WordPress-savvy engineers to talk to Elasticsearch, the need to manage Elasticsearch hosting added friction and complexity, at odds with the simple user experience 10up strives for. As we prototyped exciting use cases involving private content, we realized that end-to-end security added even more complexity. </p>
<p><strong>ElasticPress.io solves all of that</strong>—making it dead-simple to start using enterprise-caliber search and query technology with WordPress. It enables innovative features like accelerated admin performance that require end-to-end control and security.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/elasticpress-hosted-search/#more-18432" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Meet ElasticPress.io: a hosted search and query engine for ElasticPress</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-18414 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-around-the-web tag-development tag-open-source tag-wordpress wordpress-component-library">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/wordpress-component-library/">Introducing the WordPress Component Library</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/jonbellah/" title="Posts by Jon Bellah" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/jonbellah-btw-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/07/jonbellah-btw-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jon Bellah</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/wordpress-component-library/" title="Introducing the WordPress Component Library"><time datetime="2017-02-08T17:04:18-05:00">February 8, 2017</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/wordpress-component-library/#comments" class="comments-count">9 Comments</a>
</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-18427" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Screen-Shot-2017-02-08-at-1.43.49-PM.png" alt="" width="1996" height="990" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2017/02/Screen-Shot-2017-02-08-at-1.43.49-PM.png 1996w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/02/Screen-Shot-2017-02-08-at-1.43.49-PM-300x149.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/02/Screen-Shot-2017-02-08-at-1.43.49-PM-768x381.png 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/02/Screen-Shot-2017-02-08-at-1.43.49-PM-800x397.png 800w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/02/Screen-Shot-2017-02-08-at-1.43.49-PM-220x109.png 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/02/Screen-Shot-2017-02-08-at-1.43.49-PM-160x79.png 160w" sizes="(max-width: 1996px) 100vw, 1996px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p>We’re proud to introduce the <a href="https://10up.github.io/wp-component-library/">WordPress Component Library</a>: a collection of front-end components constructed with WordPress and accessibility at the forefront.</p>
<p>Many of the HTML and CSS components we build&nbsp;for our clients are structurally similar, particularly for prolific features like menus, search forms, posts, and blogrolls. A common starting point offers efficiencies to our clients while simultaneously raising the bar on polish and compliance with standards like accessibility. In evaluating existing libraries, we found&nbsp;that the industry was missing a good, open source project built with WordPress’s often opinionated markup (e.g. menus) and basic layout structure in mind.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/wordpress-component-library/#more-18414" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Introducing the WordPress Component Library</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>

<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/fivethirtyeight-top-story-2016/">10up client FiveThirtyEight publishes top story of&nbsp;2016</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/" title="Posts by " rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo avatar-default" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> </a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2017/fivethirtyeight-top-story-2016/" title="10up client FiveThirtyEight publishes top story of 2016"><time datetime="2017-01-27T13:25:14-05:00">January 27, 2017</time></a>
</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/fte-chartbeat.png" alt="" width="1135" height="651" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-18389" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2017/01/fte-chartbeat.png 1135w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/01/fte-chartbeat-300x172.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/01/fte-chartbeat-768x441.png 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/01/fte-chartbeat-800x459.png 800w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/01/fte-chartbeat-216x124.png 216w, https://10up.com/uploads/2017/01/fte-chartbeat-157x90.png 157w" sizes="(max-width: 1135px) 100vw, 1135px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;">10up client <a href="https://10up.com/our-work/fivethirtyeight/">FiveThirtyEight’s</a> political coverage earned the stats-minded publisher four spots in <a href="http://2016.chartbeat.com/stories">ChartBeat’s top 25 most engaging stories of 2016</a>, including #1 for their <a href="https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/">2016 election forecast</a>. This interactive feature provided predictions in the US presidential race, as well as 34 Senate contests nationwide, leading up to the November&nbsp;elections.</p>
<p>We love seeing clients like FiveThirtyEight topping the charts alongside long-established publishers like BBC, the New York Times, and&nbsp;NPR.</p>
</div>
</article>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-18267 type-post status-publish format-event hentry category-appearances post_format-post-format-event remote-working-conference">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2016/remote-working-conference/">Speaking at Remote Working Conference 2016</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/taylor/" title="Posts by Taylor Dewey" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TDewey-600x600-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2016/11/TDewey-600x600-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Dewey</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2016/remote-working-conference/" title="Speaking at Remote Working Conference 2016"><time datetime="2016-12-05T15:43:53-05:00">December 5, 2016</time></a>
</p>


<div class="event-meta">

<time datetime="2013-12-14T00:00">
<span class="mo">Dec</span>
6</time>

<p class="event-title">Remote Working Conference</p>


<div class="meta">
<span class="speaking">Speaking</span>
</div>
</div>

<p>Join team 10up (from wherever you are) on Dec 6 and 7 for the <a href="http://remoteworkingconf.com/" target="_blank">2016 Remote Working Conference</a>. This two-day <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hYJHu1Y4AmM" target="_blank">streaming</a> event focuses on how to succeed in a remote working environment and will dispel the myths around distributed teams.</p>
<p>On Day 1, <a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-john-eckman" target="_blank">John Eckman</a> will present “Distributed, not Disconnected: Employee Engagement for Remote Work.” Remote teams carry the stigma of being less connected than their co-located counterparts. John will share techniques and tools to drive engagement in a distributed workplace.</p>
<p>On Day 2, I close the event with my talk “Designing a Better UX Hiring Process.” Vetting UX applicants can be a challenge for remote agencies. Video interviews and online portfolios help, but cannot be the only metrics used to find the best UX design talent. In this talk, I’ll share our strategy for attracting and hiring top UX candidates.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-18220 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-projects wamu-react-rest-api">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2016/wamu-react-rest-api/">WAMU.org launches, powered by React.js and the WordPress REST&nbsp;API</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-phil-crumm" title="Posts by Phil Crumm" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/philcrumm-600x600-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2016/12/philcrumm-600x600-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Phil Crumm</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2016/wamu-react-rest-api/" title="WAMU.org launches, powered by React.js and the WordPress REST API"><time datetime="2016-12-02T18:25:49-05:00">December 2, 2016</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2016/wamu-react-rest-api/#comments" class="comments-count">3 Comments</a>
</p>
<p>Yesterday, Washington, D.C. NPR regional affiliate WAMU released a <a href="https://wamu.org/" target="_blank">fully reimagined website</a> in partnership with 10up. Designed to elegantly present written and audio content, we engineered a cutting-edge WordPress implementation that leverages React.js and the WordPress REST API to create an immersive single-page app experience. Visitors can listen to audio content using the player bar pinned to the bottom of the screen, without interruption, as they browse the site on a phone, tablet, or desktop browser.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/wamu.gif" alt="wamu" width="800" height="493" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-18252" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2016/wamu-react-rest-api/#more-18220" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on WAMU.org launches, powered by React.js and the WordPress REST&nbsp;API</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
