<article class="blog-archive-post post-16628 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-around-the-web wordpress-performance-cdn-http2">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2016/wordpress-performance-cdn-http2/">The future of WordPress performance: CDNs, HTTP/2, and&nbsp;more</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-vasken-hauri" title="Posts by Vasken Hauri" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/VHauri-600x600-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2016/11/VHauri-600x600-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Vasken Hauri</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2016/wordpress-performance-cdn-http2/" title="The future of WordPress performance: CDNs, HTTP/2, and more"><time datetime="2016-01-05T15:51:26-05:00">January 5, 2016</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2016/wordpress-performance-cdn-http2/#comments" class="comments-count">5 Comments</a>
</p>
<p>It’s&nbsp;an exciting time in the WordPress community, with the release&nbsp;of <a href="https://developer.wordpress.com/calypso/" target="_blank">Calypso</a>, a successful inaugural <a href="https://2015.us.wordcamp.org/" target="_blank">WordCamp US</a>, and <a href="https://2015.us.wordcamp.org/2015/12/07/state-of-the-word-2015/" target="_blank">WordPress now powering 25% of all websites</a>. Maturation of the <a href="http://v2.wp-api.org/">WordPress REST&nbsp;API</a> is enabling&nbsp;the decoupling of the content management layer from the&nbsp;display layer, which has the&nbsp;potential to further drive adoption; larger teams can write independent code that communicates via the API, reducing blockers and accelerating&nbsp;feature releases. At the same time, the entire Web is poised to undergo a metamorphosis, as HTTP/2 begins to fundamentally change how content is delivered.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignright size-medium wp-image-16830" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/banner-300x97.jpg" alt="WP REST API" width="300" height="97" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/banner-300x97.jpg 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/banner-768x249.jpg 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/banner-756x245.jpg 756w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/banner-220x71.jpg 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/banner-160x52.jpg 160w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/banner.jpg 1544w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px">While these developments offer tremendous potential for those of us&nbsp;who work with WordPress for a living, I think there are some important considerations to keep in mind as WordPress and the Web move into a new era&nbsp;of maturity and possibility.</p>
<p><b>Using a CDN with DDoS protection is increasingly&nbsp;important</b></p>
<p>We recently started testing a <a href="http://www.webopedia.com/TERM/C/CDN.html">CDN</a> service that offers <a href="http://www.webopedia.com/TERM/D/DDoS_attack.html">DDoS</a> protection and mitigation for&nbsp;this site. While we hardly consider ourselves a high-profile target, the number of attacks reported by service is astonishing (more than a dozen every&nbsp;day, sometimes double or triple that). The majority are attempts to exploit known vulnerabilities in WordPress plugins (or other common web applications), such as those listed in the <a href="https://wpvulndb.com/">WP Vulnerability Database</a>. Exploit mitigation (or at least, notification) at the&nbsp;CDN layer provider is compelling.</p>
<p>In addition to protection from&nbsp;known vulnerabilities, CDNs are vital to accommodating significant burst traffic, and eliminate the effort involved in&nbsp;hosting sites in multiple datacenter across the world. Instead of scaling your servers to manage&nbsp;exponential traffic as a story goes viral or an online catalog gets slammed on Cyber Monday, the work is offloaded to the CDN and its network of edge servers.</p>
<p>Of course, a CDN might not speed up your site–in fact, it can&nbsp;do <a href="https://thethemefoundry.com/blog/why-we-dont-use-a-cdn-spdy-ssl/">just the opposite</a> if you start serving up your site over&nbsp;HTTP/2 and you’re using “best practices” for optimizing your site for HTTP1.1.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2016/wordpress-performance-cdn-http2/#more-16628" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on The future of WordPress performance: CDNs, HTTP/2, and&nbsp;more</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-16689 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-projects web-to-print-open-source">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/web-to-print-open-source/">Eight Day Week: a digital-first web-to-print workflow plugin by Observer &amp;&nbsp;10up</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/joshlevinson/" title="Posts by Josh Levinson" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Josh-Levinson-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/05/Josh-Levinson-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Josh Levinson</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/web-to-print-open-source/" title="Eight Day Week: a digital-first web-to-print workflow plugin by Observer &amp; 10up"><time datetime="2015-12-28T13:24:59-05:00">December 28, 2015</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/web-to-print-open-source/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone wp-image-16691 size-full" title="Integrated digital and print workflow" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/people-coffee-tea-meeting-e1451336637187.jpg" alt="" width="1296" height="604" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/people-coffee-tea-meeting-e1451336637187.jpg 1296w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/people-coffee-tea-meeting-e1451336637187-300x140.jpg 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/people-coffee-tea-meeting-e1451336637187-768x358.jpg 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/people-coffee-tea-meeting-e1451336637187-756x352.jpg 756w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/people-coffee-tea-meeting-e1451336637187-220x103.jpg 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/people-coffee-tea-meeting-e1451336637187-160x75.jpg 160w" sizes="(max-width: 1296px) 100vw, 1296px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p>The web publishing experience is at the heart of 10up’s&nbsp;mission. So needless to say, when&nbsp;<a href="http://observer.com/" target="_blank">Observer</a> (a long-time client) offered the opportunity to reimagine their editorial process, <strong>merging content management across their digital property and hallmark print publication</strong>,&nbsp;New York Observer, they couldn’t hold us back.</p>
<p>The existing process was relatively simple, but introduced several pain points and some potential for inaccuracy. Content was first authored in a word processor; it then moved through several teams and systems: from fact checkers to InDesign and InCopy, then to print, and finally to WordPress for publication on Observer.com. All of this was tracked in a spreadsheet, which involved manually copying and pasting between the word processor, spreadsheet, and WordPress. For a publisher doggedly moving to a “digital first” business model, their process hadn’t&nbsp;exactly caught up with&nbsp;their vision.</p>
<p>The 10up/Observer team came up with a better approach: let’s flip that process on its head and drive the entire process from within WordPress, taking advantage of its content authorship and storage capabilities! In doing so, the burden of duplicating content is removed, and content can be published online much more quickly, without waiting for print publication.</p>
<p><strong>The result? <a href="https://github.com/observermedia/eight-day-week" target="_blank">Eight Day Week</a>–a web to print plugin that helps digital content creators use WordPress to streamline their print production workflow.</strong></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/web-to-print-open-source/#more-16689" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Eight Day Week: a digital-first web-to-print workflow plugin by Observer &amp;&nbsp;10up</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-16622 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-happenings flexibility-flexbox-ie">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/flexibility-flexbox-ie/">Flexibility: Flexbox support for Internet Explorer</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-taylor-lovett" title="Posts by Taylor Lovett" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TLovett-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/TLovett-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Lovett</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/flexibility-flexbox-ie/" title="Flexibility: Flexbox support for Internet Explorer"><time datetime="2015-12-23T12:39:10-05:00">December 23, 2015</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/flexibility-flexbox-ie/#comments" class="comments-count">4 Comments</a>
</p>
<p>A few weeks ago,&nbsp;we pushed out our newest&nbsp;open source project: <a href="https://github.com/10up/flexibility">Flexibility</a>, a polyfill that back ports Flexbox support to Internet Explorer versions 8 and 9.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-16678" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Screen-Shot-2015-12-23-at-9.32.26-AM.png" alt="Flexibility" width="1006" height="247" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/Screen-Shot-2015-12-23-at-9.32.26-AM.png 1006w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/Screen-Shot-2015-12-23-at-9.32.26-AM-300x74.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/Screen-Shot-2015-12-23-at-9.32.26-AM-768x189.png 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/Screen-Shot-2015-12-23-at-9.32.26-AM-756x186.png 756w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/Screen-Shot-2015-12-23-at-9.32.26-AM-220x54.png 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/Screen-Shot-2015-12-23-at-9.32.26-AM-160x39.png 160w" sizes="(max-width: 1006px) 100vw, 1006px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p>Flexbox is one of the most significant advances in&nbsp;front end website layout since the advent of CSS, empowering us&nbsp;to build beautifully responsive and <em>flexible</em> layouts using pure, clean CSS.&nbsp;Here’s&nbsp;a short explanation from a <a href="https://css-tricks.com/snippets/css/a-guide-to-flexbox/">great&nbsp;overview prepared by&nbsp;CSS-Tricks</a>:</p>
<blockquote><p>The main idea behind the flex layout is to give the container the ability to alter its items’ width/height (and order) to best fill the available space (mostly to accommodate to all kind of display devices and screen sizes). A flex container expands items to fill available free space, or shrinks them to prevent overflow.</p></blockquote>
<p>Unfortunately, Flexbox support wasn’t added to&nbsp;Internet Explorer until version 10, leaving older versions –&nbsp;still popular in some corners –&nbsp;out of the Flexbox revolution.&nbsp;This idea didn’t sit well with 10up’er Jonathan Neal,&nbsp;tasked with engineering a beautiful layout for a Fortune 50 forced to contend with supporting older versions. We decided to subsidize his time to see if we could&nbsp;introduce Flexbox support under&nbsp;less-than-ideal browser requirements. The result was Flexibility: a smooth front end experience for older browsers, without compromising our ability to use pioneering layout technology.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/flexibility-flexbox-ie/#more-16622" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Flexibility: Flexbox support for Internet Explorer</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-16590 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-happenings category-projects tag-elasticpress reflections-on-elasticpress">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/reflections-on-elasticpress/">Reflections on ElasticPress</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-taylor-lovett" title="Posts by Taylor Lovett" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TLovett-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/TLovett-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Lovett</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/reflections-on-elasticpress/" title="Reflections on ElasticPress"><time datetime="2015-12-11T12:17:08-05:00">December 11, 2015</time></a>
</p>
<p>With 2015 coming to a close, I’ve been reflecting on the <a href="https://wordpress.org/plugins/elasticpress/">ElasticPress</a> project’s accomplishments since its inception one and a half years ago.</p>
<p>Today, <strong>we <a href="https://github.com/10up/ElasticPress/releases/tag/1.7">released&nbsp;ElasticPress 1.7</a></strong>, which completely restructures post meta storage. This&nbsp;enables&nbsp;performant post meta queries with complex comparisons against data <em>types</em>, such as integers, dates, and times. We also fixed some&nbsp;bugs.</p>
<p>Like many of our popular open source projects,&nbsp;ElasticPress was originally conceived as an <em>internal</em> tool designed to support some specific client needs. Since open sourcing the project, ElasticPress has garnered over <strong>30 contributors</strong> (most of whom do not work at 10up), <strong>16 major releases</strong>, and a <strong>thriving Github community</strong>&nbsp;where developers and site owners are collaborating. ElasticPress is used by major hosting companies and across&nbsp;hundreds of websites, some of which serve millions of pages each&nbsp;month. I have introduced developers to ElasticPress at speaking engagements&nbsp;around the world.</p>
<p><a href="https://github.com/10up/elasticpress"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-16599 size-full" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/elastic_press.png" alt="elastic_press" width="999" height="247" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/elastic_press.png 999w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/elastic_press-300x74.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/elastic_press-768x190.png 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/elastic_press-756x187.png 756w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/elastic_press-220x54.png 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/12/elastic_press-160x40.png 160w" sizes="(max-width: 999px) 100vw, 999px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a></p>
<p>We’ve also learned our fair share of lessons&nbsp;since initiating&nbsp;the&nbsp;project. Here are a few that stand out.<br>
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/reflections-on-elasticpress/#more-16590" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Reflections on ElasticPress</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-16524 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-uncategorized button-and-link-usability">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/button-and-link-usability/">Button and link usability</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/taylor/" title="Posts by Taylor Dewey" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TDewey-600x600-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2016/11/TDewey-600x600-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Dewey</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/button-and-link-usability/" title="Button and link usability"><time datetime="2015-12-02T13:46:25-05:00">December 2, 2015</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/button-and-link-usability/#comments" class="comments-count">3 Comments</a>
</p>
<p>I find myself often telling designers and front-end engineers that “buttons should feel like buttons and links should look like links.” It occurs to me, that after a few years of the flat design trend, I should explain what that means.</p>
<h2>Buttons should feel like buttons</h2>
<p>When you press a physical button in the real world — any key on a physical keyboard, for example — you can tactically feel it depressing. You’ll also see its form shrink away from you and the way the light falls on it will cause it to look slightly different.<br>
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/button-and-link-usability/#more-16524" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Button and link usability</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-16541 type-post status-publish format-event hentry category-appearances post_format-post-format-event the-first-wordcamp-us">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/the-first-wordcamp-us/">The First WordCamp&nbsp;US</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-thorsten-ott" title="Posts by Thorsten Ott" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TOtt-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/TOtt-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Thorsten Ott</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/the-first-wordcamp-us/" title="The First WordCamp US"><time datetime="2015-12-01T13:42:17-05:00">December 1, 2015</time></a>
</p>


<div class="event-meta">

<time datetime="2013-12-14T00:00">
<span class="mo">Dec</span>
4</time>

<p class="event-title">WordCamp&nbsp;US</p>

<p class="location">Philadelphia, Pennsylvania</p>

<div class="meta">
<span class="attending">Attending</span>
<span class="speaking">Speaking</span>
</div>
</div>

<p>In 2006, the first <a href="https://sf.wordcamp.org/2006/" target="_blank">WordCamp</a> was held in San Francisco–followed by subsequent camps in cities around the country. This weekend, the first <a href="https://2015.us.wordcamp.org/" target="_blank">WordCamp US</a> will take place: an expansion of the traditional San Francisco conference, now attracting the WordPress community on an even larger scale.</p>
<p>Our team regularly contributes to open source projects and community initiatives, and I am thrilled to be one of seven co-organizers of the inaugural WordCamp US. Hosted in Philadelphia, PA on December 4-6, the conference is a jam packed 3-day event: kicking off with a yoga session right after registration, and moving through the weekend with more than 80 speakers and sessions, including 15-minute “Lightning Talks.” Matt Mullenweg will also present the annual “State of the Word” address: a summary on the current and future outlook of the WordPress project and community. The conference will conclude with Contributor Day: an event for novice and seasoned contributors to give back to the WordPress project, co-organized by colleague and Web Engineer, Drew Jaynes.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/the-first-wordcamp-us/#more-16541" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on The First WordCamp&nbsp;US</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-16500 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-around-the-web storycorps-google-homepage">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/storycorps-google-homepage/">Client’s “Great Thanksgiving Listen” Campaign Featured on Google Homepage</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/davidperalty/" title="Posts by David Peralty" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/2056ec3b78ef7dd31bf3e8659e219a56?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/2056ec3b78ef7dd31bf3e8659e219a56?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> David Peralty</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/storycorps-google-homepage/" title="Client’s “Great Thanksgiving Listen” Campaign Featured on Google Homepage"><time datetime="2015-11-23T18:10:59-05:00">November 23, 2015</time></a>
</p>
<p><a href="./Blog _ 10up_files/Screen-Shot-2015-11-23-at-12.40.56-PM-e1448319829121.png"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-16502" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Screen-Shot-2015-11-23-at-12.40.56-PM-e1448319829121.png" alt="StoryCorps" width="1397" height="625" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/11/Screen-Shot-2015-11-23-at-12.40.56-PM-e1448319829121.png 1397w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/11/Screen-Shot-2015-11-23-at-12.40.56-PM-e1448319829121-300x134.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/11/Screen-Shot-2015-11-23-at-12.40.56-PM-e1448319829121-768x344.png 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/11/Screen-Shot-2015-11-23-at-12.40.56-PM-e1448319829121-756x338.png 756w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/11/Screen-Shot-2015-11-23-at-12.40.56-PM-e1448319829121-220x98.png 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/11/Screen-Shot-2015-11-23-at-12.40.56-PM-e1448319829121-160x72.png 160w" sizes="(max-width: 1397px) 100vw, 1397px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a></p>
<p>We love when our clients are successful, and StoryCorps and their amazing <a href="https://storycorps.me/about/the-great-thanksgiving-listen/" target="_blank">Thanksgiving Listen campaign</a> being featured on Google’s homepage certainly qualifies. The project, powered by the <a href="http://v2.wp-api.org/">WordPress JSON REST API</a>,&nbsp;is hosted on a custom Amazon Web Services stack created by our systems team to accommodate its highly unusual scaling requirements. <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/scaling-storycorps-wordpress-json-api/" target="_blank">Check out our earlier post about StoryCorps</a> and consider using your own Thanksgiving to record your family stories!</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-16403 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-around-the-web shawnee-whitney">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/shawnee-whitney/">From Shawnee, With Love: How A Small Town Inspires Remote&nbsp;Work</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jaimee-ratliff" title="Posts by Jaimee Ratliff" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/jaimee-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/07/jaimee-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jaimee Ratliff</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/shawnee-whitney/" title="From Shawnee, With Love: How A Small Town Inspires Remote Work"><time datetime="2015-11-10T16:47:06-05:00">November 10, 2015</time></a>
</p>
<p><a href="./Blog _ 10up_files/shawnee-whitney.jpg"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-16434" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/shawnee-whitney.jpg" alt="Shawnee article" width="1300" height="838" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/11/shawnee-whitney.jpg 1300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/11/shawnee-whitney-300x193.jpg 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/11/shawnee-whitney-768x495.jpg 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/11/shawnee-whitney-756x487.jpg 756w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/11/shawnee-whitney-192x124.jpg 192w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/11/shawnee-whitney-140x90.jpg 140w" sizes="(max-width: 1300px) 100vw, 1300px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a></p>
<p>Our distributed workforce model empowers 10uppers to work where they love, providing us with the freedom to create from inspiring places and spaces around the world.</p>
<p>Take Whitney Yadrich, a Senior Project Manager &amp; Team Lead over in Shawnee, Kansas where you’ll also find her husband, their two dogs (Lita and Sarge), and the town she fell in love with. Whitney was recently featured in the Fall/Winter issue of <a href="http://issuu.com/sunflower_publishing/docs/sm15fawi_singles">Shawnee’s local magazine</a>, where she and two other young professionals dish on their love for their hometown. &nbsp;Supported by our remote work culture, she credits the city for offering inspiring work spaces where she can&nbsp;change-up her scenery, recharge, and stay focused. Whitney also offers tips for the work-from-home professional, namely: prioritizing a normal work schedule, taking the time to get dressed every morning despite the lack of a mandatory commute, and switching up locations regularly to keep things fresh.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-16349 type-post status-publish format-event hentry category-happenings post_format-post-format-event the-first-wordcamp-sacramento">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/the-first-wordcamp-sacramento/">The First WordCamp Sacramento</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/the-first-wordcamp-sacramento/" title="The First WordCamp Sacramento"><time datetime="2015-11-06T14:36:36-05:00">November 6, 2015</time></a>
</p>


<div class="event-meta">

<time datetime="2013-12-14T00:00">
<span class="mo">Nov</span>
7</time>

<p class="event-title">WordCamp Sacramento</p>

<p class="location">Sacramento, CA</p>

<div class="meta">
<span class="speaking">Speaking</span>
<span class="sponsoring">Sponsoring</span>
</div>
</div>

<p>Rumors&nbsp;of a <a href="https://sacramento.wordcamp.org/2015/">WordCamp Sacramento</a> started in 2012, after&nbsp;I rebooted the WordPress Sacramento Meetup. Fast forward to&nbsp;2015:&nbsp;there are 4 meetup organizers and northern California’s&nbsp;WordCamp San Francisco has been&nbsp;displaced by <a href="https://2015.us.wordcamp.org/">WordCamp US</a>.&nbsp;The Art Institute of Sacramento volunteered its&nbsp;campus for an event,&nbsp;a professor offered&nbsp;himself as lead organizer, and indispensable local leaders&nbsp;stepped up&nbsp;to take an active role.</p>
<p>I’m proud to have played <a href="https://sacramento.wordcamp.org/2015/wordcamp-sacramento-jake-goldman/">a small role in co-organizing</a> the first WordCamp Sacramento,&nbsp;which takes place tomorrow, and even more proud&nbsp;that <a href="https://sacramento.wordcamp.org/2015/sponsors/">10up is sponsoring the event</a>. I’ll be joined at the event by three 10uppers who are speaking: Sacramento’s own Ben Ilfeld, who will be <a href="https://sacramento.wordcamp.org/2015/ben-ilfeld/">teaching site advertising basics</a>, Northern California’s Vasken Hauri, who promises to&nbsp;<a href="https://sacramento.wordcamp.org/2015/vasken-hauri/">improve lives with event-driven caching</a>, and Luke Woodward, joining us from out-of-state&nbsp;to&nbsp;debut <a href="https://sacramento.wordcamp.org/2015/luke-woodward/">“Robots Write the Docs.”</a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-16264 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-appearances wordcamp-nyc">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/wordcamp-nyc/">10up speaks at WordCamp NYC this&nbsp;weekend</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-taylor-lovett" title="Posts by Taylor Lovett" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TLovett-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/TLovett-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Lovett</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/wordcamp-nyc/" title="10up speaks at WordCamp NYC this weekend"><time datetime="2015-10-28T18:23:19-04:00">October 28, 2015</time></a>
</p>
<p><a href="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/10/Screen-Shot-2015-10-28-at-9.43.54-AM.png"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-16270" src="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/10/Screen-Shot-2015-10-28-at-9.43.54-AM-756x165.png" alt="WordCamp NYC" width="800" height="174" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/10/Screen-Shot-2015-10-28-at-9.43.54-AM-756x165.png 756w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/10/Screen-Shot-2015-10-28-at-9.43.54-AM-300x65.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/10/Screen-Shot-2015-10-28-at-9.43.54-AM-768x167.png 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/10/Screen-Shot-2015-10-28-at-9.43.54-AM-220x48.png 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/10/Screen-Shot-2015-10-28-at-9.43.54-AM-160x35.png 160w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/10/Screen-Shot-2015-10-28-at-9.43.54-AM.png 1217w" sizes="(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a></p>
<p>10up is thrilled to sponsor <a href="https://nyc.wordcamp.org/2015/">WordCamp NYC 2015</a> this weekend in Brooklyn. This year, Chief Executive Officer John Eckman and I are presenting, with Director of Platform Experience Helen Hou-Sandi in attendance.</p>
<p>In “Modernizing WordPress Search with Elasticsearch”, I’ll cover the benefits of Elasticsearch and teach attendees how to use <a href="https://wordpress.org/plugins/elasticpress/">ElasticPress</a>: a 10up plugin that integrates WordPress with Elasticsearch, and significantly improves search results, relevancy, ranking, and filtering within WordPress.</p>
<p>John’s presentation, “The Enterprise Disconnect: WordPress and the Complexity of Simplicity”, will cover the challenges of advocating for WordPress in the enterprise, and different perspectives inside and outside the WordPress community. John will propose approaches that preserve the simplicity of WordPress, while better exposing enterprises to powerful solutions which can be built atop the platform.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/wordcamp-nyc/#more-16264" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on 10up speaks at WordCamp NYC this&nbsp;weekend</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-15988 type-post status-publish format-event has-post-thumbnail hentry category-appearances post_format-post-format-event zendcon">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/zendcon/">10up speaking at ZendCon&nbsp;2015</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-taylor-lovett" title="Posts by Taylor Lovett" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TLovett-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/TLovett-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Lovett</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/zendcon/" title="10up speaking at ZendCon 2015"><time datetime="2015-10-19T15:25:26-04:00">October 19, 2015</time></a>
</p>


<div class="event-meta">

<time datetime="2013-12-14T00:00">
<span class="mo">Oct</span>
19</time>

<p class="event-title">ZendCon&nbsp;2015</p>

<p class="location">Las Vegas</p>

<div class="meta">
<span class="speaking">Speaking</span>
</div>
</div>

<p>This year, Lead Web Engineer Eric Mann and I are attending and speaking at <a href="http://www.zendcon.com/">ZendCon</a>, the largest global gathering of the PHP community, on October 19-22, 2015 in Las Vegas. ZendCon brings together industry thought leaders, recognized PHP experts, enterprise PHP adopters, as well as independent developers for four days of professional development and networking.</p>
<p>On October 19, Eric will present his first talk, “Sandboxing your Development Environment with Vagrant”, which covers best practices in developer-side virtualization and some of the options available for runtime system configuration. On Wednesday, he’s talking about WordPress and unit testing in “A Tale of Two Test Suites.” Eric will cover fundamentals like API mocking, and comparing and contrasting the&nbsp;standard WordPress integration test suite with mock-powered unit testing alternatives.</p>
<p>Also on Wednesday, I’ll &nbsp;present “Best Practices for WordPress Enterprise”. I’ll explain how 10up successfully builds highly efficient and scalable WordPress websites for some of the world’s largest companies and organizations. Although I’m&nbsp;focusing on engineering, I’ll also touch on team&nbsp;coordination and workflows.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-15799 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-happenings commitments-open-web">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/commitments-open-web/">Reiterating our commitment to an open&nbsp;web</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/helen/" title="Posts by Helen Hou-Sandi" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Helen Hou-Sandí" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/HHouSandi-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/HHouSandi-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Helen Hou-Sandi</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/commitments-open-web/" title="Reiterating our commitment to an open web"><time datetime="2015-10-05T14:56:17-04:00">October 5, 2015</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/commitments-open-web/#comments" class="comments-count">4 Comments</a>
</p>
<blockquote><p>It’s easy to take open-source software for granted, and to forget that the Internet we use every day depends in part on the freely donated work of thousands of programmers. If open-source software is at the heart of the Internet, then we might need to examine it from time to time to make sure it’s not bleeding.</p>
<p><cite><a href="http://www.newyorker.com/tech/elements/the-internets-telltale-heartbleed">The Internet’s Telltale Heartbleed (The New Yorker)</a></cite></p></blockquote>
<p>I’m proud to be a part of 10up because we are eager to support a platform we use heavily and that powers a significant percentage of the web. <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/giving-back-to-wordpress/">I am sponsored full-time</a> as one of the six lead developers of WordPress, and am very excited to&nbsp;announce further&nbsp;expansion of our support for WordPress. As a fellow committer for WordPress, <a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-drew-jaynes">Drew Jaynes</a> will now also be enabled to work full-time on WordPress. Drew has been instrumental in creating awareness, standards, and output in our developer documentation, as well as contributing in many other areas in the core software and in community projects such as the WordPress.org site itself.</p>
<p>As a part of this expansion, we’ve created a&nbsp;Platform Engineer position and transitioned Drew to his new title. While we’re not currently hiring for the position, we’ve intentionally left the title open-ended as we continue to grow our support for and even build web platforms. We’ve dedicated significant resources to WordPress as well as projects like <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/sponsoring-sanitize-css/">sanitize.css</a> and <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/varying-vagrant-vagrants-future/">VVV</a>, and envision a future in which we continue to do the same elsewhere.</p>
<p>10up also has the rare opportunity to take advantage of a confluence&nbsp;of timing, a core WordPress&nbsp;initiative, and an employee who already runs the effort. We are doing this by donating 100 hours of <a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-scott-clark">Scott Kingsley Clark’s</a> company time to the ongoing <a href="https://make.wordpress.org/core/tag/fields-api/">Fields API project</a>, starting today. Scott has already assembled a strong group of contributors and laid a solid foundation and roadmap, and we feel strongly that supporting this initiative will help move it into a viable state for potential inclusion in a near-future release of WordPress. As a company with a central mission of creating great publishing experiences, the user and developer experiences a fields API can improve are something we are particularly well-versed in.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/commitments-open-web/#more-15799" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Reiterating our commitment to an open&nbsp;web</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-15697 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-uncategorized ios-9-content-blockers-analysis-whitepaper">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/ios-9-content-blockers-analysis-whitepaper/">Blocked: An In-Depth Special Report on iOS 9 Content Blockers</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/benilfeld/" title="Posts by Ben Ilfeld" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/ben-ilfeld-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/12/ben-ilfeld-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Ben Ilfeld</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/ios-9-content-blockers-analysis-whitepaper/" title="Blocked: An In-Depth Special Report on iOS 9 Content Blockers"><time datetime="2015-09-23T13:21:58-04:00">September 23, 2015</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/ios-9-content-blockers-analysis-whitepaper/#comments" class="comments-count">6 Comments</a>
</p>
<p><em>Editor’s Note: </em>This&nbsp;summary and report was co-authored by&nbsp;Lead Audience &amp; Revenue Strategist Ben Ilfeld and President &amp; Founder Jake Goldman.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-15709" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/impact-of-Content-Blocking.jpg" alt="iOS 9 Content Blocking" width="1500" height="620" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/09/impact-of-Content-Blocking.jpg 1500w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/09/impact-of-Content-Blocking-300x124.jpg 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/09/impact-of-Content-Blocking-768x317.jpg 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/09/impact-of-Content-Blocking-756x312.jpg 756w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/09/impact-of-Content-Blocking-220x91.jpg 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/09/impact-of-Content-Blocking-160x66.jpg 160w" sizes="(max-width: 1500px) 100vw, 1500px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p>On September 16, Apple launched iOS 9 with a suite of enhancements. One buried feature has the web content industry talking: content blocking. The immediate and obvious use case being blocking of ads and third-party scripts often used for site metrics. Less than one week in, a $0.99 ad blocker is atop the iOS App Store’s paid app charts, and a $3.99 ad blocker trails right behind it.</p>
<p>Much has been said about the ethical implications and hypothetical impact. Clients who look to 10up for web and online revenue strategies were, naturally, less interested in debating whether content blocking is fair, and more interested in modeling their potential impact and adapting. While we couldn’t help touching on the ethics – an open web is core to 10up’s DNA – we focused on analyzing technical realities, data informed predictions, practical industry implications, and potential strategies publishers can apply&nbsp;to face&nbsp;a changing landscape.</p>
<p>Read on to&nbsp;review&nbsp;highlights from the report, or skip ahead and <strong><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/ios-9-content-blockers-analysis-whitepaper/#report-download">download our free eBook in PDF or ePub format</a></strong>.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/ios-9-content-blockers-analysis-whitepaper/#more-15697" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Blocked: An In-Depth Special Report on iOS 9 Content Blockers</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-15326 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized microcopy-importance">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/microcopy-importance/">Microcopy can make a macro impression</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/taylor/" title="Posts by Taylor Dewey" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TDewey-600x600-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2016/11/TDewey-600x600-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Dewey</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/microcopy-importance/" title="Microcopy can make a macro impression"><time datetime="2015-09-03T12:05:53-04:00">September 3, 2015</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/microcopy-importance/#comments" class="comments-count">3 Comments</a>
</p>
<p>A newly hired UX Designer once quipped, “I could spend all day obsessing about word choices.” It’s true, we could! Those small fragments of text—a phrase, a sentence fragment, or even a word—can make an interface really work. We call it microcopy.</p>
<p>Microcopy sits unobtrusively alongside user interface, ready to provide contextual information for a user that needs that extra bit of help or information. It makes visitors feel confident and can help reinforce a client’s brand through tone and style. Typically you see microcopy near interactive elements. Here are some prototypical examples of microcopy found online:</p>

<style type="text/css">
#gallery-1 {
margin: auto;
}
#gallery-1 .gallery-item {
float: left;
margin-top: 10px;
text-align: center;
width: 50%;
}
#gallery-1 img {
border: 2px solid #cfcfcf;
}
#gallery-1 .gallery-caption {
margin-left: 0;
}
/* see gallery_shortcode() in wp-includes/media.php */
</style>
<div id="gallery-1" class="gallery galleryid-15326 gallery-columns-2 gallery-size-medium"><dl class="gallery-item">
<dt class="gallery-icon landscape">
<a href="./Blog _ 10up_files/googledrive.png"><img width="293" height="81" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/googledrive.png" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="" decoding="async" loading="lazy" aria-describedby="gallery-1-15356" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/googledrive.png 293w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/googledrive-220x61.png 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/googledrive-292x81.png 292w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/googledrive-160x44.png 160w" sizes="(max-width: 293px) 100vw, 293px"></a>
</dt>
<dd class="wp-caption-text gallery-caption" id="gallery-1-15356">
Status Messages: Google drive keeps you informed that your hard work is okay.
</dd></dl><dl class="gallery-item">
<dt class="gallery-icon landscape">
<a href="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/wpadmin-tags-metabox.png"><img width="300" height="179" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/wpadmin-tags-metabox-300x179.png" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="" decoding="async" loading="lazy" aria-describedby="gallery-1-15359" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/wpadmin-tags-metabox-300x179.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/wpadmin-tags-metabox-208x124.png 208w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/wpadmin-tags-metabox-151x90.png 151w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/wpadmin-tags-metabox.png 574w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a>
</dt>
<dd class="wp-caption-text gallery-caption" id="gallery-1-15359">
Form Help: WordPress admin
</dd></dl><br style="clear: both"><dl class="gallery-item">
<dt class="gallery-icon landscape">
<a href="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/hotels.com-search.png"><img width="300" height="89" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/hotels.com-search-300x89.png" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="" decoding="async" loading="lazy" aria-describedby="gallery-1-15362" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/hotels.com-search-300x89.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/hotels.com-search-220x65.png 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/hotels.com-search-160x47.png 160w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/hotels.com-search.png 704w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px"></a>
</dt>
<dd class="wp-caption-text gallery-caption" id="gallery-1-15362">
Forms: Hotels.com lets you know what you can search for.
</dd></dl><dl class="gallery-item">
<dt class="gallery-icon landscape">
<a href="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/bbc.co_.uk-login.png"><img width="300" height="160" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/bbc.co_.uk-login-300x160.png" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="" decoding="async" loading="lazy" aria-describedby="gallery-1-15365" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/bbc.co_.uk-login-300x160.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/bbc.co_.uk-login-220x117.png 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/bbc.co_.uk-login-160x85.png 160w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/bbc.co_.uk-login.png 728w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a>
</dt>
<dd class="wp-caption-text gallery-caption" id="gallery-1-15365">
Expectations: BBC lets potential signups know that it won’t post to your feeds.
</dd></dl><br style="clear: both">
</div>

<blockquote><p>“Microcopy is small yet powerful copy. It’s fast, light, and deadly. It’s a short sentence, a phrase, a few words. A single word… Don’t be deceived by the size of microcopy. It can make or break an interface.”</p>
<p><cite>— Joshua Porter, 2009</cite></p></blockquote>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/microcopy-importance/#more-15326" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Microcopy can make a macro impression</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-15208 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-projects brightcove-wordpress-plugin">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/brightcove-wordpress-plugin/">Marrying Brightcove and&nbsp;WordPress</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jaimee-ratliff" title="Posts by Jaimee Ratliff" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/jaimee-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/07/jaimee-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jaimee Ratliff</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/brightcove-wordpress-plugin/" title="Marrying Brightcove and WordPress"><time datetime="2015-08-18T11:31:01-04:00">August 18, 2015</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/brightcove-wordpress-plugin/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<p>When it comes to providing enterprise-class cloud solutions for video delivery and monetization, <a href="https://www.brightcove.com/en/" target="_blank">Brightcove</a> is the biggest game in town.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-15209 size-large" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Brightcove-10up-Case-Study1-756x425.jpg" alt="Brightcove" width="650" height="365" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/Brightcove-10up-Case-Study1-756x425.jpg 756w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/Brightcove-10up-Case-Study1-300x169.jpg 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/Brightcove-10up-Case-Study1-768x432.jpg 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/Brightcove-10up-Case-Study1-220x124.jpg 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/Brightcove-10up-Case-Study1-1152x648.jpg 1152w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/Brightcove-10up-Case-Study1-576x324.jpg 576w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/Brightcove-10up-Case-Study1-160x90.jpg 160w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/Brightcove-10up-Case-Study1.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 650px) 100vw, 650px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p>10up recently teamed up with Brightcove to create <a href="https://wordpress.org/plugins/brightcove-video-connect/" target="_blank">Brightcove Video Connect</a>: a beautiful WordPress plugin that leverages the new <a href="https://docs.brightcove.com/en/video-cloud/media/references/reference.html" target="_blank">Video Cloud API</a> to power an intuitive experience for content creators designed to look and feel like an organic extension of WordPress. The plugin features the functionality that media publishers value most, such as easy video uploads and playlist management. We even designed the plugin with extensibility in mind, so that major media companies with unique workflows and presentation requirements can customize and extend their experience.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/brightcove-wordpress-plugin/#more-15208" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Marrying Brightcove and&nbsp;WordPress</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-15006 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-around-the-web tag-front-end tag-open-source sponsoring-sanitize-css">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/sponsoring-sanitize-css/">Sponsoring Sanitize.css</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-taylor-lovett" title="Posts by Taylor Lovett" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TLovett-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/TLovett-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Lovett</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/sponsoring-sanitize-css/" title="Sponsoring Sanitize.css"><time datetime="2015-08-13T11:45:46-04:00">August 13, 2015</time></a>
</p>
<p><a href="https://github.com/10up/sanitize.css"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone wp-image-15083 size-large" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/sanitize-756x43.png" alt="sanitize" width="650" height="37" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/07/sanitize-756x43.png 756w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/07/sanitize-300x17.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/07/sanitize-768x43.png 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/07/sanitize-220x12.png 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/07/sanitize-160x9.png 160w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/07/sanitize.png 1007w" sizes="(max-width: 650px) 100vw, 650px"></a></p>
<p>In keeping with our <a href="https://10up.com/giving-back/">commitments and contributions</a> to important open source projects, <strong>we’re proud to take on stewardship of <a href="https://github.com/10up/sanitize.css">sanitize.css</a></strong>. An incredibly popular project by 10up’er Jonathan Neal, sanitize.css makes it easier to engineer website front ends that render consistently across popular browsers.</p>
<p>Elegant in its simplicity and superbly documented, the project already more than meets our <a href="https://10up.github.io/Engineering-Best-Practices/">engineering standards</a>. More importantly, tools like sanitize.css serve&nbsp;10up’s mission to create outstanding, dependable content-centric website experiences from front to back, for our clients, and for a bigger open web.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/sponsoring-sanitize-css/#more-15006" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Sponsoring Sanitize.css</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-15110 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-happenings you-got-your-content-in-my-design">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/you-got-your-content-in-my-design/">You Got Your Content in My Web&nbsp;Design</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-john-eckman" title="Posts by John Eckman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="John Eckman" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/jeckman-64x64.png" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2019/11/jeckman-128x128.png 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> John Eckman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/you-got-your-content-in-my-design/" title="You Got Your Content in My Web Design"><time datetime="2015-08-05T04:38:38-04:00">August 5, 2015</time></a>
</p>
<p><a href="http://www.designcontentconf.com/"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-15133 size-large" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/design-content-conf-756x262.jpg" alt="design-content-conf" width="650" height="225" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/design-content-conf-756x262.jpg 756w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/design-content-conf-300x104.jpg 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/design-content-conf-768x266.jpg 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/design-content-conf-220x76.jpg 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/08/design-content-conf-160x55.jpg 160w" sizes="(max-width: 650px) 100vw, 650px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a></p>
<p>I’m very excited this week for&nbsp;the <a href="http://www.designcontentconf.com/">Design and Content Conference</a> in Vancouver BC. The conference theme is “Designers and Content Strategists: We’re Better Together,” and the speakers list is a who’s-who of the web design and content strategy worlds, including Ethan Marcotte and Karen McGrane, whose <a href="http://abookapart.com/products/content-strategy-for-mobile"><i>Content Strategy for Mobile</i></a> was the first detailed, extended discussion of how design and content come together in a multi-device world.</p>
<p>For me, the most important shifts in the web design and development industry in the last decade have been:</p>
<ul>
<li>The recognition of content strategy as a discipline, and the inclusion of content strategy-driven thinking in web teams. (See Kristina Halvorson’s <a href="http://alistapart.com/article/thedisciplineofcontentstrategy"><i>The Discipline of Content Strategy</i></a> and <a href="http://contentstrategy.com/"><i>Content Strategy for the Web</i></a>)</li>
<li>The acknowledgement of the impact responsive web design has on the design process, activities, and outputs (See Marcotte’s <a href="http://alistapart.com/article/responsive-web-design"><i>Responsive Web Design</i></a> and <a href="http://abookapart.com/products/responsive-web-design"><i>Responsive Web Design</i></a>).</li>
</ul>
<p>As these authors &nbsp;pointed out, neither concept was entirely new. Ethan’s article referenced “<a href="http://alistapart.com/article/dao">A Dao of Web Design</a>” which prescribed “pages which are accessible, regardless of the browser, platform or screen that your reader chooses or must use.”</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/you-got-your-content-in-my-design/#more-15110" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on You Got Your Content in My Web&nbsp;Design</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-14982 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-appearances tag-wceu wordcamp-europe-2015">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/wordcamp-europe-2015/">Catch four 10up speakers at WordCamp Europe</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/drew-jaynes/" title="Posts by Drew Jaynes" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/b0da3360ff3e26e1e137b7144cca7aef?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/b0da3360ff3e26e1e137b7144cca7aef?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Drew Jaynes</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2015/wordcamp-europe-2015/" title="Catch four 10up speakers at WordCamp Europe"><time datetime="2015-06-26T11:43:03-04:00">June 26, 2015</time></a>
</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-14991" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Screen-Shot-2015-06-26-at-8.41.06-AM-756x159.png" alt="WordCamp Europe 2015" width="650" height="136" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2015/06/Screen-Shot-2015-06-26-at-8.41.06-AM-756x159.png 756w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/06/Screen-Shot-2015-06-26-at-8.41.06-AM-300x63.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/06/Screen-Shot-2015-06-26-at-8.41.06-AM-768x162.png 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/06/Screen-Shot-2015-06-26-at-8.41.06-AM-220x46.png 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2015/06/Screen-Shot-2015-06-26-at-8.41.06-AM-160x34.png 160w" sizes="(max-width: 650px) 100vw, 650px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p><a href="https://europe.wordcamp.org/2015/">WordCamp Europe</a> is this weekend, and four 10uppers have made the trek to Seville, Spain to mingle and&nbsp;share insights.</p>
<p>I will be presenting on Friday on the <a href="https://europe.wordcamp.org/2015/session/getting-wordpress-out-of-its-own-way-a-nux-case-study/">experience of setting up WordPress for new users</a>, raising questions about how WordPress&nbsp;can continue to drive adoption by catering to that audience. I’ll also be teaching attendees&nbsp;how to write documentation for the handbooks, inline docs, and examples for the code reference.</p>
<p>Director of Platform Helen Hou-Sandi is presenting&nbsp;<a href="https://europe.wordcamp.org/2015/session/developing-for-capabilities/">Developing for Capabilities</a>, covering approaches for mobile, responsive, and accessible development. Lead Engineer Eric Mann will be giving a short talk on Saturday on how to <a href="https://europe.wordcamp.org/2015/session/short-talks-4/">sandbox a development environment with Vagrant</a>. Finally, Senior Engineer Adam Silverstein will talk about Backbone.js and WordPress, in <a href="https://europe.wordcamp.org/2015/session/backbone/">Putting a little Backbone in your WordPress</a>.</p>
<p>With a packed <a href="https://europe.wordcamp.org/2015/schedule/">schedule</a>&nbsp;and huge attendance, WordCamp Europe looks to live up to its name once again as the premier WordCamp abroad.</p>
</div>
</article>
