<article class="blog-archive-post post-11506 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized developing-for-non-profits-at-givecamp-boston-2014">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/developing-for-non-profits-at-givecamp-boston-2014/">Developing for Non-Profits at GiveCamp Boston&nbsp;2014</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-john-eckman" title="Posts by John Eckman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="John Eckman" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/jeckman-64x64.png" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2019/11/jeckman-128x128.png 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> John Eckman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/developing-for-non-profits-at-givecamp-boston-2014/" title="Developing for Non-Profits at GiveCamp Boston 2014"><time datetime="2014-03-31T11:41:23-04:00">March 31, 2014</time></a>
</p>
<p><a href="http://newenglandgivecamp.org/"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignright size-full wp-image-11507" alt="New England GiveCamp" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/300x196xGiveCampLogo2HorizontalNoDateSmall-300x196.jpg.pagespeed.ic_.lmz0Mhn_No.jpg" width="300" height="196" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/03/300x196xGiveCampLogo2HorizontalNoDateSmall-300x196.jpg.pagespeed.ic_.lmz0Mhn_No.jpg 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/03/300x196xGiveCampLogo2HorizontalNoDateSmall-300x196.jpg.pagespeed.ic_.lmz0Mhn_No-190x124.jpg 190w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/03/300x196xGiveCampLogo2HorizontalNoDateSmall-300x196.jpg.pagespeed.ic_.lmz0Mhn_No-138x90.jpg 138w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a>This weekend (April 4th-6th, 2014), &nbsp;I’ll be gathering with over a hundred developers, designers, project managers, and strategists at the Microsoft <a title="Microsoft New England Research and Development " href="http://microsoftcambridge.com/" target="_blank">New England Research and Development</a> center for <a title="New England GiveCamp" href="http://newenglandgivecamp.org/">New England GiveCamp 2014</a>. &nbsp;We’ll spend the weekend – with many participants quite literally camping in the building and working through the night – designing, building, and enhancing websites and applications for <a title="New England GiveCamp Class of 2014" href="http://newenglandgivecamp.org/the-givecamp-class-of-2014-charities/" target="_blank">non-profit, mission-oriented organizations</a> from Massachusetts and New Hampshire.</p>
<p>GiveCamp is a fantastic event. I spoke at GiveCamp 2012 about Digital Strategy in the non-profit context, and then served as team lead in 2013.&nbsp;This year I look forward to just volunteering as a developer.&nbsp;Although many different technical platforms and languages are used at GiveCamp, my experience has been WordPress dominates the conversation and is used for the great majority of the projects.</p>
<p>If you’re in the broader New England area, and have experience with development, design, or project management I’d highly encourage you to check out <a title="New England GiveCamp" href="http://newenglandgivecamp.org/">GiveCamp</a> and consider <a title="New England GiveCamp 2014 Registration" href="http://www.eventbrite.com/e/new-england-givecamp-2014-tickets-10562515769" target="_blank">volunteering</a> your skills.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11478 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized john-eckman-ceo">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/john-eckman-ceo/">Meet John Eckman, 10up&nbsp;CEO</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-john-eckman" title="Posts by John Eckman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="John Eckman" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/jeckman-64x64.png" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2019/11/jeckman-128x128.png 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> John Eckman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/john-eckman-ceo/" title="Meet John Eckman, 10up CEO"><time datetime="2014-03-17T13:25:44-04:00">March 17, 2014</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/john-eckman-ceo/#comments" class="comments-count">8 Comments</a>
</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignright size-full wp-image-11479" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/johneckman-com1.jpg" alt="John Eckman" width="200" height="247" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/03/johneckman-com1.jpg 200w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/03/johneckman-com1-100x124.jpg 100w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/03/johneckman-com1-73x90.jpg 73w" sizes="(max-width: 200px) 100vw, 200px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;">Hi. I’m <a href="http://johneckman.com/">John Eckman</a> and I’m truly honored to officially join <a href="https://10up.com/about/">team 10up</a> today as CEO.</p>
<p><strong>Jake Goldman will continue as President &amp; Founder, and we will work closely together, as well as with the strong leadership team already in place,</strong> especially VP’s Jess Jurick and Vasken Hauri, as well as Directors Helen Hou-Sandi, John James Jacoby, Paul Clark, Taylor Aldridge, and Zach Brown. It’s truly an all-star team up and down the roster at 10up, and I feel incredibly fortunate to be part of it.</p>
<p>In broad strokes, Jake will focus on product development, recruiting, partnerships, business development, and company vision, while I will be more focused on operational management, client relationships, talent development, and execution against that vision.</p>
<p>Jake and the team have accomplished much over the last 3+ years, and I hope to continue that tradition of excellence while bringing additional processes and organizational development approaches appropriate to a growing firm.</p>
<p>I’ve spent the past 15+ years working in professional services agencies on digital strategy, user experience design, and software engineering, with a focus on content management, web publishing, and social. Short version: TVisions (which became Molecular, which became Isobar), PixelMEDIA, Optaros, and ISITE Design. (Long version: see <a href="http://www.linkedin.com/in/johneckman">LinkedIn</a>).</p>
<p>Over the course of that career I’ve worked with clients across many industries and sizes, from early-stage startups to the Fortune 50, as well as higher education and the non-profit sector. I’ve had the opportunity to work as a user experience manager, a technical architect, a project manager (and program manager), an account director and a strategy lead. I’ve worn most of the hats one can wear at a digital agency (other than visual designer, a fact that may be reasonably inferred from my own personal sites), and love nothing more than working with a team to solve a client problem or exceed a client expectation.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/john-eckman-ceo/#more-11478" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Meet John Eckman, 10up&nbsp;CEO</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11484 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-uncategorized espn-fivethirtyeight">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/espn-fivethirtyeight/">10up and FiveThirtyEight</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/" title="Posts by " rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo avatar-default" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> </a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/espn-fivethirtyeight/" title="10up and FiveThirtyEight"><time datetime="2014-03-17T12:34:59-04:00">March 17, 2014</time></a>
</p>
<p>We’re thrilled to unveil our second collaboration with ESPN, the new&nbsp;<a href="http://fivethirtyeight.com/">FiveThirtyEight</a>! The site relaunched today with a fresh new Responsive design and content strategy on&nbsp;<a href="http://wordpress.com/">WordPress.com</a>&nbsp;VIP. Over the course of roughly three months, 10up worked closely with ESPN to implement their new design vision, ensuring a fluid reader experience across devices using creative provided by their team. The WordPress theme powering the site features custom curation interfaces, advanced post editor controls (like footnotes), and sophisticated ad and analytics integrations.</p>
<p>The new FiveThirtyEight will continue to embody data journalism at its core, with Nate Silver at the helm now leading dozens of journalists reporting across verticals like Sports, Politics, and Science. In addition to traditional reporting, the site will also employ data visualization techniques to enable readers to better digest, interact with, and apply data trends to their everyday thinking. FiveThirtyEight will be housed in ESPN’s new Exit 31 content group, ”&nbsp;a creative enterprise&nbsp;that will combine&nbsp;the resources of three&nbsp;existing&nbsp;units – ESPN Films, Grantland and FiveThirtyEight&nbsp;– under one&nbsp;umbrella.”</p>
<p>We’ll have more to say about FiveThirtyEight in the future – for now, <a href="http://espnmediazone.com/us/press-releases/2014/03/espn-announces-new-content-unit-exit-31/">check out the new site</a>!</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11448 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized 10up-at-the-first-wordcamp-dayton">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/10up-at-the-first-wordcamp-dayton/">10up at the First WordCamp Dayton</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/" title="Posts by " rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo avatar-default" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> </a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/10up-at-the-first-wordcamp-dayton/" title="10up at the First WordCamp Dayton"><time datetime="2014-03-08T10:34:24-05:00">March 8, 2014</time></a>
</p>
<p><img decoding="async" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/20140308-072910.jpg" alt="WordCamp Dayton" class="alignright size-full" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;">This weekend is the first ever <a title="WordCamp Dayton" href="http://2014.dayton.wordcamp.org/">WordCamp Dayton</a>, taking place at Wright State University in Dayton, Ohio. &nbsp;I (Dustin Filippini) will be presenting, and am proud to help get a new WordCamp off the ground. &nbsp;I’m looking forward to meeting a number of amazing community members, including a great organizing committee.</p>
<p>I will be presenting “Take WordPress Beyond Pages and Posts:&nbsp;Plugins and Customizations that can take your WordPress Site to the Next Level.” &nbsp;I will look at unique and amazing WordPress customizations from around the web, showing off WordPress’s potential. I’ll offer examples of plugins, customizations, and built-in WordPress functionality that can take a site beyond than what most people realize is possible.</p>
<p>If you are in the Dayton area this weekend, stop by and support a great new WordCamp!</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11438 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized pushup-push-notifications-wordpress">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/pushup-push-notifications-wordpress/">PushUp: Push Notifications for&nbsp;WordPress</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/" title="Posts by " rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo avatar-default" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> </a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/pushup-push-notifications-wordpress/" title="PushUp: Push Notifications for WordPress"><time datetime="2014-03-07T17:04:31-05:00">March 7, 2014</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/pushup-push-notifications-wordpress/#comments" class="comments-count">5 Comments</a>
</p>
<p>We couldn’t be more proud to announce 10up’s first product, <a title="Push Notifications for WordPress" href="http://pushupnotifications.com/">PushUp</a>. PushUp makes it incredibly easy to deliver your content directly to your readers’ desktops, even when their browser is closed. In version 1.0, we’re starting with support for Safari Push Notifications on Mac OS X Mavericks, the best implementation of desktop notifications.</p>
<p><div class="fluid-width-video-wrapper" style="position: relative; width: 100%; padding-top: 75.0769%;"><iframe loading="lazy" width="650" height="488" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/HWu4XWEesX4.html" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen="" style="position: absolute; width: 100%; height: 100%; left: 0px; top: 0px;"></iframe></div></p>
<p>We couldn’t be more proud to feature launch partners like <a href="http://9to5mac.com/">9to5mac</a> and <a href="http://edelman.com/">Edelman</a>, with committed beta customers like Deadline.com and GigaOM taking PushUp into production in a matter of days. Expect to see more familiar brands rolling out PushUp in the coming weeks.</p>
<p>We think on demand notifications from websites – from desktop to mobile – is an important evolution in online publishing. Having to actively check a website or feed reader, or even Twitter, for the content you really care about seems to us as antiquated as manually opening your email client to check for new messages. Our push notifications are 100% white-labeled: we send consumers directly to your content. Nothing stands between your and your relationship with your reader, not even a link in the middle to our services.</p>
<p>Needless to say, Safari Push Notifications is just the beginning.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/pushup-push-notifications-wordpress/#more-11438" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on PushUp: Push Notifications for&nbsp;WordPress</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11427 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized 10up-ew-oscars-dashboard">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/10up-ew-oscars-dashboard/">10up goes to the Oscars with Entertainment Weekly</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-vasken-hauri" title="Posts by Vasken Hauri" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/VHauri-600x600-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2016/11/VHauri-600x600-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Vasken Hauri</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/10up-ew-oscars-dashboard/" title="10up goes to the Oscars with Entertainment Weekly"><time datetime="2014-03-02T19:29:01-05:00">March 2, 2014</time></a>
</p>
<p>As an agency with a reputation for building world-class solutions with WordPress, it may surprise you that one of our latest and most exciting projects barely even involves WordPress.</p>
<p>A new Interactive Dashboard experience, built for <a href="http://ew.com/">Entertainment Weekly’s desktop</a> and <a href="http://m.ew.com/">mobile websites</a>, presents real-time content from across EW’s vast network of industry-leading entertainment reporting. The Dashboard enables EW’s team to instantly post and curate relevant content from Twitter, EW’s network of entertainment blogs (powered by WordPress), and exclusive Red Carpet photos, serving up a true second-screen interactive experience for major entertainment events.</p>
<p><em><strong>The Dashboard had its first successful trial run during the Grammys, and will be in full swing during tonight’s Oscars presentation!</strong></em></p>
<p>Whether you’re on your computer, iPad, or mobile phone, we hope you’ll tune in!</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-11434" alt="EW Dashboard" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/ew-10up-2.jpg" width="756" height="502" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/03/ew-10up-2.jpg 756w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/03/ew-10up-2-300x199.jpg 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/03/ew-10up-2-187x124.jpg 187w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/03/ew-10up-2-136x90.jpg 136w" sizes="(max-width: 756px) 100vw, 756px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11419 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized wordcamp-st-louis">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/wordcamp-st-louis/">WordCamp St. Louis gets a jolt of&nbsp;10up</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-thorsten-ott" title="Posts by Thorsten Ott" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TOtt-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/TOtt-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Thorsten Ott</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/wordcamp-st-louis/" title="WordCamp St. Louis gets a jolt of 10up"><time datetime="2014-03-01T12:05:26-05:00">March 1, 2014</time></a>
</p>
<p><img decoding="async" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/20140301-085656.jpg" alt="20140301-085656.jpg" class="alignright size-full" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;">This weekend I (Adam Silverstein) am speaking at <a href="http://2014.stlouis.wordcamp.org/" target="_blank">WordCamp St. Louis</a> along with fellow 10uppers Rachel Baker and Doug Stewart. The event is sold out and we are excited to share our knowledge with the St. Louis WordPress community and meet fellow WordPress fans.</p>
<p>Our talks are all in the Developer II track, in support of the burgeoning local developer community.</p>
<p>My topic is “Revising WordPress Revisions.” I will cover the story and code behind the Backbone.js based revisions interface introduced in WordPress 3.6 and why revisions are awesome. What goes into remaking a feature in WordPress?</p>
<p>Doug’s topic is “Making Your Whole Life Easier With WP-CLI.” Doug will introduce developers to the powerful wp-cli, the WordPress command line interface. Doug will offer his perspective as a systems engineer, and expose developers to the power of administering WordPress from the command line.</p>
<p>Rachel’s topic is “Code with Care: Write Secure Plugins and Themes.” Rachel will cover how to protect sites from XSS (cross-site scripting), CSRF exploits, and unfiltered input attacks during common WordPress development practices. She will provide the security best-practices “how and why” for securing your code.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/wordcamp-st-louis/#more-11419" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on WordCamp St. Louis gets a jolt of&nbsp;10up</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11382 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized expanding-autocomplete-wordpress-admin">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/expanding-autocomplete-wordpress-admin/">Expanding autocomplete in the WordPress admin</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/helen/" title="Posts by Helen Hou-Sandi" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Helen Hou-Sandí" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/HHouSandi-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/HHouSandi-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Helen Hou-Sandi</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/expanding-autocomplete-wordpress-admin/" title="Expanding autocomplete in the WordPress admin"><time datetime="2014-02-27T17:24:10-05:00">February 27, 2014</time></a>
</p>
<p>Autocomplete is not a new concept in the WordPress admin – tags have had suggestions powered by <a href="http://www.enjoyxstudy.com/javascript/suggest/index.en.html">suggest.js</a> since <a href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/changeset/6542">their introduction six years ago</a> in version 2.5. This, however, remained the only instance of Ajax-powered autocompletion for another four years, until <a href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/19810">adding users in multisite was enhanced</a> with <a href="http://jqueryui.com/autocomplete/">jQuery UI autocomplete</a> for 3.4. It was originally committed with deliberately unpolished styling, so when I saw <a href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/20584#comment:1">a request to make it look better</a>, I decided to take it on. I may not consider myself a creative designer, but I do have an eye and passion for UI consistency. After a little iteration on both the design and code, we had a fully functional instance of autocomplete.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-11404" alt="WordPress autocomplete evolution" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/wp-autocomplete.png" width="756" height="110" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/02/wp-autocomplete.png 756w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/02/wp-autocomplete-300x44.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/02/wp-autocomplete-220x32.png 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/02/wp-autocomplete-160x23.png 160w" sizes="(max-width: 756px) 100vw, 756px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/expanding-autocomplete-wordpress-admin/#more-11382" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Expanding autocomplete in the WordPress admin</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11409 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized think-tank-future-wordpress">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/think-tank-future-wordpress/">A Conversation about the Future of&nbsp;WordPress</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/think-tank-future-wordpress/" title="A Conversation about the Future of WordPress"><time datetime="2014-02-24T19:56:26-05:00">February 24, 2014</time></a>
</p>
<p>10up is a digital agency that hangs its hat on the viability of open source web platforms – WordPress in particular. We think WordPress is the platform of choice for content management and publishing, and we’ve built <a title="team 10up" href="https://10up.com/about/">a team</a> that shares these open values and grasps WordPress like few others. More than 25 of us have made core contributions, and we’re home to&nbsp;<em>two</em> core committers. Needless to say, as President, I spend significant time thinking about this platform, from its underlying code quality to the healthy – and less healthy – habits of its considerable community.</p>
<p>Where is WordPress heading? Where&nbsp;<em>should</em> it head? Where are the biggest opportunities? How can WordPress continue to dominate the CMS space in another 5 years? <a href="http://jakegoldman.me/2013/09/wordpress-app-platform/">Does it make a good app platform?</a> Is there another platform we should be mastering?</p>
<p>So when WP Elevate’s Troy Dean invited me to participate in a live panel on the “future of WordPress” with leaders like WordPress founder Matt Mullenweg, Woo’s Scott Basgaard, and Modern Tribe’s Shane Pearlman (among others), I didn’t hesitate to accept.</p>
<h3><strong>You can catch <a href="http://wpthinktank.com/">WP Think Tank</a> tomorrow (February 25) at 8 pm UTC / 12 pm Pacific / 3 pm Eastern.</strong></h3>
<p>Rumor has it that, based on the reception, this might not be the only episode of WP Think Tank!</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-11411" alt="WP Think Tank" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/thinktank-756x375.jpg" width="710" height="352" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/02/thinktank-756x375.jpg 756w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/02/thinktank-300x149.jpg 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/02/thinktank-768x381.jpg 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/02/thinktank-220x109.jpg 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/02/thinktank-160x79.jpg 160w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/02/thinktank.jpg 1187w" sizes="(max-width: 710px) 100vw, 710px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11400 type-post status-publish format-aside hentry category-uncategorized post_format-post-format-aside wordpress-org-happy-hour-austin">

<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/helen/" title="Posts by Helen Hou-Sandi" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"> Helen Hou-Sandi</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/wordpress-org-happy-hour-austin/" title="WordPress.org Happy Hour in Austin, TX"><time datetime="2014-02-21T14:03:54-05:00">February 21, 2014</time></a>
</p>
<div class="body-copy">
<p>Howdy, Austin! I’m going to be in town for your upcoming WordPress Meetup on Tuesday, February 25. I’ll be at <a title="" href="http://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&amp;hl=en&amp;q=3601+South+Congress+Avenue%2C+Austin%2C+TX%2C+78704%2C+us" target="_blank">Opal Divine’s Penn Field</a> from 5 until 7 PM for the “WordPress.org Happy Hour”, along with some other members of the WordPress core team and the Automattic “dot org” team. Check out more details over on <a href="http://www.meetup.com/austinwordpress/events/166114772/" target="_blank">Meetup</a>, and come find me if you want to talk contributing or&nbsp;10up!</p>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-11387 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-uncategorized 10up-hosts-scott-berkun-in-portland">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/10up-hosts-scott-berkun-in-portland/">10up Hosts Scott Berkun in&nbsp;Portland</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/grantlandram/" title="Posts by Grant Landram" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Grant-Landram_avatar_1469546895-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2016/07/Grant-Landram_avatar_1469546895-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Grant Landram</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/10up-hosts-scott-berkun-in-portland/" title="10up Hosts Scott Berkun in Portland"><time datetime="2014-02-19T14:22:26-05:00">February 19, 2014</time></a>
</p>
<p>Hey there PDX! As you may know, 10up has a brick &amp; mortar office in Portland. So when our friend <a href="http://scottberkun.com/" target="_blank">Scott Berkun</a> reached out to us saying he’d be in Portland next weekend, we thought&nbsp;<em>Why not host a fun, unique opportunity to hear from Scott at the 10up office?</em></p>
<p>It’s our pleasure to announce we’ll be hosting Scott for a small, intimate chat about his recent book <a href="http://www.amazon.com/The-Year-Without-Pants-WordPress-com/dp/1118660633" target="_blank">The Year Without Pants</a> and his time running a distributed team working on WordPress.com. If you’re a designer, engineer, project manager or other web savvy Portlander interested in WordPress and/or distributed work, we’d love for you to join us!</p>
<p><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>The event is next Thursday, 2/27 from 5-7pm</strong></span> at the 10up office located at 618 NW Glisan St #400 Portland, OR 97209 with an informal happy hour around the corner at <a href="https://maps.google.com/maps?ie=UTF-8&amp;q=PINTS&amp;fb=1&amp;gl=us&amp;hq=pints+portland&amp;cid=5653254511340114962&amp;ei=d-oEU7ePEMSEyAGimID4DQ&amp;ved=0CKEBEPwSMAo" target="_blank">Pint’s</a> following Scott’s talk. We’d love to see you there!</p>
<p>RSVP by grabbing a (free) ticket on <a href="http://www.eventbrite.com/e/10up-hosts-scott-berkun-distributed-work-the-year-without-pants-tickets-10674927997" target="_blank">Eventbrite</a> to let us know that you’ll be coming.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11301 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized kicking-off-wordpress-3-9">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/kicking-off-wordpress-3-9/">Kicking off the WordPress 3.9 development cycle</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/helen/" title="Posts by Helen Hou-Sandi" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Helen Hou-Sandí" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/HHouSandi-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/HHouSandi-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Helen Hou-Sandi</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/kicking-off-wordpress-3-9/" title="Kicking off the WordPress 3.9 development cycle"><time datetime="2014-02-07T12:07:12-05:00">February 7, 2014</time></a>
</p>
<p>After the excitement of the 3.8 release and a typically quiet winter holiday season, it’s time to start in earnest on WordPress 3.9. This is a particularly exciting release for me: after three cycles of being a guest committer, <a href="http://make.wordpress.org/core/2013/12/31/commit-announcements-for-3-9/">I’ve been granted permanent commit access to core</a>. My goal is to continue to inform and build the admin experience, provide feedback on community contributions, and bring perspectives from real-world client implementation back to our favorite publishing platform. I’m honored to join these trusted ranks!</p>
<p>Drew Jaynes has also been renewed as a guest committer, and is on track to complete the inline documentation for hooks initiative. A few 10uppers have already begun contributing patches, with several working on unit tests. I’m particularly excited to see work by Adam Silverstein on <a href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/20564">storing revisions of post meta</a> and <a href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/20299">a ticket on the topic opened by Jake</a>.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-11368" alt="colors.css diff" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/colors-css-diff-756.png" width="756" height="291" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/02/colors-css-diff-756.png 756w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/02/colors-css-diff-756-300x115.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/02/colors-css-diff-756-220x85.png 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/02/colors-css-diff-756-160x62.png 160w" sizes="(max-width: 756px) 100vw, 756px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/kicking-off-wordpress-3-9/#more-11301" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Kicking off the WordPress 3.9 development cycle</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11355 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-uncategorized varying-vagrant-vagrants-future">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/varying-vagrant-vagrants-future/">Varying Vagrant Vagrants: All Grown&nbsp;Up</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/varying-vagrant-vagrants-future/" title="Varying Vagrant Vagrants: All Grown Up"><time datetime="2014-01-27T20:34:19-05:00">January 27, 2014</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/varying-vagrant-vagrants-future/#comments" class="comments-count">2 Comments</a>
</p>
<p><a href="http://jeremyfelt.com/code/2013/12/11/vvv-turns-one/">Just a bit over a year ago</a>, then-10upper Jeremy Felt decided it was time to part ways with MAMP and make friendly with Vagrant. With a little help from fellow 10up senior engineers and systems experts, <a href="https://github.com/10up/varying-vagrant-vagrants">Varying Vagrant Vagrants</a>&nbsp;was born, introducing a consistent and shareable approach to a WordPress development environment that better represented the real world production environments agencies like 10up build for.</p>
<p>With a 1.0 release, almost 800 commits, and nearly 40 contributors, it’s safe to say that Varying Vagrant Vagrants, or VVV as it’s become known, is an active and stable open source project. We’re so proud to have served as its founders and creators, and look forward to continuing to play a major role in its development and maintenance.</p>
<p><em><strong>And now, it’s time to give VVV a community of its own.</strong></em>&nbsp;A new Varying Vagrant Vagrants organization on GitHub has been created, and ownership of the main VVV repository is being transferred there.</p>
<p>It’s a little bittersweet to see your project take on its own life, and this is no different. Yet, as strong advocates for open source and the rising tide it fosters, we’re even more excited to see one of our investments in open R&amp;D take flight, and look forward to contributing to VVV, its community, and its future.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11299 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized tag-first-patch my-first-patch-helen">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/my-first-patch-helen/">My First Patch: Helen Hou-Sandi</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/helen/" title="Posts by Helen Hou-Sandi" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Helen Hou-Sandí" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/HHouSandi-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/HHouSandi-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Helen Hou-Sandi</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/my-first-patch-helen/" title="My First Patch: Helen Hou-Sandi"><time datetime="2014-01-27T13:55:24-05:00">January 27, 2014</time></a>
</p>
<p><em>We’re kicking off a series about first patches that became a part of an open source software project, beginning with my own story. With 25 of 50 10uppers – at the time of writing – credited as core contributors to WordPress, credits in a number of other projects, and communities of hundreds of contributors at large, we won’t run out of material any time soon. We hope that these sometimes inspiring and often humbling stories, from one-time contributors all the way up to the most prolific WordPress core developers, will entertain and offer some perspective to open source’s newest would-be contributors. Do you remember your first patch? Tell us how to get ahold of you in the comments, and we just might feature you!<br>
</em></p>
<p>My first committed patch to WordPress was for <a href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/17887">#17887</a> in June 2011, just a few months before I joined 10up. I was running trunk in my testing environment to ensure that our live site would upgrade smoothly and to be able to explain the impending 3.2 redesign to our users at the university. In hindsight, my experience is probably typical for first-time contributors, and may surprise those who know me today.</p>
<p><a href="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/01/trac-ticket-17887.png"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone wp-image-11343 size-large" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/trac-ticket-17887-756x379.png" alt="WordPress Trac ticket #17887" width="650" height="326" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/01/trac-ticket-17887-756x379.png 756w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/01/trac-ticket-17887-300x150.png 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/01/trac-ticket-17887-768x385.png 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/01/trac-ticket-17887-220x110.png 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/01/trac-ticket-17887-160x80.png 160w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/01/trac-ticket-17887.png 814w" sizes="(max-width: 650px) 100vw, 650px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/my-first-patch-helen/#more-11299" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on My First Patch: Helen Hou-Sandi</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11307 type-post status-publish format-aside hentry category-uncategorized post_format-post-format-aside new-jersey-wordpress-meetup">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/new-jersey-wordpress-meetup/" title="New Jersey WordPress Meetup"><img alt="Helen Hou-Sandí" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/HHouSandi-256x256.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/HHouSandi-512x512.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-256 photo" height="256" width="256" loading="lazy" decoding="async" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/helen/" title="Posts by Helen Hou-Sandi" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"> Helen Hou-Sandi</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/new-jersey-wordpress-meetup/" title="New Jersey WordPress Meetup"><time datetime="2014-01-24T20:54:45-05:00">January 24, 2014</time></a>
</p>
<div class="body-copy">
<p>I’ll be speaking about “Who is WordPress?” at the <a href="http://www.meetup.com/The-New-Jersey-WordPress-Meetup-Group/events/160694822/">New Jersey WordPress Meetup</a> down in Asbury Park, NJ next Tuesday, January 28. We’ll take a look at how WordPress is made and grows with the help of an amazing community, and how you’re already a part of it. This is my first time joining this meetup, and I’m really looking forward to&nbsp;it!</p>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11326 type-post status-publish format-image has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized post_format-post-format-image wordcamp-norway-2014">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/wordcamp-norway-2014/">WordCamp in the frozen&nbsp;north</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/ryan-hellyer/" title="Posts by Ryan Hellyer" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/235f395d4925593fd9560b69015f8746?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/235f395d4925593fd9560b69015f8746?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Ryan Hellyer</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/wordcamp-norway-2014/" title="WordCamp in the frozen north"><time datetime="2014-01-21T21:06:22-05:00">January 21, 2014</time></a>
</p>
<img width="650" height="866" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/me-sognsvann2-680x906.jpg" class="blog-archive-image wp-post-image" alt="" decoding="async" loading="lazy" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/01/me-sognsvann2-680x906.jpg 680w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/01/me-sognsvann2-680x906-225x300.jpg 225w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/01/me-sognsvann2-680x906-93x124.jpg 93w, https://10up.com/uploads/2014/01/me-sognsvann2-680x906-68x90.jpg 68w" sizes="(max-width: 650px) 100vw, 650px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"><p>The frozen wilderness of Norway will not keep a 10upper from attending a WordCamp! I’m heading to <a href="http://2014.norway.wordcamp.org/">WordCamp Norway</a> this weekend to talk about my experience learning WordPress security best practices. I’ll be discussing the (many) mistakes I made along the way, how I learned from them, and how you can learn from them,&nbsp;too.</p>
<p>This is the third WordCamp Norway to be held in the capital city of Oslo. The first day consists of presentations from speakers from countries as diverse as the Netherlands, Ukraine, Sweden, Switzerland, USA, New Zealand, Spain and Norway. Day two is an optional contributor day for anyone wanting to contribute to WordPress core, documentation, or the WordPress.org support&nbsp;forums.</p>
<p>Anyone in Europe interested in WordPress should come join us at WordCamp Norway. If the past two years’ were anything to go by, the 2014 event will be awesome fun for&nbsp;all.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11311 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized tag-conference tag-wordcamp wordcamp-phoenix-2014">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/wordcamp-phoenix-2014/">10up on Fire at WordCamp Phoenix&nbsp;2014</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/paul-clark/" title="Posts by Paul Clark" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/PClark-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/PClark-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Paul Clark</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2014/wordcamp-phoenix-2014/" title="10up on Fire at WordCamp Phoenix 2014"><time datetime="2014-01-16T21:31:25-05:00">January 16, 2014</time></a>
</p>
<p>WordCamp Phoenix holds a special place in my (Paul Clark) heart as a place of many firsts.</p>
<p>In 2012, Taylor Aldridge and I watched 10up’s <a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-helen-hou-sandi">Helen Hou-Sandi</a>&nbsp;present on&nbsp;<a href="http://slides.helenhousandi.com/wcphx2012.html#1">Maintaining a Beautiful&nbsp;WordPress Admin UI</a>. It was our first WordCamp as a small agency called <a href="http://brainstormmedia.com/" target="_blank">Brainstorm Media</a>.</p>
<p>In 2013, I returned for my first time as a speaker, presenting <a href="http://wordpress.tv/2013/03/08/paul-clark-how-wordpress-saves-lives-freedom-hope-and-custom-post-types/">How WordPress Saves Lives: Freedom, Hope, and Custom Post Types</a>.</p>
<p>This year, Taylor Aldridge and I are proud both to be speaking and to a be a part of the 10up team. As the start to an exciting new year, Brainstorm Media <a href="https://10up.com/blog/brainstorm-joins-10up/" target="_blank">joined the talented team of WordPress developers at 10up</a>.</p>
<p>In total, that makes five team members and six talks that will be presenting at WordCamp Phoenix this year. Find us <a href="http://2014.phoenix.wordcamp.org/schedule" target="_blank">on the schedule</a>, and come chat with us <a href="http://2014.phoenix.wordcamp.org/session/afterparty-at-chandler-city-hall/" target="_blank">at the after party!</a></p>
<ul>
<li>Taylor Aldridge:&nbsp;<a href="http://2014.phoenix.wordcamp.org/session/you-know-its-good-cause-its-blue/">You Know it’s Good, Cause it’s Blue</a></li>
<li>Paul Clark:&nbsp;<a href="http://2014.phoenix.wordcamp.org/session/cowboy-meet-ninja-how-to-never-crash-a-site-again/">Cowboy, meet Ninja: How to never crash a site again</a></li>
<li>Heather Hogan:&nbsp;<a href="http://2014.phoenix.wordcamp.org/session/scoping-contracting-and-getting-paid/">Scoping, Contracting, and Getting Paid</a></li>
<li>Eric Mann:&nbsp;<a href="http://2014.phoenix.wordcamp.org/session/ten-lessons-on-customer-centric-development/">Ten Lessons on Customer-centric Development</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="http://2014.phoenix.wordcamp.org/session/12-needs-unit-tests/">{12} Needs Unit Tests</a></li>
<li>Adam Silverstein:&nbsp;<a href="http://2014.phoenix.wordcamp.org/session/revising-wordpress-revisions/" target="_blank">Revising WordPress Revisions</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11278 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized brainstorm-joins-10up">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/brainstorm-joins-10up/">Proud to announce Brainstorm joining&nbsp;10up</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/paul-clark/" title="Posts by Paul Clark" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/PClark-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/PClark-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Paul Clark</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/brainstorm-joins-10up/" title="Proud to announce Brainstorm joining 10up"><time datetime="2013-12-24T15:19:26-05:00">December 24, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p>Over the past few years, the <a href="http://brainstormmedia.com/">Brainstorm</a> team was pleasantly surprised each time we encountered 10up. While meeting at conferences around the country, we discovered a deep-set of shared values and goals. 10up and Brainstorm believe that democratized, open publishing platforms like WordPress can make the web — and the world — a better place. We embrace community contribution, and improving the lives of those around us.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-11282" style="font-size: 14px; line-height: 1; visibility: visible;" alt="Brainstorm joins 10up" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/BrainUp-Announcement-v6-756x353.jpg" width="710" height="331" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2013/12/BrainUp-Announcement-v6-756x353.jpg 756w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/12/BrainUp-Announcement-v6-300x140.jpg 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/12/BrainUp-Announcement-v6-768x359.jpg 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/12/BrainUp-Announcement-v6-220x103.jpg 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/12/BrainUp-Announcement-v6-160x75.jpg 160w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/12/BrainUp-Announcement-v6.jpg 770w" sizes="(max-width: 710px) 100vw, 710px" data-xblocker="passed"></p>
<p>As a co-founder of Brainstorm, I (Paul Clark) will be focusing on building new business opportunities, with a special focus on non-profit and cause-oriented engagement. Anyone who has seen my 5-minute talk, “<a href="http://wordpress.tv/2013/09/09/paul-clark-lightning-talk-how-wordpress-saves-lives-moves-governments/">How WordPress Saves Lives and Moves Governments</a>,” knows I hold a special place in my heart for big ideas and humanitarian causes.</p>
<p>Taylor Aldridge, Brainstorm’s co-founder, will bring his decades of creative and design experience to 10up’s quickly growing design team, and is eager to see 10up’s creative reputation match its software engineering cred.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/brainstorm-joins-10up/#more-11278" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Proud to announce Brainstorm joining&nbsp;10up</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11007 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-uncategorized tag-taxonomy-query wordpress-mixed-relationship-taxonomy-queries">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordpress-mixed-relationship-taxonomy-queries/">Mixed relationship taxonomy queries in&nbsp;WordPress</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/helen/" title="Posts by Helen Hou-Sandi" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Helen Hou-Sandí" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/HHouSandi-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/HHouSandi-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Helen Hou-Sandi</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordpress-mixed-relationship-taxonomy-queries/" title="Mixed relationship taxonomy queries in WordPress"><time datetime="2013-12-16T17:37:05-05:00">December 16, 2013</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordpress-mixed-relationship-taxonomy-queries/#comments" class="comments-count">9 Comments</a>
</p>
<p><span style="line-height: 1.7em;">Earlier this year we launched a membership component for my very first project with 10up: </span><a style="line-height: 1.7em;" href="http://learningworksforkids.com/">LearningWorks for Kids</a><span style="line-height: 1.7em;">. LearningWorks’s content focuses on making the most of digital content to support learning, academics, and development of critical thinking skills. Memberships come with support for multiple private child users, each of whom has a profile that includes their age, thinking skills, academic skills, and special learning needs. Each member can also indicate which digital platforms and devices are available to their child users.</span></p>
<p>The central benefit of membership, beyond access to exclusive content, is the personalized recommendations across four different content types for each child user. These recommendations take into account the child’s age and available platforms, as well as a combination of skills and needs as indicated in their profile. These are related by <em>five</em> custom taxonomies – platforms, age, thinking skills, academic skills, and special needs. In this instance, we need to get content matching this set of criteria: age <code>AND</code> one of the platforms <code>AND</code> one of thinking skills <code>OR</code> academic skills <code>OR</code> special needs. This is a mixed relationship taxonomy query, and I’ll show you how we pulled it off.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone wp-image-11268 size-large" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/lwk_recommendations_crop-756x1010.png" alt="LearningsWorks recommendations" width="650" height="868" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2013/12/lwk_recommendations_crop-756x1010.png 756w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/12/lwk_recommendations_crop-225x300.png 225w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/12/lwk_recommendations_crop-768x1026.png 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/12/lwk_recommendations_crop-93x124.png 93w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/12/lwk_recommendations_crop-67x90.png 67w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/12/lwk_recommendations_crop.png 1067w" sizes="(max-width: 650px) 100vw, 650px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordpress-mixed-relationship-taxonomy-queries/#more-11007" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Mixed relationship taxonomy queries in&nbsp;WordPress</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11205 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-uncategorized wordsesh-2">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordsesh-2/">Catch 10uppers at WordSesh 2 starting tonight</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/" title="Posts by " rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo avatar-default" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> </a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordsesh-2/" title="Catch 10uppers at WordSesh 2 starting tonight"><time datetime="2013-12-06T13:05:37-05:00">December 6, 2013</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordsesh-2/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<p>In just a few short hours, three of my favorite 10uppers (myself included) will be participating in the second annual <a href="http://wordsesh.org/">WordSesh</a>&nbsp;— it’s&nbsp;1 full day of live WordPress presentations from all over the world streamed live to your screen.</p>
<p>At 6:00 UTC, our founder, Jake Goldman, is joining&nbsp;prolific free-agent designer James Dalman; together they’ll be presenting “Don’t be the Unicorn” – a talk about finding your specialization within web and WordPress, and effectively collaborating with different specialists!</p>
<p>At 17:00 UTC, one of our always charming and extremely talented senior engineers, Eric Mann, will flex some JS muscle and help pump you up in his session aptly titled: Rock-solid JavaScript and AJAX. Having recently spoke at <a href="https://10up.com/blog/10up-jquery-russia/">jQuery Russia</a>&nbsp;about the <a href="http://eamann.com/slides/jqcon-russia-2013">HTML5 web worker API</a>&nbsp;and <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infinite_monkey_theorem">Monkeys</a>, this is a session you will not want to miss.</p>
<p>And me?&nbsp;At 11:00 UTC, I’ll be doing round 2 of last year’s fireside chat, where I’ll naturally be talking about <a href="http://buddypress.org/">BuddyPress</a>, <a href="http://bbpress.org/">bbPress</a>, 10up, and hopefully taking questions from a lively international audience (since it will be about 5am here in the U.S.). I don’t have unicorns or monkeys, but maybe Paul the Dog will make a special appearance.</p>
<p>This year’s <a href="http://wordsesh.org/#speakers">lineup of speakers</a>&nbsp;is practically an all-star cast of WordPress contributors. If you can’t make our sessions, try to tune in at least for a bit. It starts Saturday, December 7, 2013, at UTC 00:00, and hopefully we’ll see you (or you’ll see us) there!</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-10989 type-post status-publish format-aside has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized post_format-post-format-aside big-media-meetup-workflows">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/big-media-meetup-workflows/" title="December Big Media WordPress Meetup: Redefining Traditional Media Workflows in WordPress"><img alt="Helen Hou-Sandí" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/HHouSandi-256x256.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/HHouSandi-512x512.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-256 photo" height="256" width="256" loading="lazy" decoding="async" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/helen/" title="Posts by Helen Hou-Sandi" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"> Helen Hou-Sandi</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/big-media-meetup-workflows/" title="December Big Media WordPress Meetup: Redefining Traditional Media Workflows in WordPress"><time datetime="2013-12-05T13:56:41-05:00">December 5, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<div class="body-copy">
<p>I’ll be presenting a flash talk entitled “Redefining Traditional Media Workflows in WordPress” tonight at the <a href="http://www.meetup.com/Big-Media-WordPress-Meetup/events/149290682/">December Big Media WordPress Meetup</a> in NYC. The topic is “big media editorial experiences”, and I’ll be joined by professionals from the Washington Post, WordPress.com VIP, and Parade. I’ll offer a quick look inside the editorial experience we built for Global News, serving over 1,000 contributors across 11 localized editions, along with the centralized web-to-print content management workflow we built for Variety. If you’re working in media and New York City, be sure to swing by.</p>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11078 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized giving-back-to-wordpress">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/giving-back-to-wordpress/">Upping our commitment to the WordPress community</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/helen/" title="Posts by Helen Hou-Sandi" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Helen Hou-Sandí" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/HHouSandi-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/HHouSandi-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Helen Hou-Sandi</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/giving-back-to-wordpress/" title="Upping our commitment to the WordPress community"><time datetime="2013-11-18T15:00:12-05:00">November 18, 2013</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/giving-back-to-wordpress/#comments" class="comments-count">5 Comments</a>
</p>
<p>Here at 10up, we strongly believe that a vibrant and active WordPress community is crucial to our success and longevity. After all, our business is built on the confidence that our favorite piece of free open source software serves as a great publishing platform. As we’ve grown, we’ve been able to expand our commitment to creating amazing publishing experiences for our clients and partners to the WordPress open source project itself.</p>
<p>At <a href="https://10up.com/blog/jake-helen-take-wordcamp-philly-2011/">WordCamp Philly 2011</a>, Jake and I finally met in person for the first time. Over dinner, we talked about our shared values in the community and the conversation led to an intriguing proposition: time each week to spend contributing to WordPress – a donation to the community by way of hours and effort. It began with 5 hours a week, and as 10up grew, it increased to become 8, then 15, then 20 hours each week. Today, I am really excited to announce that <strong>I am officially endorsed to work full-time on WordPress core </strong>as a guest committer and leader in the community.</p>
<blockquote>
<h2>I am officially endorsed to work full-time on WordPress core&nbsp;as a guest committer and leader in the community.</h2>
</blockquote>
<p>In practice, I have chosen to continue being active on some client projects. We are especially valuable in contributing back to the community in the areas we handle deeply in our work for clients and partners, and I feel that the best way for me to do that is to remain grounded in the world of implementation and especially custom administrative interfaces. I also regard our team as incomparable (<a href="https://10up.com/contact/#jobs-info">for which we’re always hiring</a>) and would hate to miss the opportunity to work with and learn from such an incredible group.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/giving-back-to-wordpress/#more-11078" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Upping our commitment to the WordPress community</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11166 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized wordcamps-orlando-denver-edmonton">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordcamps-orlando-denver-edmonton/">WordCamps and 10up everywhere: Orlando, Denver, and&nbsp;Edmonton</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/aaronholbrook/" title="Posts by Aaron Holbrook" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/AHolbrook-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/AHolbrook-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Aaron Holbrook</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordcamps-orlando-denver-edmonton/" title="WordCamps and 10up everywhere: Orlando, Denver, and Edmonton"><time datetime="2013-11-15T20:01:18-05:00">November 15, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p>This coming weekend I’ll be traveling to sunny Orlando, Florida to speak at <a href="http://2013.orlando.wordcamp.org/">WordCamp Orlando</a>, along with&nbsp;my friend and coworker, Carl Danley. Meanwhile, Grant Landram and Luke Woodward will be speaking at WordCamp Denver, led by our own Drew Jaynes, while Vasken Hauri speaks at <a href="http://2013.edmonton.wordcamp.org/">WordCamp Edmonton</a>.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-11170" alt="WordCamp Orlando Denver Edmonton" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/wordcamps-orlando-denver-edmonton.jpg" width="710" height="234" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2013/11/wordcamps-orlando-denver-edmonton.jpg 710w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/11/wordcamps-orlando-denver-edmonton-300x99.jpg 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/11/wordcamps-orlando-denver-edmonton-220x73.jpg 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/11/wordcamps-orlando-denver-edmonton-160x53.jpg 160w" sizes="(max-width: 710px) 100vw, 710px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></p>
<p>Carl and I will be giving back to back talks on Saturday morning in Orlando, so make sure to wake up early and get the best seats. I’ll be opining on the <a href="http://2013.orlando.wordcamp.org/session/how-i-learned-to-stop-worrying-and-love-interactive-debugging/">joys of interactive debugging</a>, which should be a core part of a developer’s tool set. If your go-to debugging tool starts with var and ends with dump(), this talk is for you! Senior Engineer Carl Danley will be covering <a href="http://2013.orlando.wordcamp.org/session/a-sensible-approach-to-javascript-in-wordpress-plugins/">sensible approaches to JavaScript</a>. In his own words: “<span style="line-height: 1.7em;">More often than not, as WordPress developers, we focus on PHP and often overlook the important aspects of JavaScript. In this presentation, I’ll reveal a series of steps that will help you rock your next JavaScript application by taking it the next level.” On&nbsp;</span><span style="line-height: 1.7em;">Sunday, Carl and I will help lead the <a href="http://2013.orlando.wordcamp.org/session/wordpress-contribute-session/">Contributor session</a> along with Mark Jaquith, Andrew Nacin and Pippin Williamson – sure to be a good time!</span></p>
<p>WordCamp Orlando is also <a href="http://2013.orlando.wordcamp.org/sponsor/seoslides/">sponsored by&nbsp;<em>seoslides</em></a>, a&nbsp;<a href="http://seoslides.com/">WordPress presentation creation and sharing</a> solution built&nbsp;and partly owned by 10up.</p>
<p>Westward in Denver, local Web Engineer Drew Jaynes is leading WordCamp Denver, where he’ll also lead a <a href="http://2013.denver.wordcamp.org/session/contributing-to-wp-going-from-zero-to-patch/">session on WordPress contribution</a>. Senior Strategist Grant Landram is dropping in to take part in a <a href="http://2013.denver.wordcamp.org/session/panel-how-a-ux-focus-is-driving-wordpress-forward/">panel exploring the importance of user experience</a>. Senior Strategic Engineer Luke Woodward continues the quest to <a href="http://2013.denver.wordcamp.org/session/breaking-up-with-amp/">kill classic MAMP / WAMP developer environments</a> in favor of <a href="https://github.com/10up/varying-vagrant-vagrants">the popular Varying Vagrants project</a> seeded by 10up.</p>
<p>Finally, up north in Edmonton, our Vice President of Strategic Engineering, Vasken Hauri, will cover both theory and practical tools for <a href="http://2013.edmonton.wordcamp.org/session/better-living-through-code-scanning/">automating code scanning</a> and maintaining code quality. As a former adjunct Computer Science professor, Vasken is no stranger to tackling complex subjects.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11146 type-post status-publish format-aside hentry category-uncategorized post_format-post-format-aside wordpress-hack-day-jersey-city">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordpress-hack-day-jersey-city/" title="WordPress Hack Day, Jersey City"><img alt="Helen Hou-Sandí" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/HHouSandi-256x256.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/HHouSandi-512x512.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-256 photo" height="256" width="256" loading="lazy" decoding="async" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/helen/" title="Posts by Helen Hou-Sandi" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"> Helen Hou-Sandi</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordpress-hack-day-jersey-city/" title="WordPress Hack Day, Jersey City"><time datetime="2013-11-06T00:47:48-05:00">November 6, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<div class="body-copy">
<p>This Saturday I’m hosting a WordPress core hack day here in Jersey City, right outside Manhattan. I’ll be joined by a handful of WordPress developers in the NYC metro area, including lead developers from some of the largest publications, as well as some East Coast 10uppers. Since this particular get-together will be at my home, it’s an intimate group, though I plan to facilitate future hack days at larger venues as we advance our mission to make WordPress a better publishing experience for&nbsp;all.</p>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11120 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized tag-conference tag-jquery tag-russia 10up-jquery-russia">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/10up-jquery-russia/">10up and jQuery go to&nbsp;Russia</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-eric-mann" title="Posts by Eric Mann" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/EMann-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/EMann-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Eric Mann</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/10up-jquery-russia/" title="10up and jQuery go to Russia"><time datetime="2013-11-01T16:24:14-04:00">November 1, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p>This has been a year of firsts, from first releases on <a title="10up Github" href="http://github.com/10up">10up’s GitHub</a> account to our first <a title="Coming to Portland: 10up’s First Internal Developer Summit" href="https://10up.com/blog/10up-2013-developer-summit/">internal dev summit</a>. &nbsp;This year also saw 10up’s first appearance at <a title="jQuery Russia" href="http://jquery.itmozg.ru/">jQuery Russia</a> – coincidentally also the first jQuery conference in Russia!</p>
<p>A little over a week ago, I had the opportunity to visit Moscow for an incredible day of development talks at <a title="Digital October" href="http://digitaloctober.ru/en/">Digital October</a>. &nbsp;The conference was sponsored by <a title="ITmozq" href="http://itmozg.ru/">ITmozg</a> in Russia, and headlined by the president of the <a title="jQuery Foundation" href="https://jquery.org/">jQuery Foundation</a>, Dave Methvin.</p>
<div id="attachment_11124" style="width: 300px" class="wp-caption alignright"><img aria-describedby="caption-attachment-11124" decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="size-medium wp-image-11124 " title="jQuery Cookie" alt="The snacks were as impressive as the talks!" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/IMAG0464-300x169.jpg" width="300" height="169" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2013/10/IMAG0464-300x169.jpg 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/10/IMAG0464-768x433.jpg 768w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/10/IMAG0464-756x426.jpg 756w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/10/IMAG0464-220x124.jpg 220w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/10/IMAG0464-1920x1080.jpg 1920w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/10/IMAG0464-1152x648.jpg 1152w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/10/IMAG0464-576x324.jpg 576w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/10/IMAG0464-160x90.jpg 160w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"><p id="caption-attachment-11124" class="wp-caption-text">The snacks were as impressive as the talks!</p></div>
<p>jQuery Russia covered topics from JavaScript performance to the use of $.Deferred. &nbsp;I was able to present an <a title="Web Workers + jQuery" href="http://eamann.com/slides/jqcon-russia-2013">overview of the HTML5 web worker API</a> along with a live demonstration of the <a title="Infinite Monkey Theorem" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infinite_monkey_theorem">million monkey problem</a> – implemented entirely in JavaScript.</p>
<p>jQuery Russia was an amazing experience for everyone involved, and it showed me just how well different parts of the&nbsp;<em>international</em> development community can work together. &nbsp;I don’t speak Russian and presented my talk with the help of an interpreter. &nbsp;Many of the attendees didn’t speak English, but were able to ask me questions about code after the talk and throughout the conference – again, with the aid of an interpreter.</p>
<p>All of the conference speakers were invited back to the main stage at the end of the day for an interactive Q&amp;A session. Questions ranged from browser standards to what we’d like to see added to JavaScript to where we see jQuery in 5-10 years. The range of opinions was impressive, but the expertise that backed each was even more so.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/10up-jquery-russia/#more-11120" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on 10up and jQuery go to&nbsp;Russia</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11130 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized wordcamp-boston-2013">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordcamp-boston-2013/">5 speakers, 1 organizer, and a Platinum Sponsorship: 10up loves WordCamp Boston</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordcamp-boston-2013/" title="5 speakers, 1 organizer, and a Platinum Sponsorship: 10up loves WordCamp Boston"><time datetime="2013-10-24T16:13:45-04:00">October 24, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="alignright size-full wp-image-11133" alt="WordCamp Boston 2013" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/1981_10151829966928899_977836730_n.jpg" width="300" height="300" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2013/10/1981_10151829966928899_977836730_n.jpg 300w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/10/1981_10151829966928899_977836730_n-150x150.jpg 150w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/10/1981_10151829966928899_977836730_n-124x124.jpg 124w, https://10up.com/uploads/2013/10/1981_10151829966928899_977836730_n-90x90.jpg 90w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;">WordCamp Boston has a special place in team 10up’s heart, going all the way back to Boston’s first camp, which I helped organize in 2010, before there <em>was</em> a 10up. In 2011, not 6 months after founding 10up, we reached into our pocket to offer a Silver sponsorship, and I spoke about WordPress as a CMS. In 2012, we again extended a Silver sponsorship; I debuted a talk on Enterprise, and was joined by fellow 10up speakers Jess Jurick and Luke Gedeon (who runs the neighboring Providence WordCamp). Today, two 10uppers live in the Boston metro area: Senior Engineer Dave Ross, and Engineer Kelly Dwan, who also organizes the monthly meet up and helped organize this weekend’s event. Three of our senior staff – Jess Jurick, John Jacoby, and I – all lived within ~100 miles of Boston at some point since 10up’s&nbsp;inception.</p>
<p>So it goes without saying that, above and beyond Kelly’s co-organizing, we were going to make a meaningful contribution to WordCamp Boston 2013. With more resources in hand, we’ve provided <a href="http://2013.boston.wordcamp.org/sponsor/10up/">a top-tier, Platinum Sponsorship</a>; we’re sponsoring Saturday’s lunch! You’ll find 7 of us at the conference, 5 of us&nbsp;speaking:</p>
<ul>
<li>I’m giving away 10up <a href="http://2013.boston.wordcamp.org/session/10-interview-questions-i-ask-every-developer/">developer interview strategies and questions</a>.</li>
<li>Our Director of Engineering and lead bbPress developer, John Jacoby, will be <a href="http://2013.boston.wordcamp.org/session/sweet-bbpress-secrets/">giving away some bbPress secrets</a>.</li>
<li>Senior Engineer Eric Mann, hot on the heels of his talk at jQuery Conference in Russia, is <a href="http://2013.boston.wordcamp.org/session/php-unit-testing/">teaching PHP Unit Testing</a>, a skill set crucial to the future of WordPress.</li>
<li>Are you afraid of the command line? Senior Engineer John Bloch, just coming off the TechCrunch.com relaunch last week, &nbsp;will teach you to <a href="http://2013.boston.wordcamp.org/session/how-i-learned-to-stop-worrying-and-love-the-command-line/">fear the command line no more</a>.</li>
<li>Finally, Engineer Kelly Dwan will <a href="http://2013.boston.wordcamp.org/session/ux-for-theme-and-plugin-developers/">co-lead a Friday workshop focused on theme and plug-in UX</a>.</li>
</ul>
<p>You’ll find more 10uppers roaming the halls and manning the 10up table (<strong>did someone say free swag?</strong>): local Senior Engineer Dave Ross and prolific core contributor (find her face on your credits screen) Helen&nbsp;Hou-Sandi.</p>
<p>Check out my <a href="http://2013.boston.wordcamp.org/2013/10/23/welcome-10up-as-a-platinum-sponsor/">guest blog post on the WordCamp Boston website</a> for more reminiscing about 10up and Boston connections, like our work for <a href="http://www.bostonmagazine.com/">Boston Magazine</a>. If you’ll be in town, find a 10upper, visit our table, be sure to see our talks, and enjoy lunch – it’s on&nbsp;us!</p>
</div>
</article>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-11095 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized givegamp-wordpress-seattle">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/givegamp-wordpress-seattle/">Non-Profit Hackathon Puts WordPress Center&nbsp;Stage</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/grantlandram/" title="Posts by Grant Landram" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Grant-Landram_avatar_1469546895-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2016/07/Grant-Landram_avatar_1469546895-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Grant Landram</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/givegamp-wordpress-seattle/" title="Non-Profit Hackathon Puts WordPress Center Stage"><time datetime="2013-10-10T12:13:36-04:00">October 10, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p style="position: relative; color: red;"><div style="width:400px;height:271px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:400px 271px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div><h1 style="position: absolute; font-weight: bold; z-index: 1000; top: 50%; left: 50%; color: rgb(255, 153, 0); text-align: center; transform: translate(-50%, -50%);">FAILED</h1></p>
<p>On Saturday morning I will be leading a 2-hour workshop for participating organizations and volunteers on how to better leverage WordPress on their projects during the weekend and beyond. Many of the participating organizations are either already using WordPress, or have identified their project as requiring a WordPress component. In my session I will cover a variety of WordPress topics ranging from how to start using WordPress for the first time, to using some it’s more advanced APIs, to simple every day tips and tricks. The session will be Saturday morning from 10am to noon, and is open to the general public.</p>
<p>For more information about GiveCamp visit <a href="http://seattlegivecamp.org/" target="_blank">http://seattlegivecamp.org/</a> and follow them on twitter <a href="https://twitter.com/seattlegivecamp" target="_blank">@SeattleGivecamp</a>. Best of luck to all the project teams this weekend, and if you’re in the Seattle area I hope to see you there!</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11090 type-post status-publish format-image has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized post_format-post-format-image doug-stewart-joins-10up">
