<article class="blog-archive-post post-11054 type-post status-publish format-aside hentry category-uncategorized post_format-post-format-aside 200-ok">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/200-ok/" title="200 OK"><img alt="Helen Hou-Sandí" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/HHouSandi-256x256.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/HHouSandi-512x512.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-256 photo" height="256" width="256" loading="lazy" decoding="async" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/helen/" title="Posts by Helen Hou-Sandi" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"> Helen Hou-Sandi</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/200-ok/" title="200 OK"><time datetime="2013-09-25T16:05:37-04:00">September 25, 2013</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/200-ok/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<div class="body-copy">
<p>Although I only lived in the Midwest (specifically Wichita) for a brief 11 months, I enjoyed my time there and am very excited to head back to the area on Friday, September 27, to speak at <a href="http://200ok.us/">200 OK</a>, Oklahoma’s premier web conference. I’m excited to be on a <a href="http://200ok.us/speakers/">roster</a> that includes a fellow WordPress developer from iThemes, as well as representatives of other open source supporters such as Adobe, GitHub, Mozilla, and Etsy. The WordPress Foundation is also proud to be sponsoring the event.</p>
<p>I’ll be talking about <a href="http://200ok.us/schedule/tailoring-the-wordpress-admin-for-workflows/">Tailoring the WordPress Admin for Workflows</a>; not an uncommon topic for me, but to a non-WordCamp audience and as always, I’ll be similarly tailoring my own presentation. <a href="http://200ok.us/registration">Tickets have sold out</a>, but there’s a waitlist. If you’re in the area, I’d love to meet you there!</p>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11063 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized portland-wordcamp-open-house">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/portland-wordcamp-open-house/">Making our home in&nbsp;Portland</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/taylor/" title="Posts by Taylor Dewey" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TDewey-600x600-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2016/11/TDewey-600x600-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Dewey</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/portland-wordcamp-open-house/" title="Making our home in Portland"><time datetime="2013-09-20T12:22:55-04:00">September 20, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p>A few months ago, as 10up’s Portland contingent continued to grow, we decided that it was time to put down roots in the city and <a href="https://10up.com/blog/portland-office-opening/">set up our first brick-and-mortar</a>&nbsp;office. To celebrate our new space, we hosted an open house on the eve of this year’s <a href="http://2013.portland.wordcamp.org/">WordCamp Portland</a>. We <a href="https://10up.com/blog/portland-open-house/">invited the Portland and WordPress community</a> to come check out our new office, and meet some of our team.</p>
<p>Senior Designer Megan Gray (visiting from Orange Country) and I spent the week preparing the office for the open house. Located in the former <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oregon_Cracker_Company_Building">Oregon Cracker Building</a>, our space was very much a blank canvas. With a nod to the history of the space – and the work ahead of us – we set out give the office an industrial vibe.</p>
<p>In just one week’s time, we transformed the office into a warm, welcoming atmosphere for Portland 10uppers (and their guests) to collaborate and host community events. By the end of the week, the office was full of 10uppers – both local and out-of-town – enjoying the space and the opportunity to collaborate under one roof.</p>
<p><a href="https://10up.com/uploads/2013/09/PDX-1.jpg" style="position: relative; color: red;"><div style="width:800px;height:1033px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 1033px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div><h1 style="position: absolute; font-weight: bold; z-index: 1000; top: 50%; left: 50%; color: rgb(255, 153, 0); text-align: center; transform: translate(-50%, -50%);">FAILED</h1></a></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/portland-wordcamp-open-house/#more-11063" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Making our home in&nbsp;Portland</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11036 type-post status-publish format-aside has-post-thumbnail hentry category-appearances post_format-post-format-aside alliteration-in-audio">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/alliteration-in-audio/" title="Alliteration in Audio"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jason-Clarke_avatar_1526492567-256x256.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2018/05/Jason-Clarke_avatar_1526492567-512x512.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-256 photo" height="256" width="256" loading="lazy" decoding="async" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jason-clarke" title="Posts by Jason Clarke" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"> Jason Clarke</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/alliteration-in-audio/" title="Alliteration in Audio"><time datetime="2013-09-13T13:19:10-04:00">September 13, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<div class="body-copy">
<p>10up’s <a title="John James Jacoby is the September 13th guest on the WordPress Weekly podcast" href="http://www.wptavern.com/this-week-on-wordpress-weekly-john-james-jacoby">John James Jacoby is the guest</a> for this week’s episode of <a title="WordPress Weekly podcast" href="http://www.wptavern.com/wordpress-weekly">WordPress Weekly</a>,&nbsp;WP Tavern’s <em>live</em> Friday night podcast (think Wayne’s World for WordPress, but smarter), airing this Friday, September 13th at 9pm EDT. Likely topics of conversation include John’s move from Automattic to 10up and what’s in the cards for BuddyPress and bbPress.&nbsp;<a title="Submit a question to John James Jacoby for WordPress Weekly" href="http://www.wptavern.com/this-week-on-wordpress-weekly-john-james-jacoby#comments">Submit your questions for JJJ</a> via a comment on WP Tavern, and be sure to tune into WordPress Weekly this Friday the 13th at 9pm&nbsp;EDT!</p>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11042 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-appearances category-happenings filters-and-folks-in-albuquerque">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/filters-and-folks-in-albuquerque/">Meet a few WordPress filters (and folks) in Albuquerque</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/drew-jaynes/" title="Posts by Drew Jaynes" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/b0da3360ff3e26e1e137b7144cca7aef?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/b0da3360ff3e26e1e137b7144cca7aef?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Drew Jaynes</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/filters-and-folks-in-albuquerque/" title="Meet a few WordPress filters (and folks) in Albuquerque"><time datetime="2013-09-11T20:21:58-04:00">September 11, 2013</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/filters-and-folks-in-albuquerque/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<p style="position: relative; color: red;"><div style="width:800px;height:275px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 275px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div><h1 style="position: absolute; font-weight: bold; z-index: 1000; top: 50%; left: 50%; color: rgb(255, 153, 0); text-align: center; transform: translate(-50%, -50%);">FAILED</h1></p>
<p><span style="line-height: 1.7em;">On Saturday morning, I’ll be presenting <a title="Drew Jaynes&#39; talk &#39;There&#39;s A Filter For That&#39;" href="http://2013.albuquerque.wordcamp.org/session/theres-an-api-for-that/"><strong>There’s a Filter for That</strong></a></span><span style="line-height: 1.7em;">, focusing on the ins and outs of the WordPress Filters API.&nbsp;</span>In this developer-focused talk, I’ll introduce some common (and uncommon) filters designed to spark discussion.</p>
<p><span style="line-height: 1.7em;">The timing of this talk is exciting for me, in part due to my heavy involvement in the inline-docs initiative planned for WordPress 3.7. In this new and, frankly, huge undertaking, the team is&nbsp;attempting to document all actions and filters in WordPress core in the new <a title="WordPress Developer Resources" href="http://developer.wordpress.org/">WordPress Developer Resources</a>&nbsp;announced at WordCamp San Francisco this year.&nbsp;This talk also goes hand-in-hand with the <a title="Drew Jayne&#39;s Filters of the Day blog" href="http://fotd.werdswords.com/">Filters of the Day</a> blog series I started earlier this summer.</span></p>
<p>There are <a title="Tickets to WordCamp Albuquerque 2013" href="http://2013.albuquerque.wordcamp.org/tickets/">still a few tickets left</a>, so come out to the beautiful Duke City this weekend and catch me and my fellow community members at WordCamp Albuquerque!</p>
</div>
</article>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-10968 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized wordcamp-san-francisco-wordpress-tv">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordcamp-san-francisco-wordpress-tv/">Grab a Snack and Catch Up on WordCamp San Francisco on WordPress.tv</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/elizabeth-hillis/" title="Posts by Elizabeth Hillis" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Elizabeth-Hillis_avatar-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2013/03/Elizabeth-Hillis_avatar-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Elizabeth Hillis</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordcamp-san-francisco-wordpress-tv/" title="Grab a Snack and Catch Up on WordCamp San Francisco on WordPress.tv"><time datetime="2013-08-22T21:46:56-04:00">August 22, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p>About one month ago, the 8th annual <a title="WordCamp San Francisco 2013" href="http://2013.sf.wordcamp.org/">WordCamp San Francisco</a>&nbsp;brought&nbsp;WordPress fans from all over the world together for two days of talks and a Contributor Day, one of the largest single gatherings of WordPress volunteers ever. 10up was proud to feature four team members as presenters this year – more than any company, with the exception of <a href="http://automattic.com/">Automattic</a>. Several other team members came along for the ride, hailing from places like Chicago, Colorado, Washington, and Virginia. Web Engineer Aaron Holbrook even joined the conference volunteer crew!</p>
<p style="position: relative; color: red;"><div style="width:800px;height:571px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 571px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div><h1 style="position: absolute; font-weight: bold; z-index: 1000; top: 50%; left: 50%; color: rgb(255, 153, 0); text-align: center; transform: translate(-50%, -50%);">FAILED</h1></p>
<p>If you were unable to attend – or if you attended, but missed a session – have no fear: thanks to WordPress.tv, you can watch any of the <a title="WordPress TV WordCamp San Francisco 2013" href="http://wordpress.tv/event/wordcamp-san-francisco-2013/">25+ talks</a> from the comfort of your office or living room. One of the lesser-known community resources for staying in the loop and learning new skills, WordPress.tv features hundreds of high-quality videos, including recorded WordCamp talks from across the globe. Most WordCamp talks are posted within a few weeks following a camp, so while you miss out on the community aspects of a WordCamp, you can still get the knowledge and put faces to names. <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordcamp-san-francisco-wordpress-tv/#more-10968" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Grab a Snack and Catch Up on WordCamp San Francisco on WordPress.tv</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-10976 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized wordcamp-birmingham-yall">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordcamp-birmingham-yall/">10up at WordCamp Birmingham, Y’all</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/" title="Posts by " rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo avatar-default" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> </a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordcamp-birmingham-yall/" title="10up at WordCamp Birmingham, Y’all"><time datetime="2013-08-22T16:01:23-04:00">August 22, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p style="position: relative; color: red;"><div style="width:341px;height:188px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:341px 188px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div><h1 style="position: absolute; font-weight: bold; z-index: 1000; top: 50%; left: 50%; color: rgb(255, 153, 0); text-align: center; transform: translate(-50%, -50%);">FAILED</h1></p>
<p>On Saturday, Design Engineer Daniel Immke is presenting&nbsp;<a title="WordPress and the Command Line" href="http://2013.birmingham.wordcamp.org/session/wordpress-and-the-command-line/">WordPress and the Command Line</a>, a talk for theme developers hesitant to go anywhere near the terminal in support of their development process. My talk, <a title="Responsify: 5 Things you should Know about Responsive Web Design" href="http://2013.birmingham.wordcamp.org/session/responsify-5-things-you-should-know-about-responsive-web-design/">5 Things you should know about Responsive Web Design</a>, covers strategies for building fluid layouts using techniques like media queries and JavaScript that make for a great experience across every device and screen size.</p>
<p>On Sunday, Senior Strategic Engineer Taylor Lovett Brings his popular&nbsp;<a title="What You Missed in Computer Science" href="http://2013.birmingham.wordcamp.org/session/what-you-missed-in-computer-science/">What you Missed in Computer Science</a>&nbsp;talk to the south, sharing computer science theories that make sites better and faster.</p>
<p>Daniel and I will also be volunteering at the Happiness Bar, so please be sure to stop by with your questions or just to say a quick hello. Hope to see you at WC Y’all!</p>
</div>
</article>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-11777 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized wordcamp-providence-vancouver-2">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordcamp-providence-vancouver-2/">Coast to Coast WordCamps: Providence &amp; Vancouver</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/luke/" title="Posts by Luke Gedeon" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Luke_avatar-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2012/02/Luke_avatar-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Luke Gedeon</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordcamp-providence-vancouver-2/" title="Coast to Coast WordCamps: Providence &amp; Vancouver"><time datetime="2013-08-15T21:09:38-04:00">August 15, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p>This weekend, 10up is sponsoring WordCamps on both North American coasts, as&nbsp;<a title="WordCamp Providence 2013" href="http://2013.providence.wordcamp.org/">WordCamp Providence</a> and <a title="WordCamp Vancouver 2013" href="http://2013.vancouver.wordcamp.org/">WordCamp Vancouver</a>&nbsp;host their annual conference. 10uppers are also busy preparing to play their part at both camps.</p>
<p>As an organizer for WordCamp Providence – an outgrowth of my organizer role at our <a href="http://www.meetup.com/WordPressProvidence/">local meet up</a> –&nbsp;I have the honor of delivering opening remarks for Friday’s sessions and closing remarks for the entire camp on Saturday. Providence is close to our team’s heart.&nbsp;Our President started the meet up here back in 2010, and lived here for over 10 years.&nbsp;John Jacoby, our new Director of Web Engineering, lived in the city for two years, from late 2010 to early 2013, and helped organize last year’s WordCamp.&nbsp;Jess Jurick, Director of Web Strategy, started her career at 10up while living here.&nbsp;We couldn’t help but step up with a top-level, Anchor Sponsorship. The camp has a great line up, including a number of 10uppers.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordcamp-providence-vancouver-2/#more-11777" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Coast to Coast WordCamps: Providence &amp; Vancouver</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>

<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/portland-open-house/">10up Portland Open&nbsp;House</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/taylor/" title="Posts by Taylor Dewey" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TDewey-600x600-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2016/11/TDewey-600x600-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Dewey</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/portland-open-house/" title="10up Portland Open House"><time datetime="2013-08-07T15:56:35-04:00">August 7, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p>Hey again, PDX! As you may know from our <a title="10up Portland Office Opens" href="https://10up.com/blog/portland-office-opening/">blog</a>&nbsp;or some <a href="http://www.geekwire.com/2013/wordpress-gurus-10up-open-shop-portland/">local publications</a>, 10up opened its first brick &amp; mortar office in Portland, Oregon. &nbsp;On the eve of <a href="http://2013.portland.wordcamp.org/">WordCamp Portland 2013</a> – which we’re proud to&nbsp;sponsor – we’ll have a handful of 10uppers from out-of-town joining our 7 full-time local contingent. We think this is the perfect occasion for a grand opening, and we’d like to <a href="http://www.eventbrite.com/event/7138604759">invite you to join us</a>!</p>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-10517 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized 10up-wordcamp-san-francisco">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/10up-wordcamp-san-francisco/">10up at WordCamp San Francisco 2013</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/10up-wordcamp-san-francisco/" title="10up at WordCamp San Francisco 2013"><time datetime="2013-07-23T19:59:23-04:00">July 23, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p><a title="WordCamp San Francisco 2013" href="http://2013.sf.wordcamp.org/">WordCamp San Francisco</a> was the first ever WordCamp, organized by WordPress co-founder <a title="Matt Mullenweg" href="http://ma.tt/">Matt Mullenweg</a> back in 2006. It has since grown into one of the largest WordCamps in the United States, and is considered WordPress’s canonical annual community event. I’m excited to reveal that we’ll have eight 10uppers in attendance, four of whom will be presenting.</p>
<p style="position: relative; color: red;"><div style="width:800px;height:161px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 161px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div><h1 style="position: absolute; font-weight: bold; z-index: 1000; top: 50%; left: 50%; color: rgb(255, 153, 0); text-align: center; transform: translate(-50%, -50%);">FAILED</h1></p>
<p>One of our newest employees, <a href="https://10up.com/blog/grant-landram-joins-10up/">Grant Landram</a>, will be attending WordCamp San Francisco for the first time. Grant is excited to experience the WordCamp that started this international phenomena and meet WordCampers from around the world. As a WordCamp organizer in Seattle, he’s eager to learn from the organizing team and bring that knowledge back home.&nbsp;Grant’s presentation explores collaboration with <a title="Bridging the Chasm: Working with Non Technical Stakeholders" href="http://2013.sf.wordcamp.org/session/bridging-the-chasm-working-with-non-technical-stakeholders/">non-technical stakeholders</a>, and offers an anecdotal overview of the pitfalls technical personnel may encounter when working with non-technical stakeholders. He’ll cover techniques for identifying and understanding a stakeholders’ true knowledge, and actions that help non-technical participants follow technical conversations. Grant is also volunteering at the Happiness Bar on Friday, so stop by to chat with him if you’re going!</p>
<p><a href="https://10up.com/blog/eric-mann-joins-10up/">Eric Mann</a> will also be attending WordCamp San Francisco for the first time, and is eager to connect with online collaborators he’s engaged on Twitter and IRC.&nbsp;Eric will be giving a short talk on Saturday morning, highlighting ways developers can <a title="Automated WordPress Development" href="http://2013.sf.wordcamp.org/session/automated-wordpress-development/">automate their coding process</a> using Grunt. Like his presentation in Seattle earlier this year, this version will focus on the goals of automation and practical tools, along with a live demo. At 10up, we’ve built two fantastic tools that leverage Grunt for WordPress development: a template that builds the foundation for a new plugin and one that builds the foundation for a new theme.&nbsp;Eric also built out a template that <a href="https://github.com/ericmann/grunt-wp-underscores">builds a new theme based on Automattic’s _s (Underscores) starter theme</a>. Attendees will walk out with access to plenty of tools to kick-start, simplify, and improve their development processes.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/10up-wordcamp-san-francisco/#more-10517" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on 10up at WordCamp San Francisco 2013</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-10559 type-post status-publish format-image has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized post_format-post-format-image jason-clarke-joins-10up">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content" style="position: relative; color: red;"><div style="width:800px;height:800px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 800px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div><h1 style="position: absolute; font-weight: bold; z-index: 1000; top: 50%; left: 50%; color: rgb(255, 153, 0); text-align: center; transform: translate(-50%, -50%);">FAILED</h1></div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-11775 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized jsconf-nodbots-yayquery-2">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/jsconf-nodbots-yayquery-2/">JSConf: JavaScript, NodeBots &amp; yayQuery</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/" title="Posts by " rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo avatar-default" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> </a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/jsconf-nodbots-yayquery-2/" title="JSConf: JavaScript, NodeBots &amp; yayQuery"><time datetime="2013-07-16T16:55:50-04:00">July 16, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p>Back in June, I attended <a title="JSConf Blog" href="https://10up.com/blog/10up.com/blog/jsconf-2013/">JSConf</a>, a three-day JavaScript Conference, where I participated in the Yammer and SpringSource track. JSConf is one of the best JavaScript conferences in the world; every talk was enlightening, every speaker was inspiring, and all the content was exceptional. I can’t even choose a favorite speaker!</p>
<p style="position: relative; color: red;"><div style="width:800px;height:487px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 487px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div><h1 style="position: absolute; font-weight: bold; z-index: 1000; top: 50%; left: 50%; color: rgb(255, 153, 0); text-align: center; transform: translate(-50%, -50%);">FAILED</h1></p>
<p>The highlight of the event was the Bitovi NodeBots event on the second day. The event kicked off at 9:00 AM with an introductory course in <a href="http://nodebots.io/">NodeBots</a> and how they can help us. Rick Waldron provided examples and connected us to the <a title="Johnny-Five Library" href="https://github.com/rwldrn/johnny-five">Johnny-Five Library</a> to get us started.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/jsconf-nodbots-yayquery-2/#more-11775" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on JSConf: JavaScript, NodeBots &amp; yayQuery</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-10041 type-post status-publish format-image has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized post_format-post-format-image grant-landram-joins-10up">

<article class="blog-archive-post post-9060 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized jquery-conference-portland">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/jquery-conference-portland/">Inspiration at jQuery Conference Portland</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-eric-mann" title="Posts by Eric Mann" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/EMann-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/EMann-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Eric Mann</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/jquery-conference-portland/" title="Inspiration at jQuery Conference Portland"><time datetime="2013-06-19T12:58:09-04:00">June 19, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p>Last week, Jeremy Felt, Carl Danley, and I attended <a title="jQuery Conference Portland 2013" href="http://events.jquery.org/2013/portland/">jQuery Conference Portland 2013</a>. The Conference was a great chance to connect with and listen to web professionals experienced with <a title="jQuery" href="http://jquery.com/">jQuery</a>.</p>
<p style="position: relative; color: red;"><div style="width:600px;height:349px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:600px 349px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div><h1 style="position: absolute; font-weight: bold; z-index: 1000; top: 50%; left: 50%; color: rgb(255, 153, 0); text-align: center; transform: translate(-50%, -50%);">FAILED</h1></p>
<p>From keynotes explaining the jQuery server infrastructure – an elegant use of Github and Grunt.js enabling websites to commit using pull requests – to speakers like Patrick Camacho, who detailed Twitter’s use of <a href="http://backbonejs.org/">Backbone</a> for <a href="http://crashlytics.com/">Crashlytics</a>&nbsp;(Carl’s conversation with Patrick about Backbone design patterns was his highlight),&nbsp;every speaker offered well-informed, broad, and &nbsp;fascinating content.&nbsp;In addition to solid presentations consistently interlaced with humor, participants had the chance to pick speakers’ brains.</p>
<p>I had the opportunity to speak before my largest audience on the importance of Unit Testing in a presentation I titled “Minutes Now Will Save Hours Later.”&nbsp;In contrast to presentations I’ve offered at other conferences, I’m&nbsp;<em>still</em>&nbsp;getting questions nearly one week later.&nbsp; It’s wonderful to have such an interested, interactive, and enthused crowd!<br>
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/jquery-conference-portland/#more-9060" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Inspiration at jQuery Conference Portland</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-9230 type-post status-publish format-aside has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized post_format-post-format-aside wordpress-documentation-sprint">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content" style="position: relative; color: red;"><div style="width:800px;height:507px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 507px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div><h1 style="position: absolute; font-weight: bold; z-index: 1000; top: 50%; left: 50%; color: rgb(255, 153, 0); text-align: center; transform: translate(-50%, -50%);">FAILED</h1></div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8787 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-uncategorized ads-jetpack-carousel">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/ads-jetpack-carousel/">Injecting Ads into the Jetpack Carousel</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/tanner/" title="Posts by Tanner Moushey" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Tanner_avatar-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2013/02/Tanner_avatar-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Tanner Moushey</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/ads-jetpack-carousel/" title="Injecting Ads into the Jetpack Carousel"><time datetime="2013-06-15T19:12:12-04:00">June 15, 2013</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/ads-jetpack-carousel/#comments" class="comments-count">3 Comments</a>
</p>
<blockquote><p><strong><em>This is really neat!</em></strong></p></blockquote>
<p>Kind words from <a href="http://vip.wordpress.com/">WordPress.com VIP</a>‘s rock star team after deploying <a href="https://github.com/10up/jetpack-carousel-ads">our new ad integration extension</a> to <a href="http://jetpack.me/2012/07/13/jetpack-1-5-with-carousel/">Jetpack’s Carousel</a>.&nbsp;Built for <a href="http://9to5mac.com/">9to5mac.com</a>, this extension&nbsp;appends a custom image to the full screen carousel modal. We’re excited to share it with the WordPress community, along with a few cautions and insights.</p>
<h2>Rules are rules: no AdSense</h2>
<p>If you were hoping to inject AdSense ads, we’re sorry to disappoint: <a title="http://support.google.com/adsense/bin/answer.py?hl=en&amp;answer=48182 " href="http://support.google.com/adsense/bin/answer.py?hl=en&amp;answer=48182">AdSense policies</a> clearly stipulate that an ad may not be “Displayed in pop-ups or pop-unders.” You may, of course, be able to leverage our approach for other, more forgiving ad networks. We envision the typical use case will involve an internal “house” ad image.</p>
<h2>Hooking into Jetpack with JavaScript</h2>
<p>Because the modal Jetpack Carousel is generated entirely by JavaScript, classic WordPress PHP API hooks do not apply. Fortunately, JetPack provides 2 JavaScript hooks: <code>jp_carousel.afterOpen</code> and <code>jp_carousel.beforeClose</code>. We hooked into afterOpen – which fires every time the carousel is generated – on <a href="https://github.com/10up/jetpack-carousel-ads/blob/master/js/carousel-ads.js#L14">line 14 of carousel-ads.js</a>:</p>
<pre class="brush: js">$( document.body ).on( 'jp_carousel.afterOpen', SELF.insertAd );</pre>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/ads-jetpack-carousel/#more-8787" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Injecting Ads into the Jetpack Carousel</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-9075 type-post status-publish format-image has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized post_format-post-format-image aaron-holbrook-joins-10up">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content" style="position: relative; color: red;"><div style="width:800px;height:650px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 650px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div><h1 style="position: absolute; font-weight: bold; z-index: 1000; top: 50%; left: 50%; color: rgb(255, 153, 0); text-align: center; transform: translate(-50%, -50%);">FAILED</h1></div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8813 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry grunt-for-wordpress">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/grunt-for-wordpress/">Introducing Grunt for&nbsp;WordPress</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-eric-mann" title="Posts by Eric Mann" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/EMann-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/EMann-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Eric Mann</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/grunt-for-wordpress/" title="Introducing Grunt for WordPress"><time datetime="2013-06-08T10:48:52-04:00">June 8, 2013</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/grunt-for-wordpress/#comments" class="comments-count">7 Comments</a>
</p>
<p>Since I’m always looking for ways to improve my productivity, I constantly strive to streamline my development workflow. Lately, that meant adding <a title="Grunt" href="http://gruntjs.com/">Grunt</a> to the mix.</p>
<p>Grunt is a scripting tool that helps automate certain development tasks using JavaScript. &nbsp;It runs on top of <a title="Node JS" href="http://nodejs.org/">Node</a> in your local environment, and can handle just about any task you can imagine – from <a title="grunt-contrib-jshint" href="https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt-contrib-jshint">linting</a> your scripts to <a title="grunt-contrib-cssmin" href="https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt-contrib-cssmin">minfying</a> your stylesheets to running <a title="grunt-contrib-qunit" href="https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt-contrib-qunit">unit tests</a>.&nbsp;A few months ago, at <a title="Coming to Portland: 10up’s First Internal Developer Summit" href="https://10up.com/blog/10up-2013-developer-summit/">our first summit</a>,&nbsp; our entire team had the chance to play with Grunt. As a result, most of us are&nbsp;incorporating&nbsp;it into our regular workflow.</p>
<p>To make it easier to use Grunt with new &nbsp;WordPress projects, we’ve created two project templates: <a title="grunt-wp-plugin" href="https://github.com/10up/grunt-wp-plugin">grunt-wp-plugin</a> and <a title="grunt-wp-theme" href="https://github.com/10up/grunt-wp-theme">grunt-wp-theme</a>. &nbsp;These templates make it easy to kickstart development of a new WordPress plugin or theme by building out the directory structure and project’s core files for you.</p>
<p>If you’re building a plugin, you will start out with the core plugin file, the basic WordPress.org readme standard, and a basic directory structure for all of your PHP, CSS, JS, and image assets. &nbsp;The template also configures your plugin textdomain and registers a few useful constants and core functions. &nbsp;Here’s an example of grunt-wp-plugin in action:</p>
<p style="position: relative; color: red;"><div style="width:650px;height:390px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:650px 390px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div><h1 style="position: absolute; font-weight: bold; z-index: 1000; top: 50%; left: 50%; color: rgb(255, 153, 0); text-align: center; transform: translate(-50%, -50%);">FAILED</h1></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/grunt-for-wordpress/#more-8813" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Introducing Grunt for&nbsp;WordPress</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8806 type-post status-publish format-aside has-post-thumbnail hentry post_format-post-format-aside 10up-on-money-2-0">

<article class="blog-archive-post post-8730 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized 10up-hacks-white-house">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/10up-hacks-white-house/">WP the People: 10up Hacks the White&nbsp;House</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/" title="Posts by " rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo avatar-default" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> </a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/10up-hacks-white-house/" title="WP the People: 10up Hacks the White House"><time datetime="2013-06-06T23:46:55-04:00">June 6, 2013</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/10up-hacks-white-house/#comments" class="comments-count">2 Comments</a>
</p>
<p dir="ltr">Back in February, we applied&nbsp;to&nbsp;<a title="We the People" href="https://petitions.whitehouse.gov/">We the People</a>‘s second ever White House Hackathon. The event is an open-ended civic hack day where developers of all stripes from across the United States are invited to create applications in languages like Python and JavaScript. The purpose of the event was to create resources for websites, smartphones and other platforms that build on&nbsp;<a href="https://petitions.whitehouse.gov/">We the People</a>. As a Senior Web Engineer, I had the&nbsp;privilege of&nbsp;representing WordPress at the White House, alongside fellow 10upper Christopher Cochran and&nbsp;<a title="Automattic" href="http://automattic.com/">Automattic</a>‘s&nbsp;Mo Jangda. Given just how small and selective the event was, we were deeply honored to be accepted and participate.</p>
<p style="position: relative; color: red;"><div style="width:600px;height:324px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:600px 324px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div><h1 style="position: absolute; font-weight: bold; z-index: 1000; top: 50%; left: 50%; color: rgb(255, 153, 0); text-align: center; transform: translate(-50%, -50%);">FAILED</h1></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8754 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry wordpress-com-vip-intensive-developer-workshop">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordpress-com-vip-intensive-developer-workshop/">Inspiration &amp; Education: WordPress.com VIP’s Intensive Developer Workshop</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-thorsten-ott" title="Posts by Thorsten Ott" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TOtt-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/TOtt-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Thorsten Ott</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordpress-com-vip-intensive-developer-workshop/" title="Inspiration &amp; Education: WordPress.com VIP’s Intensive Developer Workshop"><time datetime="2013-06-04T20:36:30-04:00">June 4, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p>As a <a title="WordPress VIP Hosting" href="http://vip.wordpress.com/">WordPress.com VIP</a> featured partner, 10up was invited to participate in this year’s&nbsp;<a title="WordPress.com VIP Intensive Developer Workshop page" href="http://vip.wordpress.com/vip-workshop-2013/">VIP Intensive Developer Workshop</a>&nbsp;in Napa, California. I had the pleasure of representing 10up at the event (although our Director of Strategic Engineering managed to make a cameo appearance, too). Hosted at the amazing <a title="The Caneros Inn and Resort Website" href="http://www.thecarnerosinn.com/">Carneros Inn and Resort</a>, surrounded by vineyards, a group of roughly 50 VIP developers and 20 Automatticians spent two and a half days digging deep into the WordPress.com VIP platform.</p>
<p>After arriving on Monday, May 13th, the event kicked off with a meet and greet, where I had the chance to chat with representatives from media outlets like the New York Times, the Washington Post, and Penske Media Corporation, in addition to Automatticians I’d only collaborated with online. The meals we shared all week long were delicious, matched only by the stimulating conversations and the content to come.</p>
<p style="position: relative; color: red;"><div style="width:800px;height:412px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 412px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div><h1 style="position: absolute; font-weight: bold; z-index: 1000; top: 50%; left: 50%; color: rgb(255, 153, 0); text-align: center; transform: translate(-50%, -50%);">FAILED</h1></p>
</div>
</article>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-8677 type-post status-publish format-video has-post-thumbnail hentry post_format-post-format-video publishing-workflows-wordpress">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/publishing-workflows-wordpress/">Publishing Workflows for WordPress &amp; CMS Expo&nbsp;2013</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/publishing-workflows-wordpress/" title="Publishing Workflows for WordPress &amp; CMS Expo 2013"><time datetime="2013-05-21T17:40:00-04:00">May 21, 2013</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/publishing-workflows-wordpress/#comments" class="comments-count">3 Comments</a>
</p>
<div class="blog-video-wrap"><div class="blog-video-screen"><div class="fluid-width-video-wrapper" style="position: relative; width: 100%; padding-top: 75.0769%;"><iframe loading="lazy" width="650" height="488" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/jstkU6WTMqg.html" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen="" style="position: absolute; width: 100%; height: 100%; left: 0px; top: 0px;"></iframe></div></div><div class="blog-video-bottom"></div></div><p>Last week, I had the opportunity <a href="https://10up.com/blog/speaking-cms-expo-wordpress/">to participate in CMS Expo 2013, </a>where I&nbsp;presented&nbsp;<em>Publishing Workflows for WordPress</em>. The final talk is broken down into three major sections: (1)&nbsp;<span style="line-height: 1.7em;">a review of inherent WordPress workflow, including some improvements coming with 3.6, (2) a</span><span style="line-height: 1.7em;">&nbsp;look at plug-ins that enrich its native workflow, from full featured editorial plug-ins like </span><a style="line-height: 1.7em;" href="http://editflow.org/">Edit Flow</a><span style="line-height: 1.7em;">, to narrow, helpful tools like </span><a style="line-height: 1.7em;" href="http://wordpress.org/plugins/ice/">Ice Visual Revisions</a>, and (3) i<span style="line-height: 1.7em;">nspiring case studies that illustrate just how far WordPress workflow and curation can be extended in the hands of a strong engineering and user experience team.</span></p>
<p>I’ve published the slides to YouTube, since a large portion of the presentation includes screen recordings, demoing some built in features, plug-ins, and showcases. I want to thank the awesome, engaged audience, which ranged from fellow WordPress professionals to novices who have never even opened the software.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/publishing-workflows-wordpress/#more-8677" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Publishing Workflows for WordPress &amp; CMS Expo&nbsp;2013</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8515 type-post status-publish format-aside has-post-thumbnail hentry post_format-post-format-aside sponsoring-speaking-wordcamp-seattle">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content"><div style="width:800px;height:559px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 559px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8635 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry top-100-blogs">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/top-100-blogs/">10up in the Top&nbsp;100</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/elizabeth-hillis/" title="Posts by Elizabeth Hillis" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Elizabeth-Hillis_avatar-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2013/03/Elizabeth-Hillis_avatar-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Elizabeth Hillis</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/top-100-blogs/" title="10up in the Top 100"><time datetime="2013-05-15T01:34:10-04:00">May 15, 2013</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/top-100-blogs/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<p>Last week, Royal Pingdom released their <a href="http://royal.pingdom.com/2013/05/07/wordpress-top-100-blogs/">annual analysis of the top 100 blogs</a>, based on <a title="Technorati Authority" href="http://technorati.com/what-is-technorati-authority">site linking behavior and categorization over a 6 month time frame</a>&nbsp;as collected by Technorati (a debatable, but reasonable metric). Royal Pingdom has pointed out that 52% of the sites are built on WordPress. Comparing this list to last year’s list, we see that WordPress’s dominance as a publishing platform rose from 48% to 52%. At the same time, competing publishing formats like Drupal and MoveableType have dropped or remained constant.</p>
<p>The news for 10up is even better: we’ve provided direct service for 8 of the blogs on the list. <a title="TechCrunch Showcase" href="https://10up.com/showcase/techcrunch/">TechCrunch</a> moved up into the top five. <a title="9to5mac Showcase" href="https://10up.com/showcase/9to5mac/">9to5mac</a> moved up two spaces from #33 to #31. <a title="Deadline.com" href="https://10up.com/blog/www.deadline.com/">Deadline</a> maintained its place on the list at #26. Two of our clients made the list for the first time: &nbsp;<a title="Consumerist.com" href="http://consumerist.com/">Consumerist</a> at #90 and <a title="hip2save Showcase" href="https://10up.com/showcase/hip2save-today/">hip2save.com</a> at #98. Three other blogs enlisted our web strategy services.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><div style="width:750px;height:250px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:750px 250px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p>With more than a dozen core <a title="WordPress Core" href="http://make.wordpress.org/core/">WordPress contributors</a> on our team, including a guest core committer, we’ve actually written code running on each of the other 44 WordPress-backed blogs. Add in our modest&nbsp;<a href="https://10up.com/blog/jquery-developer-summit-2012/">jQuery core contributions</a>, and we’ve made some small contribution to every site on the list!</p>
<p>We’d like to congratulate everyone who made the list! You can find the WordPress statistics at <a title="Royal Pingdom WordPress Top 100" href="http://royal.pingdom.com/2013/05/07/wordpress-top-100-blogs/">Royal Pingdom</a> and the original list over at <a title="Technorati Top 100" href="http://technorati.com/blogs/top100/">Technorati</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>

<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/speaking-cms-expo-wordpress/">Talking WordPress at CMS Expo this&nbsp;week</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/speaking-cms-expo-wordpress/" title="Talking WordPress at CMS Expo this week"><time datetime="2013-05-12T17:42:01-04:00">May 12, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p>This coming week I’ll be participating in and speaking at the annual <a href="http://www.cmsexpo.net/">CMS Expo</a>&nbsp;in Chicago. CMS Expo educates and informs business leaders, content marketers, website implementors, and other professionals looking for an in-depth review of the latest web-based publishing solutions. With three full days of content and more than 50 speakers, CMS Expo covers a cross-section of popular content management systems, including Drupal, Joomla, MODx, and of our favorite, WordPress. I’ll be one of four speakers offering insight and content focused on WordPress.</p>
<p><div style="width:800px;height:271px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 271px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p>Assuming planes run on time, I’ll be there on Monday evening for the <a href="http://www.cmsexpo.net/schedule/special-events/123-meetup-monday-night">Welcome Kickoff Meetup</a> at the&nbsp;Orrington Conference Center, where I’ll look forward to joining lead WordPress developer <a href="http://www.cmsexpo.net/schedule/special-events/9-uncategorised/230-meetup-monday-night-wordpress">Andrew Nacin’s WordPress breakout meetup</a>.</p>
<p>The conference fully kicks off on Tuesday, May 14, where I’ll be presenting <a href="http://www.cmsexpo.net/sessions/2-264-Publishing_Workflows_for_WordPress"><em>Publishing Workflows for WordPress</em></a> at 4:30 pm CST.&nbsp; On the heels of a session reviewing WordPress’s CMS chops, I’ll dive into scenarios where light weight, out-of-the-box WordPress just doesn’t cut it. Here’s my session description:</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/speaking-cms-expo-wordpress/#more-8629" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Talking WordPress at CMS Expo this&nbsp;week</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8500 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry watch-those-hook-priorities">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/watch-those-hook-priorities/">Watch those hook priorities</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/taylor/" title="Posts by Taylor Dewey" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TDewey-600x600-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2016/11/TDewey-600x600-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Dewey</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/watch-those-hook-priorities/" title="Watch those hook priorities"><time datetime="2013-05-10T02:10:14-04:00">May 10, 2013</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/watch-those-hook-priorities/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<p>When adding an action or a filter to WordPress, the third parameter allows you to adjust priority. In this way, multiple bits of code can determine the order that they should execute without having to rely on the order that PHP actually parses them.</p>
<p>Generally, there are no minimums or maximum limits (other than those imposed by PHP itself) for priority, but there’s a very good reason to give consideration to when your code runs. Here’s an example:</p>
<p>Widget registration should be hooked to ‘widgets_init’ as in the following code:<br>
<code></code></p>
<pre>function mytheme_register_widgets() {
register_widget( 'Mytheme_Widget' );
}
add_action( 'widgets_init', 'mytheme_register_widgets' );</pre>
<p>This is also the hook used internally by WordPress to take all the registered widgets and create a global array, <code>$wp_registered_widgets</code>. Specifically, this is in the WP_Widget_Factory class’s constructor function which is called once in wp-settings.php, immediately before the ‘setup_theme’ action hook.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/watch-those-hook-priorities/#more-8500" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Watch those hook priorities</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8612 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry portland-office-opening">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/portland-office-opening/">10up opens up an office in&nbsp;Portland</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/jeremy/" title="Posts by Jeremy Felt" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jeremy_avatar-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2012/02/Jeremy_avatar-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jeremy Felt</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/portland-office-opening/" title="10up opens up an office in Portland"><time datetime="2013-05-07T16:47:41-04:00">May 7, 2013</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/portland-office-opening/#comments" class="comments-count">4 Comments</a>
</p>
<p><strong>We’re proud to formally announce the opening of our first office in Portland, Oregon this month.&nbsp;</strong>Portland has an incredible online media community, second only to mega-metropolises like New York City and San Francisco, without the high cost of living.&nbsp;As a <a href="http://scottberkun.com/2013/how-many-companies-are-100-distributed/">distributed company</a>, we find the best strategy, creative, WordPress engineering, and systems talent from across the United States. As it turns out, 5 of our 25 full-time employees live in the Portland metro area, with two more living just a three hour drive (or train ride!) away in greater Seattle.</p>
<p><div style="width:800px;height:424px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 424px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p>In short, this expanding, thriving technology community is the perfect atmosphere for 10up to begin growing its distributed roots into brick and mortar hubs.</p>
<p>Our Portland team is excited to have a local hub, and anticipate working out of our office for more than half of their working hours. Other 10uppers from across the country have already expressed an eagerness to visit the office throughout the year.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/portland-office-opening/#more-8612" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on 10up opens up an office in&nbsp;Portland</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8580 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry convergese-2013-review">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/convergese-2013-review/">Report from ConvergeSE 2013</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/" title="Posts by " rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo avatar-default" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> </a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/convergese-2013-review/" title="Report from ConvergeSE 2013"><time datetime="2013-05-05T21:32:56-04:00">May 5, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p>This past week I had the pleasure of attending <a href="http://convergese.com/">ConvergeSE</a>, a three-day web conference held annually in Columbia, South Carolina. Over 400 participants gathered to discuss and explore up-and-coming trends, technologies, and disciplines in web design and development. Speakers ranged from presidents of agencies, to Google employees, to house hold names in the design community. &nbsp;It was intense content in a laid back atmosphere, between venue hopping in downtown Columbia, food carts lunches, and an art museum party. The event was hugely successful, and it’s easy to tell why just by looking at their <a href="http://convergese.com/speakers.php">speaker roster</a> and the <a href="http://convergese.com/schedule.php">schedule of activities</a>.</p>
<h2>Build Responsively</h2>
<p><div style="width:800px;height:275px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 275px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p>The highlight was Mr. Callahan’s application of a preprocessor called&nbsp;<a href="http://sass-lang.com/">SASS</a>,&nbsp;which he uses to generate a single CSS file (improving performance)&nbsp;for visitors using older versions of Internet Explorer or modern browsers. Combing imports, a <a href="https://github.com/sparkbox/SB-Media">custom mix-in</a>&nbsp;(written by his company), and some conditional tags, his approach generates a&nbsp;stylesheet with efficient, modern techniques like <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_queries">media queries</a>&nbsp;served to modern browsers, and another stylesheet optimized&nbsp;for older browsers.</p>
<p>Ben wrapped up by reviewing design patterns arising as responsive web design gains popularity. It is truly amazing to watch the web mature as we transition from a desktop-centric experience to an increasingly mobile-centric audience.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/convergese-2013-review/#more-8580" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Report from ConvergeSE 2013</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8569 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry code-with-me-portland">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/code-with-me-portland/">Code with me: Digital Journalism</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/taylor/" title="Posts by Taylor Dewey" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TDewey-600x600-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2016/11/TDewey-600x600-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Dewey</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/code-with-me-portland/" title="Code with me: Digital Journalism"><time datetime="2013-05-02T16:29:39-04:00">May 2, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p dir="ltr"><a title="Code with me: Portland" href="http://codewithme.us/portland/index.html">Code with me: Portland</a> is a two day, student-mentor workshop that teaches journalists the foundations of coding in languages like HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.&nbsp;Founded by Sisi Wei and Tom Giratikanon, Code with me has been successful in Washington DC and Miami, and Code with me: Portland promises to be the biggest workshop yet, with 36 student and 22 mentors! With about two students to every mentor, the classes are very personal and hands-on. Between learning how to code, the journalists use mentor time to help with personal projects.</p>
<p dir="ltr">Portland’s organizer, a former WordPress.com VIP support engineer, helped organize the workshop and invited Jeremy Felt and me to be mentors. The mentors are talented and diverse, ranging from <a title="team 10up" href="https://10up.com/about/">10uppers</a> and <a title="Automattic" href="http://automattic.com/">Automatticians</a>&nbsp;to designers, developers, and editors from newspapers like the <a title="Seattle Times" href="http://seattletimes.com/html/home/index.html">Seattle Times</a>.</p>
<p dir="ltr">The primary goal of <a title="Code with me" href="http://codewithme.us/">Code with me</a> is to help journalists understand code so that they can better integrate into their work. Many of the attendees were inspired after reading the New York Times’s “<a title="Snow Fall: The Avalance at Tunnel Creek" href="http://www.nytimes.com/projects/2012/snow-fall/#/?part=tunnel-creek">Snow Fall</a>”, a showcase for crafting and coding an online presentation around a single, great story. Snow Fall is a great example of how technology can enhance storytelling without restraining or complicating it.</p>
<p dir="ltr"> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/code-with-me-portland/#more-8569" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Code with me: Digital Journalism</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8526 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry global-news-10up">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/global-news-10up/">WordPress.com VIP, Global News talk redesign and&nbsp;10up</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/" title="Posts by " rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo avatar-default" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> </a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/global-news-10up/" title="WordPress.com VIP, Global News talk redesign and 10up"><time datetime="2013-04-27T17:23:46-04:00">April 27, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p>Less than one month ago, <a title="Global News" href="http://globalnews.ca/">Global News</a> released a brand new website, engineered by 10up and hosted on&nbsp;<a title="WordPress.com VIP" href="https://10up.com/blog/vip.wordpress.com/">WordPress.com VIP</a>.&nbsp;With features like content tailored automatically to the visitor’s geolocation, highly curated home pages, and beautiful responsive design, we couldn’t be more proud to have been part of the Global News redesign team. &nbsp;You can read more about our involvement by checking out our <a title="Global News redesign" href="https://10up.com/showcase/global-news/">extended case study</a>.</p>
<p>On Thursday, the <a href="http://vip.wordpress.com/blog/">WordPress.com VIP publisher blog</a>&nbsp;posted a <a title="Global News Q&amp;A: The Technology Behind Their Responsive Redesign" href="http://vip.wordpress.com/2013/04/25/global-news-qa/">Q&amp;A with Keith Robinson</a>, Manager of Digital Products at Global News, where he took some time to highlight some of our contributions:</p>
<blockquote><p>“10up helped us come up with a curation system that powers a lot of the site: the navigation, carousel, featured story, top story. It’s all one system that gives different choices.”</p>
<p>“We engaged with 10up in the fall to do the WordPress integration…we were very fortunate to hire some really top talent to work with us, and we’ve been working with really good partners.”</p>
<p>“10up brought a lot in terms of being able to listen to our needs and turn it into a functional site. They were great for us because we were at a stage where we needed things done very quickly and needed to discuss exactly what we were looking to do and how we were looking to do it–they helped us go from the discovery process to the implementation…we really benefited from the partnership and they were good to work with.”</p></blockquote>
<p>You can <a href="http://vip.wordpress.com/2013/04/25/global-news-qa/">read the full Q&amp;A here</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
