<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordsesh-10up-videos/">WordSesh Archives: Watch Team 10up&nbsp;Anytime!</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/chris-cochran/" title="Posts by Christopher Cochran" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Chris-Cochran_avatar-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2013/01/Chris-Cochran_avatar-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Christopher Cochran</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordsesh-10up-videos/" title="WordSesh Archives: Watch Team 10up Anytime!"><time datetime="2013-04-19T19:35:12-04:00">April 19, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p><a title="WordSesh 2013" href="http://wordsesh.org/">WordSesh 2013</a> may no longer be live, but you can keep learning by checking out the session recordings over on the WordSesh <a title="WordSesh YouTube" href="http://www.youtube.com/WordSesh/">YouTube</a> page!</p>
<p>If you missed it, WordSesh 2013 was the first ever free, live-streaming WordPress presentation venue. It ran uninterrupted for 24 hours on April 13th, 2013 (UTC), featuring a new session every hour on the hour. 10up was <a title="10up and WordSesh: Free WordPress Presentations" href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/04/wordsesh-free-wordpress-presentations/">excited to be a part of WordSesh</a>, with four presenters across three sessions!&nbsp;Now that the event is over, the organizers of WordSesh have archived all 24 hours worth of presentations. Each session has been separated into its own video, so you can browse <a title="WordSesh Videos" href="http://www.youtube.com/user/WordSesh/videos">their videos</a> by presentation title.</p>
<p>Go below the fold to check out videos from Jake’s <a title="Interview Cheat Sheet: 10 Questions I Ask Every Developer" href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gTI3USo7_kE">10 Questions I Ask Developers</a>, my (Christopher’s)&nbsp;<a title="Anywhere, Everywhere WordPress Themes. (An Adaptive Talk)" href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dOK8kP4Q8eQ">Anywhere , Everywhere WordPress Themes</a>, and Carl and Eric’s <a title="WordPress Javascript Hooks" href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oEF7EBjZ-kE">WordPress Javascript Hooks</a>.</p>
<p>That should keep you busy while we eagerly WordSesh II!</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordsesh-10up-videos/#more-8491" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on WordSesh Archives: Watch Team 10up&nbsp;Anytime!</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8446 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry developer-summit-summation">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/developer-summit-summation/">Summarizing the&nbsp;Summit</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/elizabeth-hillis/" title="Posts by Elizabeth Hillis" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Elizabeth-Hillis_avatar-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2013/03/Elizabeth-Hillis_avatar-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Elizabeth Hillis</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/developer-summit-summation/" title="Summarizing the Summit"><time datetime="2013-04-18T13:04:24-04:00">April 18, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p>The Developer Summit was a few weeks ago, but our team is still buzzing. I asked a few my teammates to share their main take away from our first ever <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/04/developer-summit-wrap-up/">Developer Summit</a>&nbsp;– here’s what they came back with:</p>
<p><strong>Jake Goldman:&nbsp;</strong>There were so many highlights: learning from the smartest minds I’ve ever worked with about unit testing, advanced JavaScript, and Vagrant… seeing a great group of Portland-area WordPress pros show up at our social… seeing a few members of our team in person for the first time. The real highlight was being able to sit back and watch the team brainstorm the big process and technique questions we confront, so effectively. It’s one thing to have great “online” chemistry in IRC chat rooms, small video conferences, and status blogs, but it was amazing to see just how much chemistry this team has when we get together in person – more than any brick and mortar group I’ve ever led or been a part of.</p>
<p><strong>Taylor Dewey:&nbsp;</strong>On the first day of our summit, only a few people had lunch together. On the second day of our summit, there were a few groups of folks in different spots. On the last day of our summit, everyone was eating lunch together in the same area. Seeing everyone come together organically proved that we actually do have a team, not a group of individuals, and that has tremendous value.</p>
<p><div style="width:800px;height:326px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 326px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8438 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry wordsesh-free-wordpress-presentations">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordsesh-free-wordpress-presentations/">10up and WordSesh: Free WordPress Presentations</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/elizabeth-hillis/" title="Posts by Elizabeth Hillis" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Elizabeth-Hillis_avatar-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2013/03/Elizabeth-Hillis_avatar-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Elizabeth Hillis</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordsesh-free-wordpress-presentations/" title="10up and WordSesh: Free WordPress Presentations"><time datetime="2013-04-12T12:46:06-04:00">April 12, 2013</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordsesh-free-wordpress-presentations/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<p>If you ever wanted to learn about WordPress, but never had a chance to attend a <a href="http://central.wordcamp.org/">WordCamp</a>, now there’s an amazing opportunity to attend WordCamp-style lectures from home! It’s called <a href="http://wordsesh.org/">WordSesh</a>, and we’re proud to be a big part of it.</p>
<p><div style="width:800px;height:214px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 214px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p>WordSesh 2013 is the first ever 24 hour free, live-streaming WordPress presentation venue. Starting at midnight UTC on April 13, 2013 (that’s 8:00 pm EST and 5:00 pm PST tonight, April 12) and running uninterrupted for 24 hours, WordSesh will feature a new session every hour, on the hour.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordsesh-free-wordpress-presentations/#more-8438" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on 10up and WordSesh: Free WordPress Presentations</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8430 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry documentation">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/documentation/">Documentation</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/taylor/" title="Posts by Taylor Dewey" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TDewey-600x600-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2016/11/TDewey-600x600-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Dewey</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/documentation/" title="Documentation"><time datetime="2013-04-12T01:15:56-04:00">April 12, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p>At our <a title="10up Developer Summit Wrap-Up" href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/04/developer-summit-wrap-up/">10up Developer Summit</a>, we collectively decided to document our workflow, tools, and process. With a handful of employees it’s easy to spread collective knowledge, but we’re growing fast and now have a need to document web technologies such as Vagrant, Git, and Grunt; who to contact and how to use our internal IRC channel; and how our staging servers are set up.</p>
<p>But who writes those docs, where do they go, and what should they look like?</p>
<p>Earlier this week I attended <a href="http://writethedocs.com/">Write The Docs</a>: a conference for technical writers that was created in the domain of software and web development.&nbsp;Many of the talks at this conference were devoted to who should write the docs. The consensus is that engineers compose technical documentation which is then edited by more experienced writers. Other presentations covered technical writing itself, careers, and documentation platforms.</p>
<p>Our code is well documented – and soon our internal processes will be too. Our engineers are already documentarians. The docs are being assembled in an internal WordPress-powered website and I’ve started the initial concept of a theme to make those docs easily readable and navigable.</p>
<p>If you’d like to help us write our docs, strategy, proposals, and emails, we are <a href="mailto:jobs@10up.com">hiring web strategists</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8407 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry developer-summit-wrap-up">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/developer-summit-wrap-up/">10up Developer Summit Wrap-Up</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/elizabeth-hillis/" title="Posts by Elizabeth Hillis" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Elizabeth-Hillis_avatar-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2013/03/Elizabeth-Hillis_avatar-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Elizabeth Hillis</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/developer-summit-wrap-up/" title="10up Developer Summit Wrap-Up"><time datetime="2013-04-08T20:24:07-04:00">April 8, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p>10up’s Developer Summit was an amazing experience. In addition to meeting one another in person (a first, for some of us), we were treated to fantastic workshops covering everything from WordPress&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unit_testing">unit testing</a>&nbsp;to simulating live environments in <a href="http://www.vagrantup.com/">Vagrant</a> to advanced JavaScript performance techniques. We’re lucky to have an incredibly smart and diverse staff, over half which contributed to the presentations. Jeremy Felt and Carl Danley, two of our amazing Web Engineers, organized the <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/04/preparing-for-developer-summit/">entire conference</a> and ensured that every member of our team would learn something new.</p>
<p><div style="width:800px;height:532px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 532px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/developer-summit-wrap-up/#more-8407" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on 10up Developer Summit Wrap-Up</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8394 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry preparing-for-developer-summit">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/preparing-for-developer-summit/">Preparing for Portland: 10up’s Developer Summit</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/elizabeth-hillis/" title="Posts by Elizabeth Hillis" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Elizabeth-Hillis_avatar-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2013/03/Elizabeth-Hillis_avatar-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Elizabeth Hillis</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/preparing-for-developer-summit/" title="Preparing for Portland: 10up’s Developer Summit"><time datetime="2013-04-02T18:09:21-04:00">April 2, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p dir="ltr">As the new Web Strategist here at 10up, I’m still getting to know the team. Naturally, I was very excited to learn that I would be attending our Developer Summit in Portland on my second week! To find out more, I sat down with Jeremy Felt and Carl Danley (over Skype) to find out just what the Summit is all about and how it came to be.</p>
<p dir="ltr"><div style="width:800px;height:286px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 286px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p dir="ltr"><strong>How many people are you expecting at the Summit?</strong><br>
<strong>Jermey Felt:</strong> [Almost] everybody from 10up. 22 people total.<br>
<em>Editor’s note:</em> Our Operations Manager, Pat, is holding down the back office in Sacramento during the Summit, and our Director of User Interface Engineering, Helen, just began her maternity leave.</p>
<p dir="ltr"><strong>There are many diverse jobs/responsibilities at 10up; how do you plan to cater to them all in one collective conference?</strong><br>
<strong>JF:</strong> Originally this was planned as just a Developer Summit, which is still the core focus, different web engineering technologies… [Director of Web Strategy] Jess Jurick proposed that we also have a mini project management conference, which she and [Senior Web Strategist] Megan Gray will handle somewhat separately… everyone will get a handle on the engineering concepts, and be involved in the lectures in some way… The workshop style will help us make sure nobody gets lost.<br>
<strong>Carl Danley:</strong> The focus is primarily on the attendees, not the presenters… we’ll be there supplementing what they hear and helping them master the techniques.</p>
<p dir="ltr"> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/preparing-for-developer-summit/#more-8394" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Preparing for Portland: 10up’s Developer Summit</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8387 type-post status-publish format-aside hentry post_format-post-format-aside hang-out-10up-portland">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content"><div style="width:800px;height:525px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 525px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8375 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry 10up-2013-developer-summit">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/10up-2013-developer-summit/">Coming to Portland: 10up’s First Internal Developer Summit</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/jeremy/" title="Posts by Jeremy Felt" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jeremy_avatar-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2012/02/Jeremy_avatar-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jeremy Felt</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/10up-2013-developer-summit/" title="Coming to Portland: 10up’s First Internal Developer Summit"><time datetime="2013-03-26T20:40:24-04:00">March 26, 2013</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/10up-2013-developer-summit/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<p>Excitement abounds at 10up as our team prepares to descend on Portland for 3 days for our first Developer Summit.&nbsp;We’ve finalized a fantastic schedule of topical workshops, where the team will focus on adapting and strengthening our collaborative project engineering practices.</p>
<p><div style="width:300px;height:200px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:300px 200px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p>Rather than adopting the speaker oriented structure of a standard conference, we’re breaking things down into multiple hour long workshops, in which a short presentation by a designated expert will be followed by hands on application by every engineer on the team. Each day, when we walk out of the door, we’ll have gained valuable experience that can be applied immediately to client projects.</p>
<p>We’re also excited to simply hang out as a team. This will be the second time we’ve gathered in whole and we have quite a bit planned – including a 10up community social! (Details to come)</p>
<p>As we progress through our workshops, we’ll be documenting as much as possible and will be looking to pass knowledge back to the community. Keep an eye on <a title="10up.com Blog" href="https://10up.com/blog/">10up.com</a> and our <a title="10up on Twitter" href="http://twitter.com/10up">Twitter</a> and <a title="10up on Facebook" href="https://www.facebook.com/10up.agency">Facebook</a> streams for updates. Take a look at our schedule below, and if this summit sounds like something you would love to be a part of – we’re always looking for great hires!</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/10up-2013-developer-summit/#more-8375" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Coming to Portland: 10up’s First Internal Developer Summit</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-8330 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry wordpress-boston-hack-day-sponsor">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordpress-boston-hack-day-sponsor/">10up sponsors &amp; organizes WordPress Boston Hack&nbsp;Day</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/" title="Posts by " rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo avatar-default" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> </a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordpress-boston-hack-day-sponsor/" title="10up sponsors &amp; organizes WordPress Boston Hack Day"><time datetime="2013-02-23T01:08:06-05:00">February 23, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p><div style="width:230px;height:400px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:230px 400px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p>I recently became a <strong>part of the WordPress Boston organizing team</strong>. My first organizing event is also the first ever <a href="http://bwphackday.eventbrite.com/">WordPress Boston Hack Day</a>, which is taking place next Saturday from 10am-6pm at Bocoup. It’s a day dedicated to developers working together on core WordPress tickets. We’re going to start with an introduction by lead developers Mark Jaquith and Andrew Nacin. Mark will fill everyone in on the state of the development cycle since WordPress 3.5 came out, and tell us how we can help. It’s a great opportunity for new contributors to get their feet wet, as we spend the day coding, testing, and documenting.</p>
<p>I’m really happy to announce that 10up is going to be sponsoring the hackathon! This is sure to be a productive day, so if you’re in the Boston area and looking to get your name in the credits, join us at Bocoup. And if you love hacking core, and want to do more of that, <a href="https://10up.com/contact/">get in touch</a> &nbsp;– we’re always looking for your type!</p>
</div>
</article>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-8316 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry sponsor-higheredweb-new-england">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/sponsor-higheredweb-new-england/">10up Sponsors HigherEdWeb New&nbsp;England</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/sponsor-higheredweb-new-england/" title="10up Sponsors HigherEdWeb New England"><time datetime="2013-02-13T00:39:24-05:00">February 13, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p><div style="width:300px;height:105px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:300px 105px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p>Conferences like HigherEdWeb New England inspire schools to implement smarter, more engaging websites that better tout the outstanding education New England schools deliver, attract superior applicants in the age of social media and smartphones, and increase administrative efficiency. <strong>The values of openness, community, and meritocracy espoused by open source projects like WordPress are shared by higher education and shared by 10up.&nbsp;</strong>As a graduate of a New England university, the University of Rhode Island, I’m especially proud that our team is supporting a conference that shares our values and pushes large institutions like universities to embrace the benefits of changing technology.</p>
<p>You can catch Jess, our Director of Web Strategy, and Craig, a Senior Web Strategist, at the conference. Craig in particular is no stranger to higher ed websites, having led projects for the University of Vermont and The New England Culinary Institute.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/sponsor-higheredweb-new-england/#more-8316" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on 10up Sponsors HigherEdWeb New&nbsp;England</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-8241 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-uncategorized hiring-jobs-front-end-wordpress-developer">

<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/hiring-jobs-front-end-wordpress-developer/">Come Work With Us: WordPress developer with a front-end focus</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/hiring-jobs-front-end-wordpress-developer/" title="Come Work With Us: WordPress developer with a front-end focus"><time datetime="2013-01-16T20:37:30-05:00">January 16, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p>At 10up, we say we’re always hiring, and it’s true. We’re always looking for WordPress engineers and web strategists, but right now we’ve especially got our eyes on hiring another WordPress developer with a focus on the front-end. We offer a competitive full-time salary and benefits. If you’re interested, send a resumé and code samples (like a WordPress theme) to&nbsp;<a href="mailto:jobs@10up.com">jobs@10up.com</a>.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/hiring-jobs-front-end-wordpress-developer/#more-8241" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Come Work With Us: WordPress developer with a front-end focus</span></a></p>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-8231 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry wordcamp-phoenix-2013">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordcamp-phoenix-2013/">Returning to the desert; my start with 10up and WordCamp Phoenix</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/taylor/" title="Posts by Taylor Dewey" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TDewey-600x600-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2016/11/TDewey-600x600-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Dewey</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2013/wordcamp-phoenix-2013/" title="Returning to the desert; my start with 10up and WordCamp Phoenix"><time datetime="2013-01-16T20:09:21-05:00">January 16, 2013</time></a>
</p>
<p><div style="width:125px;height:125px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:125px 125px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p>It seems fitting, then, that the three of us: Jake, Eric, and myself are returning to <a title="Phoenix WordCamp 2013 official site" href="http://2013.phoenix.wordcamp.org/">WordCamp Phoenix 2013</a> as speakers.</p>
<p>Jake is attending as a rockstar presenter. Eric and I are teaching Friday classes and Sunday sessions. I’ll be talking about developer tools and techniques. Eric will talk about leveraging WordPress and open source publishing in developing or low-tech environments. Jake will dive into the “core of WordPress core”, studying its most base level information architecture and database schema.</p>
<p>If you happen to be headed to WordCamp Phoenix this January, we’d love to meet up and say hello. We’re always looking for new employees and great WordPress stories.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8218 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry enforcing-wordpress-image-sizes-within-your-theme">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/enforcing-wordpress-image-sizes-within-your-theme/">Enforcing WordPress Image Sizes Within Your&nbsp;Theme</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/" title="Posts by " rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo avatar-default" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> </a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/enforcing-wordpress-image-sizes-within-your-theme/" title="Enforcing WordPress Image Sizes Within Your Theme"><time datetime="2012-12-19T17:15:30-05:00">December 19, 2012</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/enforcing-wordpress-image-sizes-within-your-theme/#comments" class="comments-count">7 Comments</a>
</p>
<p><div style="width:300px;height:108px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:300px 108px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p>As a designer and programmer here at 10up, I have the unique opportunity to see my design through from the first wireframe to the fin</p>
<p>al product. There’s nothing that makes me grimace more than turning control over to a client only to see the design fall apart with use. Ensuring that as little as possible is “breakable” is on top of my quality assurance list. WordPress’s native, customizable image sizes is a common cause of breakdowns.</p>
<h2>How I use image sizes in designs</h2>
<p>Nothing disturbs my blank white canvas in Photoshop until I have set the grid and guides that will determine the structure of the layout. As I begin to flesh out the design, image placeholders find their way in, and they’re always made to fit within those guidelines. Common placeholders include a featured slider image, a thumbnail for the main index/search/archive post list view, and a special size for the “image” <a href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Post_Formats">post format</a>. Most of the time, I want images used within posts and pages to use these same consistent sizes so that the layout stays as clean as possible. Call me OCD, it wouldn’t be the first time. (<em>Editor’s note: all great designers are a bit OCD!)</em></p>
<p>I could create predefined image sizes for each call to an image attachment (and I often do at least one or two of those), but defining an endless set of sizes has a real performance toll every time an image is uploaded, not to mention the bloating effect on the upload directory. If I define 5 custom sizes, and we add that to the 3 default sizes (thumbnail, medium, and large), we wind up with 9 sizes, counting the original. That’s 9 images generated every time an image is uploaded to the site. I always try to avoid the weight and clutter by using the default image sizes.</p>
<h2>Enforcing the image sizes</h2>
<p>It may have crossed your mind that this breaks my own OCD rule, as administrators can adjust default image sizes from the Media settings page. But wait – that’s what this post is all about! Let’s get to some code.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/enforcing-wordpress-image-sizes-within-your-theme/#more-8218" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Enforcing WordPress Image Sizes Within Your&nbsp;Theme</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8210 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry techonomy-12-social-is-the-message">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/techonomy-12-social-is-the-message/">Techonomy ’12 – Social *is* the&nbsp;message</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-craig-chevrier" title="Posts by Craig Chevrier" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Craig_avatar-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2012/09/Craig_avatar-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Craig Chevrier</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/techonomy-12-social-is-the-message/" title="Techonomy ’12 – Social *is* the message"><time datetime="2012-11-18T17:48:35-05:00">November 18, 2012</time></a>
</p>
<p>On November 11 to 13, I was privileged to attend <a href="http://techonomy.com/conf/12-tucson/">Techonomy ’12 in Tucson, Arizona</a>, with 10up founder Jake Goldman.<em>&nbsp;</em>Techonomy ’12 in Tuscon featured exciting content and internationally-known business, science, and political leaders focused on the intersection of technology and the global economy. Sponsored by companies like Forbes Magazine, speakers included technology, finance, education, and publishing luminaries like Steve Forbes, EMC CEO Joe Tucci, AI pioneer and author Ray Kurzweiler, and Nielsen president Steve Hasker.</p>
<p>Techonomy founder David Kirkpatrick led and moderated the 3 days of talk about the accelerating speed of technological progress, driven by increasing availability of the Internet and mobile devices. And that change is not limited to just technological progress, but to human progress as well: the technology-empowered individual is affecting a major shift in economic and political power on a global scale.</p>
<p><div style="width:800px;height:360px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 360px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/techonomy-12-social-is-the-message/#more-8210" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Techonomy ’12 – Social *is* the&nbsp;message</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-8014 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry wordcamp-toronto-developers">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-toronto-developers/">WordCamp Toronto: Developers</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/taylor/" title="Posts by Taylor Dewey" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TDewey-600x600-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2016/11/TDewey-600x600-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Dewey</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-toronto-developers/" title="WordCamp Toronto: Developers"><time datetime="2012-11-12T16:57:25-05:00">November 12, 2012</time></a>
</p>
<p>This is a post about a WordCamp. It is far from the first one: we sponsor and send people to a number of them each year . This past weekend I had the opportunity to speak at WordCamp Toronto: Developers.</p>
<p>Toronto has now held the second developer-centric WordCamp. The idea—as it was explained during the opening remarks—is that these are viability tests of niche WordCamps.</p>
<p>The Toronto organizers are (rightly) considering the test a success. They sold out tickets with an attendance near 300 and a slate of talented speakers despite Hurricane Sandy forcing a last-minute call for speakers.</p>
<p>I had the opportunity to speak about how to create websites tailored to the people using them through a process called Interaction Design. This half science, half design discipline answers questions such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>Who is the site being created for, what do we mean by “user?”</li>
<li>What tasks and goals should this website address?</li>
<li>How will someone interact with the website?</li>
</ul>
<div> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-toronto-developers/#more-8014" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on WordCamp Toronto: Developers</span></a></div>
</div>
</article>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-7611 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry wordpress-plug-in-self-deactivation">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordpress-plug-in-self-deactivation/">WordPress Plug-in Self Deactivation</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordpress-plug-in-self-deactivation/" title="WordPress Plug-in Self Deactivation"><time datetime="2012-10-22T21:17:18-04:00">October 22, 2012</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordpress-plug-in-self-deactivation/#comments" class="comments-count">8 Comments</a>
</p>
<p>WordPress 3.5 is almost upon us, and I was excited to learn that <a href="http://wordpress.org/extend/plugins/sort-query-by-post-in/">my Sort Query by Post In plug-in</a> had been folded into core, <a href="http://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/13729">thanks to a ticket</a> I opened and submitted a patch for some time ago. Sort Query by Post In allowed developers to return posts from a post query (WP_Query) in the order designated using the <em>post__in</em> parameter.</p>
<p>Now that identical functionality is in core,&nbsp;I wanted to update my plug-in to automatically disable itself – with a notice – for users running 3.5 or newer. This code would also prevent the plug-in from being activated if installed on 3.5 or newer. Surprisingly, there seemed to be a dearth of good tutorials, so I came up with my own solution.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordpress-plug-in-self-deactivation/#more-7611" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on WordPress Plug-in Self Deactivation</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-7361 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry webfonts-cors-and-ie">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/webfonts-cors-and-ie/">Webfonts, CORS, and&nbsp;IE</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/helen/" title="Posts by Helen Hou-Sandi" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Helen Hou-Sandí" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/HHouSandi-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/HHouSandi-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Helen Hou-Sandi</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/webfonts-cors-and-ie/" title="Webfonts, CORS, and IE"><time datetime="2012-10-22T00:09:01-04:00">October 22, 2012</time></a>
</p>
<p>We do quite a bit of development on the WordPress.com VIP infrastructure, where sites are generally domain-mapped and theme files are loaded over their CDN. Recently we developed a site where the webfont needed was not available through a hosted service, so @font-face was used to include the font files. Once the site was off of our local and staging environments and moved onto WordPress.com, however, we discovered a number of issues concerning the fonts.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/webfonts-cors-and-ie/#more-7361" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Webfonts, CORS, and&nbsp;IE</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-7390 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry jquery-developer-summit-2012">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/jquery-developer-summit-2012/">jQuery Developer Summit&nbsp;2012</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/" title="Posts by " rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo avatar-default" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> </a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/jquery-developer-summit-2012/" title="jQuery Developer Summit 2012"><time datetime="2012-10-19T01:46:34-04:00">October 19, 2012</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/jquery-developer-summit-2012/#comments" class="comments-count">2 Comments</a>
</p>
<p>This week, I had the privilege of attending the first ever <a href="http://events.jquery.org/2012/developer-summit/">jQuery Developer Summit</a>. I spent two full days hacking jQuery and collaborating with the jQuery team and community to squash as many bugs as possible. The Summit was held at the AOL campus in Dulles, VA.</p>
<p><div style="width:300px;height:168px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:300px 168px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p>I was assigned to Table 2 where our goal was to fix jQuery bugs. We covered a vast array of topics including <a href="http://gruntjs.com/">Grunt.js</a>, Git and <a href="http://swarm.jquery.org/">TestSwarm</a>. It was refreshing to see so many JavaScript engineers get together to talk about complex JavaScript bugs and solutions.</p>
<p>Yesterday, we kicked off the Summit with several brief presentations from various jQuery team members and discussed the goals for each table. After this, we jumped into code head first. Dave Methvin, president of the jQuery foundation, was at Table 2 leading the bug assignments and assisting us whenever possible. The bug I was assigned to fix (<a href="http://bugs.jquery.com/ticket/12519">#12519</a>) branched into many other conversations that made us question the design principles of the correlated code that the bug referenced. After rationalizing the best way to address these issues with Dave and several jQuery members, we finally decided on a solution. I committed the changes Tuesday morning and my pull request was approved shortly thereafter, representing my very first <a href="https://github.com/jquery/jquery/pull/976">jQuery core patch</a> on behalf of 10up!</p>
<p>I’m looking forward to continuing to contribute to the jQuery community and to exploring new ways to integrate advanced jQuery solutions into WordPress.</p>
<p><div style="width:800px;height:450px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 450px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-7192 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry taylor-zack-and-jeremy-at-wordcamp-vancouver">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/taylor-zack-and-jeremy-at-wordcamp-vancouver/">Taylor, Zack, and Jeremy at WordCamp Vancouver</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/jeremy/" title="Posts by Jeremy Felt" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jeremy_avatar-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2012/02/Jeremy_avatar-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jeremy Felt</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/taylor-zack-and-jeremy-at-wordcamp-vancouver/" title="Taylor, Zack, and Jeremy at WordCamp Vancouver"><time datetime="2012-10-13T11:58:25-04:00">October 13, 2012</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/taylor-zack-and-jeremy-at-wordcamp-vancouver/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<p>WordCamp Vancouver is coming up quick and 10up is excited not only to be a bronze level sponsor, but to also represent with three developers from our Portland contingent.<a href="https://10up.com/?attachment_id=7208" rel="attachment wp-att-7208"><br>
</a></p>
<p><div style="width:800px;height:122px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 122px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p>I’ll be starting the developer track off on Saturday with a talk on ‘Calm and Simple Code’. We’ll have a good time going through the reasons and best practices for remaining simple and coding with purpose when working with WordPress as a framework.</p>
<p>Later in the afternoon, Zack will be tackling the topic of cache invalidation in WordPress. It’s often easy to get started with the WordPress transient API and object caching in general, but things can quickly turn difficult when you start looking for the best approach to invalidating your caches to keep your data fresh.</p>
<p>And to top it off, we’ll be there for the first ever BuddyCamp the following day!</p>
<p>Be sure to look for us in our 10up shirts on Saturday, though we may change for your benefit on Sunday. Any topic is welcome. We can help you with your WordPress questions, converse about some geeky technical issue, or give you an overview of 10up and what kind of work we do on a daily basis. We’re always interested and we’re always hiring!</p>
</div>
</article>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-6334 type-post status-publish format-aside hentry post_format-post-format-aside wordcamp-baltimore">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-baltimore/" title="WordCamp Baltimore"><img alt="Helen Hou-Sandí" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/HHouSandi-256x256.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/HHouSandi-512x512.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-256 photo" height="256" width="256" loading="lazy" decoding="async" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/helen/" title="Posts by Helen Hou-Sandi" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"> Helen Hou-Sandi</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-baltimore/" title="WordCamp Baltimore"><time datetime="2012-09-07T13:15:12-04:00">September 7, 2012</time></a>
</p>
<div class="body-copy">
<p>I’ll be speaking at WordCamp Baltimore this weekend, giving a designer oriented talk entitled <a href="http://2012.baltimore.wordcamp.org/session/photoshop-ettiquette/"><em>How to Help a Developer Faithfully Realize Your WordPress Theme Design</em></a>. We’ll cover essential WordPress theme components, a little bit of Photoshop etiquette, and explore what goes on in a developer’s head when they convert your lovely theme into an interactive reality. I’ll be joined at the conference by fellow 10up engineer Taylor Lovett, so be sure to say&nbsp;hi!</p>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-5972 type-post status-publish format-video hentry post_format-post-format-video video-discussion-enterprise-class-wordpress">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/video-discussion-enterprise-class-wordpress/">Video &amp; Discussion: Enterprise Class WordPress</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/video-discussion-enterprise-class-wordpress/" title="Video &amp; Discussion: Enterprise Class WordPress"><time datetime="2012-08-25T14:02:49-04:00">August 25, 2012</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/video-discussion-enterprise-class-wordpress/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<div class="blog-video-wrap"><div class="blog-video-screen"><div class="fluid-width-video-wrapper" style="position: relative; width: 100%; padding-top: 56.1538%;"><embed src="http://v.wordpress.com/vjawLLrC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="650" height="365" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" wmode="transparent" style="position: absolute; width: 100%; height: 100%; left: 0px; top: 0px;"></div></div><div class="blog-video-bottom"></div></div><p><em>Enterprise Class WordPress</em> is a look at what it means to tackle web projects for really big organizations using WordPress. The talk highlights tools and resources for enterprise implementations, marketing tactics and resources for pursuing large scale clients, and even takes a hard look at what our platform needs to do better (multilingual). Above all, it explores how we, as a community, can better pursue large businesses and make WordPress not just the #1 web publishing platform for small to medium sized organizations, but the #1 platform for large scale implementations.</p>
<p>Meaningful conversation and education about WordPress in enterprise is really critical for ushering in the next stage of WordPress’s growth, which is why I’ve taken this conversation to a few WordCamps in the last few months. I debuted the talk in Orange County, but the Boston version was the first to make it up to WordPress.tv. You can also <a title="Enterprise Class WordPress slides" href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/06/slides-enterprise-class-wordpress/">see the standalone slides from the original version</a> (which has evolved a bit).</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/video-discussion-enterprise-class-wordpress/#more-5972" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Video &amp; Discussion: Enterprise Class WordPress</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-5144 type-post status-publish format-aside hentry post_format-post-format-aside helen-and-zack-at-wordcamp-chicago">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/helen-and-zack-at-wordcamp-chicago/" title="Helen and Zack at WordCamp Chicago"><img alt="Helen Hou-Sandí" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/HHouSandi-256x256.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/HHouSandi-512x512.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-256 photo" height="256" width="256" loading="lazy" decoding="async" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/helen/" title="Posts by Helen Hou-Sandi" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"> Helen Hou-Sandi</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/helen-and-zack-at-wordcamp-chicago/" title="Helen and Zack at WordCamp Chicago"><time datetime="2012-08-22T14:14:11-04:00">August 22, 2012</time></a>
</p>
<div class="body-copy">
<p>This weekend will bring Zack and I to the Midwest, where we’ll be representing 10up at WordCamp Chicago. Not only are we excited to both be on semi-familiar stomping grounds, but we’ll be bringing you two brand new talks! Zack will be presenting “<a title="Permalink to Grokking the WordPress Object Cache: Getting a Handle on the WP_Object_Cache Class" href="http://2012.chicago.wordcamp.org/session/grokking-the-wordpress-object-cache-getting-a-handle-on-the-wp_object_cache-class/" rel="bookmark">Grokking the WordPress Object Cache: Getting a Handle on the WP_Object_Cache Class</a>“, an absolute must for developers and anybody else who cares about performance or the deeper innards of WordPress. I will be giving a talk entitled “<a title="Permalink to How to Sneak Your Way Into Being a Rockstar WordPress Developer When Everyone Thinks You’re a Designer" href="http://2012.chicago.wordcamp.org/session/how-to-sneak-your-way-into-being-a-rockstar-wordpress-developer-when-everyone-thinks-youre-a-designer/" rel="bookmark">How to Sneak Your Way Into Being a Rockstar WordPress Developer When Everyone Thinks You’re a Designer</a>“, which, despite ironically being in the designer track, is about how I got involved with contributing to WordPress and how you can, too, whether or not you’re a developer-type. We’re excited to be at DePaul in the beautiful neighborhood of Lincoln Park, and we hope to see you there!</p>
</div>
</div>
</article>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-5636 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-uncategorized usability-considerations-new-tab-window">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/usability-considerations-new-tab-window/">Opening a new tab or window: usability considerations</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/taylor/" title="Posts by Taylor Dewey" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TDewey-600x600-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2016/11/TDewey-600x600-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Dewey</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/usability-considerations-new-tab-window/" title="Opening a new tab or window: usability considerations"><time datetime="2012-08-14T21:29:00-04:00">August 14, 2012</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/usability-considerations-new-tab-window/#comments" class="comments-count">5 Comments</a>
</p>
<p>Have you ever asked your web developer to open a link in a new tab or window? Generally, this is accomplished by adding a&nbsp;<code>target="_blank"</code>&nbsp;attribute to a link. <strong>Let’s consider the usability implications</strong>.</p>
<p>The rationale is almost always founded in a desire to keep the audience engaged with your content longer, or a concern about usability (for example, keeping the reader losing his or her bearings). The overwhelming finding from user experience researchers*, however, is that new windows/tabs should be avoided when simply opening new web pages. However, there are some appropriate use cases: opening a non-HTML document (web page) like a large image, video, audio, or other media, or to avoid interrupting an important linear process like a checkout. Even with these exceptions, however, there are &nbsp;friendlier alternatives like tool-tips and lightboxes.</p>
<p>In fact, the <code>target=""</code> attribute was actually deprecated (being phased out) from the HTML specifications until HTML5. As of HTML5, the W3C guidelines stipulate that it is no longer deprecated because it is deemed “useful in Web applications, e.g. in conjunction with iframe.”</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/usability-considerations-new-tab-window/#more-5636" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Opening a new tab or window: usability considerations</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-5668 type-post status-publish format-aside hentry post_format-post-format-aside 501-tech-club-ask-an-expert-a-group-problem-solving-salon">

<article class="blog-archive-post post-5618 type-post status-publish format-aside hentry post_format-post-format-aside 10up-goes-social">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/10up-goes-social/" title="10up goes social"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-256x256.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-512x512.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-256 photo" height="256" width="256" loading="lazy" decoding="async" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/10up-goes-social/" title="10up goes social"><time datetime="2012-08-13T00:39:27-04:00">August 13, 2012</time></a>
</p>
<div class="body-copy">
<p>We might tell our clients to be serious about social media, and we might even build <a href="http://twitchy.com/">next generation websites structured entirely around social media</a>. But we’ve been so busy helping clients that it wasn’t until tonight that we started getting serious about our <em>own</em> social strategy. We now own <a href="http://twitter.com/10up">@10up</a>&nbsp;on Twitter – the official place for 10up news and insights. In addition, we’ve launched <a href="http://www.facebook.com/10up.agency">our Facebook fan page</a>, where you’ll find team photos you won’t find anywhere else. Of course, you also can continue to follow me <a href="http://twitter.com/jakemgold">at @jakemgold</a> for unique 10up insights and news, and the <a href="https://twitter.com/#!/10up/team10up/">team 10up list</a> for a peek into our psyche. Be sure to let us know what you think – at those locations!</p>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-5562 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry wordcamp-san-francisco-10up-annual-meeting-2012">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-san-francisco-10up-annual-meeting-2012/">Reflections: WordCamp San Francisco &amp; 10up’s Annual Meeting</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-taylor-lovett" title="Posts by Taylor Lovett" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TLovett-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/TLovett-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Lovett</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-san-francisco-10up-annual-meeting-2012/" title="Reflections: WordCamp San Francisco &amp; 10up’s Annual Meeting"><time datetime="2012-08-11T19:27:55-04:00">August 11, 2012</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-san-francisco-10up-annual-meeting-2012/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<p>Last weekend I had a blast attending <a href="http://2012.sf.wordcamp.org/">WordCamp San Francisco</a>, the original and largest WordCamp. For the price of one incredibly cheap entry ticket (well, plus travel from my home base in Washington DC…), I saw interesting speakers, ate great food, met friendly people, listened to live jazz, and was given complimentary WordPress gear. The conference was filled with WordPress users, enthusiasts, developers, and everyday people who just wanted to learn more about the platform, bonded by an affection and appreciation for the open-source WordPress project.&nbsp;Tied in with our annual company meeting, all of team 10up was flown into San Francisco for the purpose of attending the WordCamp and having some time for team bonding.</p>
<p><div style="width:760px;height:244px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:760px 244px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p>The most anticipated WordCamp event was, of course, Matt Mullenweg’s “State of the Word” – a light-hearted expression of his aspirations for and reflections on the current and future state of WordPress. As a web developer and plugin maker, Matt’s thoughts on unit tests for plugins stood out. Matt underscored the importance of elevating the quality of plugins in the official repository; units tests would be a great way to start this process off.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-san-francisco-10up-annual-meeting-2012/#more-5562" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Reflections: WordCamp San Francisco &amp; 10up’s Annual Meeting</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-5247 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry wordpress-vip-partner">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordpress-vip-partner/">10up – A Featured WordPress.com VIP&nbsp;Partner</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordpress-vip-partner/" title="10up – A Featured WordPress.com VIP Partner"><time datetime="2012-08-02T10:01:30-04:00">August 2, 2012</time></a>
</p>
<p>Today, <a href="http://automattic.com/">Automattic</a> officially announced an expansion of their <a href="http://vip.wordpress.com/">WordPress.com VIP</a> featured partner program. Among other changes, it will now include consulting agencies for the first time. Here at 10up, we’re proud to be on a list that includes elite WordPress.com partners like Facebook and Flipboard.</p>
<h2><div style="width:300px;height:116px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:300px 116px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></h2>
<h2><strong><em>“The WordPress.co</em></strong><strong><em>m VIP team vets each agency that applies … to ensure the agency’s capabilities fit the needs and scale of VIP customers.”</em> </strong></h2>
<p>At 10up, quality and customer service is number one. 10up’s President is a core WordPress contributor with over a dozen top rated plug-ins to his name. Understanding what it means to build a high quality web solution goes all the way to the top. With a modern, distributed workforce, 10up has been able to hand pick some of the best talent from around the country; talent like Helen, 10up’s Lead User Interface Engineer, and the <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/05/10up-core-wordpress-team/">team representative for User Interface on the Core WordPress.org project</a>. No fewer than five of 10up’s employees are credited core WordPress contributors, more than any other agency in the program – with more on the way.</p>
<p>If WordPress is the best platform in the world for managing a website (and we think it is!), WordPress.com VIP is the best platform in the world for hosting high volume WordPress sites. On WordPress.com VIP’s unique, highly scalable, cloud infrastructure 10up clients never have to worry about their sites going down when their popularity surges. That’s why 10up has brought fast growing clients like <a href="https://10up.com/showcase/hip2save-today/">Hip2Save</a> – the official deal blog of the Today Show – and Twitchy – an innovative editorial news site centered on Twitter – to the platform.</p>
<p>10up has been privileged to work with an exciting mix of WordPress.com VIP clients, from the world’s top technology news site, <a href="https://10up.com/showcase/techcrunch/">TechCrunch</a>, to cable TV sports network Universal Sports, to Canada’s top news portal, Canada.com, to <a href="https://10up.com/showcase/9to5mac/">9to5 Mac</a>, one of the top 100 blogs on the web. 10up is working on its most exciting VIP projects yet, and we can’t wait to tell you more.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><div style="width:756px;height:107px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:756px 107px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordpress-vip-partner/#more-5247" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on 10up – A Featured WordPress.com VIP&nbsp;Partner</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>

<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/team-10up-takes-san-francisco/" title="Team 10up Takes San Francisco"><time datetime="2012-08-01T20:31:14-04:00">August 1, 2012</time></a>

<p>This weekend is the biggest WordPress event of the year – <a href="http://2012.sf.wordcamp.org/">WordCamp San Francisco</a>. So where else would team 10up be? No, we’re not just sending a couple of executives or a few top developers – you’ll find all of team 10up at this annual anchor event, running around in our 10up gear. At 10up, WordCamp San Francisco is our annual anchor, so we’ll be heading down the day before and sticking around for a couple of days after the camp for some face to face team work and some on site visits with local clients. Hope to see you there!</p>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-5239 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry wordcamp-boston-2012">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-boston-2012/">10up takes WordCamp Boston&nbsp;2012</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/steven-lasch/" title="Posts by Steven" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Steven_avatar-64x64.png" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2012/06/Steven_avatar-128x128.png 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Steven</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-boston-2012/" title="10up takes WordCamp Boston 2012"><time datetime="2012-08-01T20:19:55-04:00">August 1, 2012</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-boston-2012/#comments" class="comments-count">3 Comments</a>
</p>
<p><a href="http://2012.boston.wordcamp.org/">WordCamp Boston 2012</a> occurred on a hot and steamy weekend on July 14 &amp; 15 at Boston University.</p>
<p>My WordCamp experience started with a vibrant <a title="WordPress Can Do That" href="http://www.slideshare.net/jessjurick/wordpress-can-do-that-13154220">presentation by our own Jess Jurick</a> on some lesser trumpeted capabilities that WordPress offers. She covered some of her favorite plugins such as Gravity Forms, WooCommerce and BuddyPress while showcasing some sites that push the boundaries of WordPress far beyond blogging.</p>
<p>Sam Hotchkiss offered attendees another atypical take on WordPress with <em>Using WordPress as a Web App Framework</em>. If you have an idea for an app, you can produce that interactive, secure, desktop-like program using WordPress! Features like user support, admin management, security, rapid deployment and many other essential requirements of app development are all part of WP’s framework.</p>
<p><div style="width:756px;height:391px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:756px 391px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p>Jake Goldman, our President, gave a polished <a title="Slides: Enterprise Class WordPress" href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/06/slides-enterprise-class-wordpress/">presentation focused on applying WordPress to enterprise environments</a> where complex, scalable and mission-critical web development is essential. Topics included marketing to enterprise level clients, demonstrating WordPress’s value as an open source CMS with an enormous developer community, and the advantages of VIP Hosting.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-boston-2012/#more-5239" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on 10up takes WordCamp Boston&nbsp;2012</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-5188 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry wordcamp-portland-2012">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-portland-2012/">WordCamp Portland&nbsp;2012</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/taylor/" title="Posts by Taylor Dewey" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/TDewey-600x600-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2016/11/TDewey-600x600-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Taylor Dewey</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-portland-2012/" title="WordCamp Portland 2012"><time datetime="2012-07-31T01:07:46-04:00">July 31, 2012</time></a>
</p>
<p>It’s WordCamp season for 10up! Well, actually, are always&nbsp;traveling to various WordCamps, but in the next few months we’ve got a few. Near to my heart is&nbsp;<a title="2012 WordCamp Portland" href="http://2012.portland.wordcamp.org/">WordCamp Portland</a>, rapidly approaching on August 18th. We have four 10uppers attending, two are featured speakers, and 10up is a <strong>top-tier, Bald Eagle sponsor</strong>.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="size-medium wp-image-5195 alignright" title="wc-pdx" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/wc-pdx-e1343711189328-300x94.png" alt="" width="300" height="94"></p>
<p>The three 10up Portlanders: Zack, Taylor, and Jeremy will be there and, since it’s our hometown, we will be volunteering throughout the day. Among the 12 selected to be featured speakers are Zack and Taylor. Presenting development anti-patterns&nbsp;is Zack, with his session titled&nbsp;<em>_doing_it_wrong: Improving Your Development Skills Through Examining Bad Practices</em>. Taylor is presenting a talk about how we, as authors, designers, and developers, should focus our attention on the interaction between users and content. His talk, titled&nbsp;<em>Why We Click Publish: Advocating for User-Centricity through Interaction Design</em>, as well as Zack’s are&nbsp;<a title="2012 WordCamp Portland Schedule" href="http://2012.sf.wordcamp.org/schedule/">scheduled simultaneously</a>, first thing after the morning announcements.</p>
<p>Because 25% of 10up employees call Portland home, 10up is sponsoring WordCamp Portland as a top-tier, Bald Eagle sponsor and Jake is flying in to keep tabs on us. If you’re in town for WordCamp, we’d love to meet you: find us in our grey 10up shirts or better yet, attend one of our sessions.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-4288 type-post status-publish format-aside hentry post_format-post-format-aside wordcamp-reno-tahoe">

<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-reno-tahoe/" title="Speaking at WordCamp Reno / Tahoe 2012"><time datetime="2012-06-24T19:51:59-04:00">June 24, 2012</time></a>
</p>
<div class="body-copy">
<p>Looking forward to participating in <a href="http://2012.reno.wordcamp.org/">WordCamp Reno-Tahoe 2012</a> next weekend, June 30-July 1. I had my first chance to visit beautiful Lake Tahoe about 1 month ago, and am already excited to be heading back. <a href="http://2012.reno.wordcamp.org/session/enterprise-class-wordpress/">I’ll be revisiting <em>Enterprise Class WordPress</em></a>, an exploration of what it means to use and sell WordPress as the CMS solution for massive website projects.</p>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-4084 type-post status-publish format-aside hentry post_format-post-format-aside speaking-at-the-kansas-city-meetup">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/speaking-at-the-kansas-city-meetup/" title="Speaking at the Kansas City MeetUp"><img alt="Helen Hou-Sandí" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/HHouSandi-256x256.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/HHouSandi-512x512.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-256 photo" height="256" width="256" loading="lazy" decoding="async" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a>

<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/helen/" title="Posts by Helen Hou-Sandi" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"> Helen Hou-Sandi</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/speaking-at-the-kansas-city-meetup/" title="Speaking at the Kansas City MeetUp"><time datetime="2012-06-15T19:44:29-04:00">June 15, 2012</time></a>
</p>
<div class="body-copy">
<p>Before I move from Wichita back to the East Coast (my original home) in a couple of weeks, I’m going to meet the fine folks of the Kansas City WordPress MeetUp and reprise my WCNYC talk on “Making Custom Content Management Disappear into the WordPress Admin”, since I wasn’t able to speak at WordCamp Kansas City. <article class="blog-archive-post post-4048 type-post status-publish format-image has-post-thumbnail hentry post_format-post-format-image interview-on-codepoet-wordpress">

<article class="blog-archive-post post-3868 type-post status-publish format-video hentry post_format-post-format-video slides-enterprise-class-wordpress">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/slides-enterprise-class-wordpress/">Slides: Enterprise Class WordPress</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/slides-enterprise-class-wordpress/" title="Slides: Enterprise Class WordPress"><time datetime="2012-06-07T17:53:33-04:00">June 7, 2012</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/slides-enterprise-class-wordpress/#comments" class="comments-count">3 Comments</a>
</p>
<div class="blog-video-wrap"><div class="blog-video-screen"><iframe loading="lazy" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/13213165.html" width="372" height="250" frameborder="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="no"></iframe></div><div class="blog-video-bottom"></div></div><p><strong>Updated 9/16/2012 with the latest version of the deck, presented at WordCamp Los Angeles.</strong></p>
<p>Here are my slides from <a title="WordCamp Orange County: Enterprise Class WordPress" href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/05/wordcamp-orange-county-enterprise-class-wordpress/"><em>Enterprise Class WordPress</em></a> – a talk I debuted <a href="http://2012.oc.wordcamp.org/session/enterprise-class-wordpress/">at WordCamp Orange County</a> last weekend. Like <em><a title="What Would Core Do?" href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/02/what-would-core-do/">What Would Core Do?</a></em>, the focus was on big ideas, not code. I found this difficult to formulate, largely because it involves a complex “problem” that’s more human than technical, and as such, requires a lot of generalizing. I do think that the underlying ideas are important to WordPress’s growth, and I’d like to see the conversation percolate. I plan to refine the talk and explore this with other communities and at other camps – <a href="http://2012.boston.wordcamp.org/speakers/#jake-goldman">starting with Boston</a>. Please chime in with ideas!</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-3546 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry see-you-at-wordcamp-milwaukee">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/see-you-at-wordcamp-milwaukee/">See you at WordCamp Milwaukee!</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/" title="Posts by " rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo avatar-default" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> </a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/see-you-at-wordcamp-milwaukee/" title="See you at WordCamp Milwaukee!"><time datetime="2012-05-24T12:59:27-04:00">May 24, 2012</time></a>
</p>
<p>In an unexpected, but certainly delightful turn of events, I will be speaking at WordCamp Milwaukee next weekend! As some of you may or may not know, my family is from Milwaukee and I lived there for a few years, so I’m really excited to not only attend, but speak at the city’s inaugural WordCamp.</p>
<p>WordCamp Milwaukee will consist of three tracks: User, Developer, and Unconference. I’ll be speaking in the User track and delivering my “WordPress Can Do That” presentation. My talk will focus on showcasing some of the amazing sites running WordPress, profiling unique front-end user experiences and the custom backend publishing interfaces that make managing these sites a breeze.</p>
<p>If you’re in the area or plan on attending the event, feel free to ping me on Twitter (<a href="http://twitter.com/jessjurick">@jessjurick</a>) if you’d like to meet up!</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-3501 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry wordcamp-seattle-2012-recap">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-seattle-2012-recap/">WordCamp Seattle 2012&nbsp;Recap</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/jeremy/" title="Posts by Jeremy Felt" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jeremy_avatar-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2012/02/Jeremy_avatar-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jeremy Felt</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-seattle-2012-recap/" title="WordCamp Seattle 2012 Recap"><time datetime="2012-05-23T15:02:42-04:00">May 23, 2012</time></a>
</p>
<p>The WordCamp Seattle organizers had great foresight when they chose last weekend for their 2012 event at the Seattle Art Museum. Not only did everything turn out perfect, from the weather to the venue, but 10up’s entire Portland contingent was able to make the trip.</p>
<p>We had an excellent time mingling and meeting likeminded folks and were impressed with the quality of sessions offered in all three tracks. I think the only regret is we weren’t able to attend them all.</p>
<p><div style="width:600px;height:450px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:600px 450px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-seattle-2012-recap/#more-3501" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on WordCamp Seattle 2012&nbsp;Recap</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-3459 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry speakers-sponsors-wordcamp-nyc-2012">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/speakers-sponsors-wordcamp-nyc-2012/">Join us at WordCamp NYC&nbsp;2012</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/luke/" title="Posts by Luke Gedeon" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Luke_avatar-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2012/02/Luke_avatar-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Luke Gedeon</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/speakers-sponsors-wordcamp-nyc-2012/" title="Join us at WordCamp NYC 2012"><time datetime="2012-05-22T14:36:36-04:00">May 22, 2012</time></a>
</p>
<p><div style="width:250px;height:250px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:250px 250px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p>In Jake’s presentation, he will be asking:&nbsp;<a href="http://2012.nyc.wordcamp.org/session/what-would-core-do-extending-with-class-and-consistency/">“What would core do?”</a>, and challenging you to keep asking yourself the same as you add your themes and plugins to WordPress. He will show you how to extend core “with class and consistency”.</p>
<p>Helen will be talking about:&nbsp;<a href="http://2012.nyc.wordcamp.org/session/making-plugins-and-themes-disappear-into-the-wordpress-admin/">“Making Plugins and Themes Disappear into the WordPress Admin.</a>&nbsp;One of the best things about WordPress is its beautiful admin UI.” Helen suggests, “We should take advantage of what is built-in and also strive to have our additions look as though they are native.”</p>
<p>I will&nbsp;be talking about: <a href="http://2012.nyc.wordcamp.org/session/actions-and-filters-in-core-javascript-hooked-on-javascript-works-for-me/">Actions and Filters in Core JavaScript.</a> As JavaScript becomes an ever more important part of the WordPress admin, knowing how to use these JavaScript hooks will become as essential as knowing PHP hooks.</p>
<p>If you are in the New York area, come see us. We would look forward to meeting you (or seeing you again).</p>
</div>
</article>
