<article class="blog-archive-post post-3034 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry 10up-core-wordpress-team">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/10up-core-wordpress-team/">Team Rep and Community Things</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/helen/" title="Posts by Helen Hou-Sandi" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Helen Hou-Sandí" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/HHouSandi-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/05/HHouSandi-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Helen Hou-Sandi</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/10up-core-wordpress-team/" title="Team Rep and Community Things"><time datetime="2012-05-11T12:18:24-04:00">May 11, 2012</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/10up-core-wordpress-team/#comments" class="comments-count">5 Comments</a>
</p>
<p>About a month ago, Jane Wells posted surveys for various WordPress contributor groups, including <a href="http://wpdevel.wordpress.com/2012/04/05/organizing-our-contributor-groups/">one for core code contributors on wpdevel</a>, in an effort to begin getting them more organized and select team representatives. I’m very excited to have been <a href="http://wpdevel.wordpress.com/2012/04/26/team-reps/">chosen as one for the core contributors group</a>. We’ll be aiming to have regular cross-group chats and an in-person summit sometime in the near future. This is very exciting, not just for those of us representing the various groups, but for the community at large. Some of the things that I know I’m looking forward to are more communication and collaboration across groups (e.g. UI and accessibility, core development and documentation) and encouraging more people to contribute in whichever way suits them as the WordPress ecosystem continues to grow.</p>
<p><div style="width:756px;height:165px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:756px 165px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/10up-core-wordpress-team/#more-3034" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Team Rep and Community Things</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-3165 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry wordcamp-orange-county-enterprise-class-wordpress">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-orange-county-enterprise-class-wordpress/">WordCamp Orange County: Enterprise Class WordPress</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-orange-county-enterprise-class-wordpress/" title="WordCamp Orange County: Enterprise Class WordPress"><time datetime="2012-05-09T18:50:35-04:00">May 9, 2012</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-orange-county-enterprise-class-wordpress/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<p><div style="width:320px;height:154px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:320px 154px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p>Having taken the “fine-tuning administration” series as far as I can go (<em><a title="Customizing WordPress Admin – updated for 3.1 with new tips!" href="https://10up.com/blog/2011/03/customizing-wordpress-admin/">Hijacking WordPress Admin</a></em>,&nbsp;<em><a title="Editing WordPress’s Visual Editor" href="https://10up.com/blog/2011/12/editing-wordpress-tinymce-visual-editor/">Editing the Visual Editor</a></em>,&nbsp;and <em><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/02/what-would-core-do/">What Would Core Do?</a></em>),&nbsp;I’m turning my attention to another topic that’s near and dear to me: WordPress as an enterprise caliber content management solution.</p>
<p>There’s no question that WordPress has won the hearts and minds of the publishing industry, with everyone from the New York Times to TechCrunch embracing the platform. And WordPress is used by many huge business organizations, non-profits, and government entities – but usually, for microsites, a blog, or another “piece” of their publishing solution. WordPress still faces resistance from many big institutions in many verticals when it comes to that “enterprise CMS” need – the content management system that’s at the core of the organization’s online presence.</p>
<p>At 10up, we’ve had some big successes helping large organizations adopt WordPress as their central CMS, but we’ve also seen huge prospective opportunities ultimately shy away because of lingering hesitations about WordPress’s suitability to the enterprise class title. Some of the concerns are legitimate worries about its functional suitability to issues that only concern huge, international entities. Other concerns are more organizational – can huge companies use a CMS owned and managed by an open source “community”? Is WordPress a CMS meant for the million dollar project?</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-orange-county-enterprise-class-wordpress/#more-3165" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on WordCamp Orange County: Enterprise Class WordPress</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-3059 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry wc-sea-2012-theres-a-function-for-that">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wc-sea-2012-theres-a-function-for-that/">WC SEA 2012: There’s a Function for&nbsp;That!</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/zack/" title="Posts by Zack" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Zack_avatar-64x64.png" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2012/06/Zack_avatar.png 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Zack</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wc-sea-2012-theres-a-function-for-that/" title="WC SEA 2012: There’s a Function for That!"><time datetime="2012-05-07T17:31:53-04:00">May 7, 2012</time></a>
</p>
<p>On May 19th, <a href="http://2012.seattle.wordcamp.org/session/theres-a-function-for-that-doing-more-for-less-with-core-functions/">I will be speaking at WordCamp Seattle</a>. My talk is entitled: “There’s a Function for That: Doing More for Less with Core Functions”. It is exciting to have the opportunity to geek out about some of the hidden gems in WordPress Core.</p>
<p>I plan to curate a plethora of interesting, obscure and powerful WordPress functions to give them the attention and love that they need. Drawing from my experience with complex WordPress projects, I will introduce developers to exciting WordPress functions. WordPress Core has had so many brilliant developers contribute to it. Part of those contributions have led to an extensive catalog of powerful functions that are waiting to make developer’s lives easier. I hope to shed light on these functions to make developer’s work more agile, allow developers to do things the “WordPress way,” and help contribute to the cannon of poetic code in the world.</p>
</div>
</article>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-2817 type-post status-publish format-video hentry post_format-post-format-video video-next-generation-web">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/video-next-generation-web/">Video: Next Generation Web</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/video-next-generation-web/" title="Video: Next Generation Web"><time datetime="2012-04-24T09:56:10-04:00">April 24, 2012</time></a>
</p>
<div class="blog-video-wrap"><div class="blog-video-screen"><div class="fluid-width-video-wrapper" style="position: relative; width: 100%; padding-top: 56.1538%;"><embed src="http://v.wordpress.com/zmQP9y3e" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="650" height="365" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" wmode="transparent" style="position: absolute; width: 100%; height: 100%; left: 0px; top: 0px;"></div></div><div class="blog-video-bottom"></div></div><p>The video from my WordCamp Phoenix 2012 presentation in the “Think Tank” track on “Next Generation Web” is up on WordPress.tv. This was a fun talk to give, a mix of theory on the evolution of web technologies, a high level technical overview and preview of some of today’s cutting edge open web technologies, and a sneak preview at what’s coming down the pike.</p>
<p>If you’re looking for a deep dive into the technical nuances of HTML5 and CSS3, this is <em>not</em>&nbsp;the talk for you. If you like thinking about technology trends, want a sampler of some hot technologies you can use today, and want to be inspired by what’s still ahead, I think you’ll enjoy the talk. You can <a title="Next Generation Web: What HTML5 and CSS3 Are All About" href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/02/next-generation-web-html5-css3/">find the slides here</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-2658 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry debug-bar-cron">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/debug-bar-cron/">WordPress Debug Bar&nbsp;Cron</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/zack/" title="Posts by Zack" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Zack_avatar-64x64.png" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2012/06/Zack_avatar.png 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Zack</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/debug-bar-cron/" title="WordPress Debug Bar Cron"><time datetime="2012-04-16T23:05:08-04:00">April 16, 2012</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/debug-bar-cron/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<p>WordPress’ cron implementation is a powerful tool for scheduling events in WordPress projects. Its usefulness at times is only matched by the frustration inherent in debugging issues with cron. After my most recent frustrations implementing a WordPress scheduled event, I decided to build <a title="Debug Bar Cron" href="http://wordpress.org/extend/plugins/debug-bar-cron/" target="_blank">Debug Bar Cron</a>, an extension for the fantastic <a title="Debug Bar" href="http://wordpress.org/extend/plugins/debug-bar/" target="_blank">Debug Bar</a> that adds a panel of information about registered events. With 10up teammate Helen Hou-Sandi’s UI love, this plugin helps you easily visualize all of the WordPress scheduled events information to quickly see what is happening with these events.</p>
<p>The plugin focuses on providing developers with the most pertinent information regarding their scheduled events as easily as possible. The “dashboard” shows how many events are scheduled, whether or not WordPress cron ran on the current request, when the next event is scheduled to occur, and the current time for easy comparison for the event times.</p>
<p><div style="width:800px;height:120px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 120px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/debug-bar-cron/#more-2658" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on WordPress Debug Bar&nbsp;Cron</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-2628 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry html-body-class-for-ios">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/html-body-class-for-ios/">Quick Coding Tip: Body Class for iOS Devices (Cache Friendly!)</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/html-body-class-for-ios/" title="Quick Coding Tip: Body Class for iOS Devices (Cache Friendly!)"><time datetime="2012-04-16T14:32:33-04:00">April 16, 2012</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/html-body-class-for-ios/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<p>At 10up, responsive design is a hot request. In fact, over the course of the last year, we’ve seen this type of work evolve from relative indifference – when pitched – to a common client expectation.</p>
<p>It often makes sense to release a new “desktop” experience before rolling CSS3 media queries or other responsive techniques. Furthermore, you might invest in contextual layout for phone screens, but leave the “desktop” experience for tablet devices. While devices like an iPad or iPhone do a great job of rendering any web page (this was the original selling point!), there are cases where the layout calls for subtle changes. In one case, we needed to hide buttons that spawned unsupported technologies (e.g. Flash) on iOS devices. We also had to deal with a subtle but ugly <a href="http://www.billrobbinsdesign.com/fixing-background-image-sizing-in-ios/">iOS Safari quirk involving large background images</a>.</p>
<p>It’s easy enough to write server side code&nbsp;(e.g. PHP) that changes the output based on the browser’s user agent, but if you need to work with page caching, <em>server side</em> code based on visitor specific properties isn’t an option.</p>
<p><strong>The following simple JavaScript code snippet will add a “browser-ios” class to your body tag</strong> that will allow you to easily tweak elements with basic CSS, and without any server side concerns like page caching.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/html-body-class-for-ios/#more-2628" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Quick Coding Tip: Body Class for iOS Devices (Cache Friendly!)</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>

<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordpress-agencies/">Pulling back the curtain: thoughts on&nbsp;agencies</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordpress-agencies/" title="Pulling back the curtain: thoughts on agencies"><time datetime="2012-04-01T14:16:11-04:00">April 1, 2012</time></a>
</p>
<div class="blog-video-wrap"><div class="blog-video-screen"><div class="fluid-width-video-wrapper" style="position: relative; width: 100%; padding-top: 56.1538%;"><embed src="http://v.wordpress.com/sDP49Oqf" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="650" height="365" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" wmode="transparent" style="position: absolute; width: 100%; height: 100%; left: 0px; top: 0px;"></div></div><div class="blog-video-bottom"></div></div><p>Back in February at WordCamp Phoenix, I participated in a panel on agencies, offering thoughts, experiences, and insights into the agency model. <article class="blog-archive-post post-2052 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry wordcamp-san-diego-talk-caching-for-coders">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-san-diego-talk-caching-for-coders/">WordCamp San Diego Talk: Caching for&nbsp;Coders</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/zack/" title="Posts by Zack" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Zack_avatar-64x64.png" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2012/06/Zack_avatar.png 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Zack</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-san-diego-talk-caching-for-coders/" title="WordCamp San Diego Talk: Caching for Coders"><time datetime="2012-03-17T12:45:12-04:00">March 17, 2012</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/wordcamp-san-diego-talk-caching-for-coders/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<p>I am privileged to have the opportunity to talk about caching for WordPress sites during <a href="http://2012.sandiego.wordcamp.org/">WordCamp San Diego 2012</a>. My talk, titled “Caching for Coders: How, What and When to Cache in WordPress”, will introduce WordPress developers to core concepts for deploying successful caching strategies in WordPress. There will be an emphasis on getting rid of a “cookie cutter” approach to caching design patterns in favor of building caching patterns that fit the needs of&nbsp; specific WordPress sites. I am most excited to discuss the often neglected topic of “when” to cache in WordPress projects. Not all caching strategies are created equal and I will be addressing some of the more successful caching approaches inspired by my work at 10up LLC.</p>
<p>This talk also gives me the opportunity to try out a new model for developing slides for a presentation. I am using HTML5 slides, which I am managing on a <a title="Caching for Coders Repo" href="https://github.com/tollmanz/caching-for-coders">GitHub repo</a>. Hosting these slides on GitHub allows me to effectively “open-source” the talk. Having GitHub as the center of development and discussion of these slides will allow others to contribute to the talk and hopefully let it evolve over time. Who knows what will happen, but I am excited for the potential that this idea has.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-1976 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry were-hiring-a-marketing-coordinator">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/were-hiring-a-marketing-coordinator/">We’re Hiring a Marketing Coordinator!</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/" title="Posts by " rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo avatar-default" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> </a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/were-hiring-a-marketing-coordinator/" title="We’re Hiring a Marketing Coordinator!"><time datetime="2012-03-13T21:07:12-04:00">March 13, 2012</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/were-hiring-a-marketing-coordinator/#comments" class="comments-count">2 Comments</a>
</p>
<p>Are you a tech-savvy, self-motivated marketing professional, or recent college graduate, with a passion for using online and offline tools to help companies better market their services and convert prospects into clients? Then you might be a great fit for 10up’s new Marketing Coordinator role! As Marketing Coordinator, you will be responsible for:</p>
<ul>
<li>Scheduling introduction meetings with prospective new clients</li>
<li>Preparing one-page briefs on new project opportunities that will inform initial conversations with prospects</li>
<li>Developing lead generation channels to expand our prospective client pool</li>
<li>Collaborating with the strategy team to prepare proposals for new project opportunities</li>
<li>Maintaining, updating, and creating content for our website, including client case studies and blog posts</li>
<li>Building a content strategy for 10up’s Facebook and Twitter presences and managing interactions on those platforms</li>
<li>Preparing client status and billing reports</li>
<li>Managing basic operational tasks, including scheduling team trips and preparing monthly client invoices</li>
</ul>
<p>While prior experience is great, enthusiasm and the ability to learn quickly on your feet will serve as great substitutes for experience. As with all of our positions, the Marketing Coordinator’s scope of responsibilities is expected to evolve over time, so you should have the willingness to be flexible and pitch in where needed. Ideally, after an initial training period, the person who fills this role will have the opportunity to take on more senior marketing and project management responsibilities, so excellent communication (both written and verbal) and organizational skills are required.</p>
<p>We envision the Marketing Coordinator position as a full-time role, but applicants seeking part-time work will also be considered. 10up is a distributed company, so you will have the opportunity to work from home, which is just one of the many perks we offer our employees!</p>
<p>Think you’re ready to join team 10up and help us grow our business? Then send your resume, cover letter, and three references to <a href="mailto:jake@get10up.com" target="_blank">jake<code>@</code>get10up.com</a>.</p>
</div>
</article>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-1653 type-post status-publish format-video hentry post_format-post-format-video next-generation-web-html5-css3">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/next-generation-web-html5-css3/">Next Generation Web: What HTML5 and CSS3 Are All&nbsp;About</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/next-generation-web-html5-css3/" title="Next Generation Web: What HTML5 and CSS3 Are All About"><time datetime="2012-02-25T14:16:23-05:00">February 25, 2012</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/next-generation-web-html5-css3/#comments" class="comments-count">2 Comments</a>
</p>
<div class="blog-video-wrap"><div class="blog-video-screen"><iframe loading="lazy" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/11748316.html" width="372" height="318" frameborder="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="no"></iframe></div><div class="blog-video-bottom"></div></div><p>Here are the slides from my talk at WordCamp Phoenix 2012. Presented in the “Think Tank” track, it explores some ideas and concepts that underlie change in web development medium, and introduces coding techniques for the last HTML5 / CSS3 capabilities. Here’s the description from the WordCamp schedule:</p>
<p><em>We’ve all probably heard of HTML5, CSS3, Responsive Design, and other “future of the web” buzzwords. Maybe you’ve even dabbled in HTML5 doctype declarations and “header” tags, or used CSS3 rounded corners or gradients. But most of us have only scratched the surface of these technologies, and for good reason – not everyone is using Chrome 16 or Firefox 9 yet, and even they haven’t settled on uniform implementations. We’ll look at how Responsive Design is already beginning to change the way we approach building sites for different screen sizes, and peak into potentially transformative HTML5 techniques that are only beginning to appear around the web.</em></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</div>
</article>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-1541 type-post status-publish format-video hentry post_format-post-format-video what-would-core-do">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/what-would-core-do/">What Would Core&nbsp;Do?</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/what-would-core-do/" title="What Would Core Do?"><time datetime="2012-02-19T14:58:44-05:00">February 19, 2012</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/what-would-core-do/#comments" class="comments-count">4 Comments</a>
</p>
<div class="blog-video-wrap"><div class="blog-video-screen"><iframe loading="lazy" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/11664563.html" width="372" height="318" frameborder="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="no"></iframe></div><div class="blog-video-bottom"></div></div><p>WWCD? Or, <em>What Would Core Do</em>? Yesterday, at WordCamp Miami, I finally debuted a talk that I had been thinking about for some time. I see WWCD as the third and capstone talk in my “extending WordPress administration” series, and it’s my favorite of the set.</p>
<p>The series began in 2010 at Chicago with “Hijacking WordPress Admin” – one of the first talks to focus on hooks and techniques to generally tailor the administrative panel to individual clients. You can only fit so much into a talk, so rather than focus on good user interface, I focused on sometimes over the top examples to illustrate the idea that the admin panel is actually remarkably flexible. After a few repeats at different WordCamps, I used WordCamp Chicago 2011 to debut the second in the series: “Editing the Visual Editor.” This time, the focus was solely on methods to customize the visual editor and refine the writing experience – the place where publishers spend most of their time.</p>
<p>The capstone talk is the lightest on code (two quick slides at the end). Rather, it gets back to the <em>philosophy</em> of extending WordPress administration, and challenges plug-in and theme authors to “do better.” It’s a fun look at some terrible plug-in practices, with a serious underlying point: when you build on WordPress, do you think about how the core development team would approach the problem?</p>
<p>We’ll hopefully have the video from WordPress.tv soon, as well.</p>
</div>
</article>

<a href="https://10up.com/blog/author/" title="Posts by " rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=64&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=128&amp;d=mm&amp;r=pg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo avatar-default" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> </a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/building-communities-around-content/" title="Building Communities Around Your Content"><time datetime="2012-02-19T14:32:31-05:00">February 19, 2012</time></a>
</p>
<div class="blog-video-wrap"><div class="blog-video-screen"><iframe loading="lazy" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/11649515.html" width="372" height="318" frameborder="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="no"></iframe></div><div class="blog-video-bottom"></div></div><p>How do you build an audience and inspire them to actively engage with your content? <p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2012/editing-the-visual-editor-video-from-wordcamp-chicago/" title="Editing the Visual Editor – video from WordCamp Chicago"><time datetime="2012-01-30T13:27:04-05:00">January 30, 2012</time></a>
</p>
<div class="blog-video-wrap"><div class="blog-video-screen"><div class="fluid-width-video-wrapper" style="position: relative; width: 100%; padding-top: 56.1538%;"><embed src="http://v.wordpress.com/9MTqMCVV" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="650" height="365" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" wmode="transparent" style="position: absolute; width: 100%; height: 100%; left: 0px; top: 0px;"></div></div><div class="blog-video-bottom"></div></div><p>The <a title="Editing WordPress’s Visual Editor" href="https://10up.com/blog/2011/12/editing-wordpress-tinymce-visual-editor/">slides I already posted</a> are the best guide to my talk on editing WordPress’ visual editor, but if you’d like to see the narrative and discussion that go along with it, check out this video on WordPress.tv from WordCamp Chicago 2011.</p>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-334 type-post status-publish format-aside hentry post_format-post-format-aside upcoming-wordcamp-orlando">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content"><div style="width:800px;height:353px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 353px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></div>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-11760 type-post status-publish format-video hentry category-uncategorized tag-speaking tag-tips tag-wordcamp tag-wordpress post_format-post-format-video editing-wordpress-tinymce-visual-editor-2">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2011/editing-wordpress-tinymce-visual-editor-2/">Editing WordPress’s Visual&nbsp;Editor</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2011/editing-wordpress-tinymce-visual-editor-2/" title="Editing WordPress’s Visual Editor"><time datetime="2011-12-20T09:39:04-05:00">December 20, 2011</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2011/editing-wordpress-tinymce-visual-editor-2/#comments" class="comments-count">2 Comments</a>
</p>
<div class="blog-video-wrap"><div class="blog-video-screen"><iframe loading="lazy" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/10647085.html" width="372" height="318" frameborder="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="no"></iframe></div><div class="blog-video-bottom"></div></div><p>These are the slides from a talk I gave at the 2011 WordCamps (WordPress conferences) in <a href="https://2011.chicago.wordcamp.org/session/editing-the-visual-editor/">Chicago</a>, <a href="https://2011.philly.wordcamp.org/session/editing-the-visual-editor/">Philly</a>, and <a href="https://2011.orlando.wordcamp.org/session/editing-the-visual-editor/">Orlando</a>. I consider this a “sequel” to a broader talk on <a title="Editing WordPress Admin" href="https://www.10up.com/blog/2011/03/customizing-wordpress-admin/">editing the WordPress administrative experience</a> that I like to think I pioneered in 2010 at a few WordCamps, including Chicago and Mid-Alantic, which several new speakers now seem to be running with.</p>
<p>WordPress’s visual content editor (<a href="https://www.tinymce.com/">TinyMCE</a>) is, in many ways, at the heart of WordPress’s content management experience. It’s where editors spend most of their time, and where content is crafted to appear on the front end of your site. Like most of WordPress, the editor can be customized to be both more powerful and more specific to the needs of an individual site or client. This presentation covers topics including custom editor stylesheets based on post type, modifying and removing buttons from the editor, and even creating your own custom buttons for the TinyMCE toolbar. It even covers brand new WordPress 3.3 techniques introduced with the new <a href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Function_Reference/wp_editor"><em>wp_editor</em></a> function.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2011/editing-wordpress-tinymce-visual-editor-2/#more-11760" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Editing WordPress’s Visual&nbsp;Editor</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>

</article>

</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-289 type-post status-publish format-image has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized tag-providence tag-speaking tag-wordpress post_format-post-format-image ri-foundation-talk">

<article class="blog-archive-post post-287 type-post status-publish format-video hentry category-uncategorized tag-speaking tag-tips tag-video tag-web-development tag-wordcamp tag-wordpress post_format-post-format-video intro-wordpress-cms">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2011/intro-wordpress-cms/">Introducing WordPress as a&nbsp;CMS</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2011/intro-wordpress-cms/" title="Introducing WordPress as a CMS"><time datetime="2011-08-03T11:47:58-04:00">August 3, 2011</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2011/intro-wordpress-cms/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<div class="blog-video-wrap"><div class="blog-video-screen"><div class="fluid-width-video-wrapper" style="position: relative; width: 100%; padding-top: 75.0769%;"><iframe loading="lazy" width="650" height="488" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/RnVQ6yYfi90.html" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen="" style="position: absolute; width: 100%; height: 100%; left: 0px; top: 0px;"></iframe></div></div><div class="blog-video-bottom"></div></div><p>A week and a half later, here are the slides from my WordCamp Boston 2011 talk, “Introducing WordPress as a CMS”. Unfortunately, the slides don’t include my live demo of some CMS-centric implementations, which I think was eye opening to a few participants.</p>
<p>None-the-less, if you’re looking for an overview of content management concepts applied to WordPress, you can find them here. I’ve uploaded the slideshow as a video to YouTube (to preserve its feel); the video moves quickly, so you might have to be quick on the pause button!</p>
</div>
</article>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-198 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-uncategorized tag-development tag-freebies tag-plug-ins tag-wordpress secondary-html-content-3-0-preview">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2011/secondary-html-content-3-0-preview/">Secondary HTML Content 3.0&nbsp;preview</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2011/secondary-html-content-3-0-preview/" title="Secondary HTML Content 3.0 preview"><time datetime="2011-05-18T19:19:23-04:00">May 18, 2011</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2011/secondary-html-content-3-0-preview/#comments" class="comments-count">14 Comments</a>
</p>
<p>As much as we like giving back to the community, it’s often hard to find time to keep some of the more sophisticated plug-ins up to date. One plug-in that hasn’t been updated in some time that I am frequently asked about is Secondary HTML Content.</p>
<p>I’ve had a number of ambitious goals for 3.0 for some time:</p>
<ul>
<li>Enable a more complete editor experience (notably, Visual / HTML tabs)</li>
<li>Allow users to customize the labels for each content block</li>
<li>Add support for custom post types (not just posts and pages)</li>
<li>Remove arbitrary limit of 5 editor blocks</li>
<li>Integrate the settings with the “Writing” settings page (a logical place for them; I’m make a conscious effort with my themes and plug-ins to not “clutter” the settings panel)</li>
<li>On top of all this, provide a seamless upgrade path for 2.0 users</li>
</ul>
<p>The first bullet has been by far the most challenging. While WordPress has a number of core functions that simplify adding a visual editor, they simply weren’t built with <em>multiple</em> editors on one page in mind. For the technically savvy, there are many hardcoded ID attributes, interacting with both CSS and JavaScript that rely on those IDs. As we know, the DOM is not intended to have multiple elements with identical IDs (particularly when we’re hooking events with JavaScript).</p>
<p>Nonetheless, I’m excited to say that the biggest hurdles have been tackled. Since we can’t work on hobby projects full time, the release is probably at least a couple of weeks out, mostly having to do with the upgrade path code.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-193 type-post status-publish format-image has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorized tag-smashing-magazine tag-tips tag-web-development tag-wordpress post_format-post-format-image smashing-magazine-tips">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content"><div style="width:800px;height:617px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 617px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-173 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-uncategorized tag-downloads tag-web-development tag-wordcamp tag-wordpress customizing-wordpress-admin">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2011/customizing-wordpress-admin/">Customizing WordPress Admin – updated for 3.1 with new&nbsp;tips!</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2011/customizing-wordpress-admin/" title="Customizing WordPress Admin – updated for 3.1 with new tips!"><time datetime="2011-03-25T16:48:45-04:00">March 25, 2011</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2011/customizing-wordpress-admin/#comments" class="comments-count">17 Comments</a>
</p>
<p><div style="width:150px;height:150px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:150px 150px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p>At the heart of the talk was a simple &nbsp;Twenty-Ten child theme, with the focal point being a&nbsp;<em>functions.php</em> file loaded to the gills with hooks and functions that customize the branding and administrative experience (available for download here).</p>
<p><strong>I’ve updated the child theme to 1.5</strong>; in addition to incorporating some suggestions, I’ve updated some small bits (like removing menu items) to take advantage of new WordPress 3.1 API calls and some other best practices (it now <strong>requires WordPress 3.1</strong>).</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2011/customizing-wordpress-admin/#more-173" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Customizing WordPress Admin – updated for 3.1 with new&nbsp;tips!</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-170 type-post status-publish format-video hentry category-uncategorized tag-meetup tag-speaking tag-video tag-wordpress post_format-post-format-video wordpress-is-a-cms">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2011/wordpress-is-a-cms/">That’s a WordPress Site?? – A&nbsp;reminder</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2011/wordpress-is-a-cms/" title="That’s a WordPress Site?? – A reminder"><time datetime="2011-03-22T16:17:48-04:00">March 22, 2011</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2011/wordpress-is-a-cms/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<div class="blog-video-wrap"><div class="blog-video-screen"><div class="fluid-width-video-wrapper" style="position: relative; width: 100%; padding-top: 75.0769%;"><iframe loading="lazy" width="650" height="488" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/VllR9uL8ap0.html" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen="" style="position: absolute; width: 100%; height: 100%; left: 0px; top: 0px;"></iframe></div></div><div class="blog-video-bottom"></div></div><p>This evening, at our <a href="http://www.wordpressprovidence.com/">Providence WordPress Meetup</a>,&nbsp; one of our attendees mentioned that he participated in a training session run by Acquia for aspiring Drupal developers. As a user of WordPress, he was dismayed but not surprised to hear Acquia dismiss another attendee’s questions about WordPress’s viability as a content management system. “If you want a blog, go with WordPress. If you want a real website, go with Drupal.”</p>
<p>I have nothing against Drupal. In fact, I’ve developed websites on Drupal, and have recommended Drupal for some truly atypical and complex website projects. That said, I maintain that WordPress is not just a <em>capable </em>CMS for 90% of websites, but today, it’s the better choice. It’s usability is second to none, and with lower setup costs, hosting requirements, and maintenance requirements, it’s a smarter choice for the average client’s wallet. With the fairly recent addition of features like custom post types, custom taxonomies, and built in menu management, WordPress is quickly closing the gap on that 10% “unsuitability” hole, too.</p>
<p>You can’t blame Acquia for trying to protect their business, but it is a bit sad to see serious companies perpetuating the myth. For those still in doubt, I’ve attached my presentation from my “That’s a WordPress site??” lightning talk from July of last year.</p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-100 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-around-the-web tag-interviews tag-podcast tag-wordpress tag-wordpress-weekly podcast-series-wordpress-commercial">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2010/podcast-series-wordpress-commercial/">Podcast Series: Exploring Commercial WordPress Models</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2010/podcast-series-wordpress-commercial/" title="Podcast Series: Exploring Commercial WordPress Models"><time datetime="2010-05-28T13:59:25-04:00">May 28, 2010</time></a>
•
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2010/podcast-series-wordpress-commercial/#comments" class="comments-count">1 Comment</a>
</p>
<p><div style="width:120px;height:120px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:120px 120px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></p>
<p>The origin of the series actually dated back to January’s WordCamp Boston, where Jeff moderated a panel I organized called “Monetization in a Free World”, intended to help the audience understand the commercial WordPress themes, plug-ins, and SaaS businesses. Jeff ended up being in an impossible position, with 40 minutes to cover all 3 models and incorporate Automattic’s perspective, visa vi Jane Wells. Jeff and I decided it was worth doing justice to the <em>idea</em>; and so the April series of podcast episodes came to life.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2010/podcast-series-wordpress-commercial/#more-100" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on Podcast Series: Exploring Commercial WordPress Models</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-79 type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-appearances tag-speaking tag-wordcamp tag-wordpress wordcamp-miami-great-cms-debate">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2010/wordcamp-miami-great-cms-debate/">WordCamp Miami, The Great CMS&nbsp;Debate</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2010/wordcamp-miami-great-cms-debate/" title="WordCamp Miami, The Great CMS Debate"><time datetime="2010-02-15T13:05:43-05:00">February 15, 2010</time></a>
</p>
<p>I will be talking WordPress at two upcoming events, on opposite ends of the U.S. east coast this month.</p>
<p><strong>WordCamp Miami</strong>. Never a big fan of winter, I’m definitely looking forward to a breather in sunny Miami, Florida. I’m flying down the evening before (this Friday, the 19th) and returning the following Tuesday. It’s actually more economic to stay a couple of extra days at the hotel as compared with taking a Sunday flight back. In any case, <a href="http://wordcampmia.com/speakers/">I’ll be speaking</a> at <a href="http://www.wordcampmia.com/">Miami’s WordCamp</a>, which takes place on Saturday the 20th at the University of Miami. I’ll be presenting a revised version of <a href="http://speakerrate.com/talks/2034-themes-101">Themes 101, which “premiered” at WordCamp Boston</a>. It will incorporate new information on the upcoming “default” theme, along with some feedback from Boston. If you’re in the area and interested in meeting up on Sunday or Monday, send me a note.</p>
<p><strong>Boston North Shore Web Geeks’ </strong><strong>“Great CMS Debate”.</strong> I’ll be representing WordPress on a <a href="http://www.eventbrite.com/event/539248908">panel debating the merits of a few popular web content management systems</a> (CMS). Other panelists include Boston Web Studio’s Marc Amos (<a href="http://expressionengine.com/">Expression Engine</a>), Jay Batson (co-founder of Acquia, a widely known <a href="http://www.drupal.org/">Drupal</a> consultancy), and Fidelity’s Tom Herer (representing <a href="http://kentico.com/">Kentico</a>). My friend, founder of WordCamp Boston, and strategy guru at Optaros, <a href="http://www.openparenthesis.org/">John Eckman</a>, moderates. It takes place on February 25th, at 7 ,pm in Newburyport, Massachusetts.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2010/wordcamp-miami-great-cms-debate/#more-79" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on WordCamp Miami, The Great CMS&nbsp;Debate</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-78 type-post status-publish format-video hentry category-around-the-web tag-video tag-wordcamp tag-wordpress post_format-post-format-video wordpresstv-cameo-intranet">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<h1><a href="https://10up.com/blog/2010/wordpresstv-cameo-intranet/">WordPress.tv Cameo: Intranets</a></h1>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-64x64.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-128x128.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-64 photo" height="64" width="64" loading="lazy" decoding="async"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2010/wordpresstv-cameo-intranet/" title="WordPress.tv Cameo: Intranets"><time datetime="2010-01-10T15:07:50-05:00">January 10, 2010</time></a>
</p>
<div class="blog-video-wrap"><div class="blog-video-screen"><iframe width="650" height="366" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/uGLXHQP5.html" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen=""></iframe><script src="https://v0.wordpress.com/js/next/videopress-iframe.js?m=1435166243"></script></div><div class="blog-video-bottom"></div></div><p>Back in November, I had the pleasure of attending <a href="https://2009.newyork.wordcamp.org/">WordCamp New York City</a>. I spent about 10 minutes presenting my <a href="https://www.cmurrayconsulting.com/software/google-reader-shared-wordpress/">Google Reader plug-in</a>, had a <a href="https://wordcampboston.com/2010/01/06/thats-all-she-wrote-wordcamp-boston-sells-out-again/">kick off WordCamp Boston planning meeting</a>, had the pleasure of <a href="https://blog.afterthedeadline.com/2009/11/16/the-ten-people-you-meet-at-wordcamp-nyc/">meeting inspiring folks like Raffi Mudge</a>, and even had a great conversation in the hallway with <a href="https://ma.tt/">Matt Mullenweg</a> and <a href="https://www.wptavern.com/">Jeff Chandler</a> (me in the&nbsp; middle with the shoulder&nbsp; bag, Matt sitting to my left, Jeff to my right – photo courtesy John Eckman) for about 40 minutes.</p>
<p>One of the sessions I attended was Ramil Teodosio’s <em>WordPress Powered-Intranets</em>. I’ve done a few Intranet implementations of my own and Ramil’s seminar was a bit more focused on SharePoint-like substitution than I expected. My own experience gave me an opportunity to pipe up a couple of times to offer suggestions and, among other things, plug my free <a href="https://www.cmurrayconsulting.com/software/wordpress-restricted-site-access/">Restricted Site Access plug-in</a>, which was born out of an Intranet project, and I thought might be of interest to the audience. Judging by the post-presentation follow-up with a handful of attendees, at least a few found my comments useful.</p>
<p> <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2010/wordpresstv-cameo-intranet/#more-78" class="more-link">Read More <span class="screen-reader-text">on WordPress.tv Cameo: Intranets</span></a></p>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-77 type-post status-publish format-image has-post-thumbnail hentry category-around-the-web tag-podcast tag-thinking tag-wordpress post_format-post-format-image wordpress-weekly-interview">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content"><div style="width:800px;height:800px;background-image:url(data:image/svg+xml;base64,);background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:800px 800px;" data-xblocker="blocked"></div></div>

<article class="blog-archive-post post-76 type-post status-publish format-aside hentry category-around-the-web tag-guest-posts tag-smashing-magazine tag-web-development tag-wordpress post_format-post-format-aside smashing-magazine-advanced-power-tips-for-wordpress-template-developers-reloaded">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2009/smashing-magazine-advanced-power-tips-for-wordpress-template-developers-reloaded/" title="Smashing Magazine: Advanced Power Tips for WordPress Template Developers (Reloaded)"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-256x256.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-512x512.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-256 photo" height="256" width="256" loading="lazy" decoding="async" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a>

</p>
<div class="body-copy">
<p>On the heels of <a href="http://www.jakegoldman.net/2009/11/smashing-magazine-advanced-wordpress-power-tips-for-template-developers/">part 1</a>, <a href="http://www.smashingmagazine.com/2009/12/14/advanced-power-tips-for-wordpress-template-developers-reloaded/">part 2</a> of my Advanced Power Tips for WordPress Template developers was <a href="http://www.smashingmagazine.com/2009/12/14/advanced-power-tips-for-wordpress-template-developers-reloaded/">published on Smashing Magazine</a> this morning. The article made it up to #2 on the Delicious popular bookmarks list during the day. Part 2 reviews techniques for delivering a more elegant, customized administrative experience.</p>
</div>
</div>
</article>
<article class="blog-archive-post post-74 type-post status-publish format-aside hentry category-around-the-web tag-guest-posts tag-smashing-magazine tag-web-development tag-wordpress post_format-post-format-aside smashing-magazine-advanced-wordpress-power-tips-for-template-developers">
<div class="blog-archive-post-content">
<a href="https://10up.com/blog/2009/smashing-magazine-advanced-wordpress-power-tips-for-template-developers/" title="Smashing Magazine: Advanced WordPress Power Tips for Template Developers"><img alt="Avatar photo" src="./Blog _ 10up_files/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-256x256.jpg" srcset="https://10up.com/uploads/2014/09/Jake-Goldman_avatar_1410997004-512x512.jpg 2x" class="avatar avatar-256 photo" height="256" width="256" loading="lazy" decoding="async" data-xblocker="passed" style="visibility: visible;"></a>
<p class="author byline">
<a href="https://10up.com/about/#employee-jake-goldman" title="Posts by Jake Goldman" rel="author" class="author-posts-link"> Jake Goldman</a> on <a href="https://10up.com/blog/2009/smashing-magazine-advanced-wordpress-power-tips-for-template-developers/" title="Smashing Magazine: Advanced WordPress Power Tips for Template Developers"><time datetime="2009-11-29T18:30:06-05:00">November 29, 2009</time></a>

<div class="body-copy">
<p>My latest <a href="http://www.smashingmagazine.com/2009/11/25/advanced-power-tips-for-wordpress-template-developers/" target="_blank">Power Tips article</a> was published last Wednesday on <strong>Smashing Magazine</strong>. Part 1 covers techniques for adding sidebar content elements and associating post categories with pages. Part 2 will be published in about 2 weeks, and focuses on administrative customization.</p>
</div>
</div>
</article>
